Forum Post: 
Post title: qtype_calculated Sudden illegal formula syntax and datasetitem error
Post description: I feel like i've been sharing so many question/quiz related errors recently since updating to Moodle 4.4.4. We've run into a qtype_calculated error. These questions were working fine previously but suddenly we got an illegal formula syntax starting with { error. As well as an error " Cannot get the specified dataset for a dataset dependent question! (question: 1091718, datasetitem: 0) ". I've check the unicode and it shouldn't be the reason for the syntax error since it was and should be able to read the character set. I've hit a wall with these errors. ---(Answer {Eö} + {Es} + 180 ) Illegal formula syntax starting with 'Illegal formula syntax starting with '{'' Debug info: Error code: illegalformulasyntax Stack trace: line 434 of /question/type/calculated/question.php: moodle_exception thrown line 71 of /question/type/calculated/question.php: call to qtype_calculated_variable_substituter->calculate() line 158 of /question/type/calculated/question.php: call to qtype_calculated_question->calculate_all_expressions() line 55 of /question/type/calculated/question.php: call to qtype_calculated_question_helper::start_attempt() line 364 of /question/behaviour/behaviourbase.php: call to qtype_calculated_question->start_attempt() line 1069 of /question/engine/questionattempt.php: call to question_behaviour->init_first_step() line 587 of /question/engine/questionusage.php: call to question_attempt->start() line 129 of /question/bank/previewquestion/preview.php: call to question_usage_by_activity->start_question() ---(Answer {Eoe}+{As}+{Es}-{Es}+{Aoe}-{Aoe} ) Cannot get the specified dataset for a dataset dependent question! (question: 1091718, datasetitem: 0) Debug info: Error code: cannotgetdsfordependent Stack trace: line 253 of /question/type/calculated/question.php: moodle_exception thrown line 156 of /question/type/calculated/question.php: call to qtype_calculated_dataset_loader->get_values() line 55 of /question/type/calculated/question.php: call to qtype_calculated_question_helper::start_attempt() line 364 of /question/behaviour/behaviourbase.php: call to qtype_calculated_question->start_attempt() line 1069 of /question/engine/questionattempt.php: call to question_behaviour->init_first_step() line 587 of /question/engine/questionusage.php: call to question_attempt->start() line 129 of /question/bank/previewquestion/preview.php: call to question_usage_by_activity->start_question()
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: For the first error, Illegal formula syntax starting with 'Illegal formula syntax starting with '{'' , there's a Tracker issue for this: MDL-83515 qtype_calculated no longer supports special characters . It looks like the fix for security issue MSA-24-0026 caused this. I realise that doesn't help much, I can only suggest you watch and vote for the Tracker issue.
Comment 2: Thanks. I find it odd though, I made a copy of the question and then it worked fine. Does it only exist to questions that were created prior to the update?

Forum Post: 
Post title: students list of ungraded attempt quiz
Post description: Sometimes I allow a quiz to be submitted after the deadline has passed using the User Exceptions tool. Or I allow other students to try to improve their grades on a quiz by giving them extra attempts. At the same time, all students have another new quiz to answer because classes are moving forward and time does not stand still. All teachers have many students. This usually means that after a while I've forgotten which students have ungraded tests or which ones I haven't reviewed yet. Then, to fix this I have to go through each quiz, one by one, to check that all my students have all their attempts graded. This involves a lot of time. I think it will be useful to have a tool that shows us a list of all the students who have an ungraded attempt without having to buy each quiz one by one. Does anyone know if moodle has a tool or tip that allows you to do this? Thank you so much
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: If your quiz has any essay question, (you could add a simple essay question yourself) in the quiz, the Grade Me plugin will show every student who needs a quiz, "graded."
Comment 2: Thank you very much
Comment 3: As Al noticed, you are using essay questions. Right? If so, Al's suggestion seems viable, but I don't personally use it. I would first look at the grade book to see which quizzes have students with no grade for a quiz. It might be that for some quizzes every student has a grade. Then using the Gradebook, I would go to those quizzes with ungraded quizzes. From the Grades view, I can see which students require grading. As a suggestion, consider not allowing students to submit late. Make do dates be solid! I know, I know, I know. But train students to do work on time, then you will minimize the number of exceptions. Also, there might be ways to convert essay questions into other automatically graded types, such as T/F, Multiple Choice, etc. Then you would not need to grade these. This is especially important for multiple attempts. Multiple attempts with quizzes containing essay questions can develop into a grading nightmare.
Comment 4: Thank you very much Francesc

Post title: One course - 2 separate identical versions - easy export of quizzes?
Post description: Hi there, For a pilot project in the Caribbean, we will offer free access to our online course 'Coral Reef Architecture & Organisms'. I thus have to duplicate an existing (commercial) course to avoid mixing up paying customers with students accessing the (free) course where they will interact with their teachers. What is the best way of copying the course? I tested it out, and by copying the html code of each topic into the new course, everything seems to be fine (except some links, that will have to be modified) - but what about the quizzes? What is the best way to copy quizzes from one course to a second course? Thank you, Stephan
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: The best way is to backup the course and then to restore it in the new location. That way also all links will be converted correctly automatically.
Comment 2: As you stated, the best way to create a new course is from a backed up old course.  Since you are working on identical courses, this would be ideal, but, I have had with this method when creating later instances of the same course.  It requires adjustment of date specific items such as the course start date and test times once the new course is created.  I wish there were a way to adjust this at installation of the new course.  I am not yet a programmer but I am sure this can be done by adjusting fields in the XML files in the actual archive. Charles
Comment 3: Gustav - You do not mean using the back-up feature available in the admin section? I think this one only backs up student results. I think you mean backing up the entire course somehow... like making an identical copy of it? I just want to be sure to understand you right before giving instructions to my web developer. Thank you very much, Stephan

Post description: Hello, When a student accesses a quiz attempt for the first time, a "quiz attempt" button is displayed. By clicking on this button the student accesses to the quiz. Comment 2: Ok Tim Thanks for your answer I just wanted to know if there was a possibility. María.
Comment 3: Put a Text block on that page with a JavaScript script that automatically triggers the 'Attempt' button. It seems to me it could be done in perhaps less than five minutes.
Comment 4: `<script>` `window.onload = function() {` `let startButton = document.querySelector(".quizstartbuttondiv button");` `if (typeof(startButton) != 'undefined' && startButton != null) {` `startButton.click()` `}`
Comment 5: ok, thanks Dominique and Matthias. María.

Forum Post: 
Post title: [3.8.3+] Adding quiz sections, showing multiple questions per section?
Post description: I had read in a very old thread that a quiz could have sections . For me this is good since I want a quiz with the first set of 5 questions relating to one chapter of my content, and the next set of 11 questions relating to a different chapter, and a section with 7 questions, and so on. I'm currently using description question types, but it doesn't look great and it means I have questions in my banks that aren't questions. I went ahead and built the quiz with all the questions. I then clicked on the 'Add' button at the bottom and it gives me these options: a new question from question bank a random question There's no option to add a section. I have discovered what I need to to to put section headings in arbitrary locations within the quiz, which is this: Click the repaginate quiz button Repaginate with 1 question per page. in the 'add' menu for the question BEFORE i want a section heading, click add. This now has the following drop-down a new question from a question bank a random question a new section heading I enter the section heading as I want it, and do this for all locations throughout the quizI click the repaginate quiz button againI then select 'unlimited' questions and update. this collapses down the pages and leaves the sections I've defined.voilà I have sections in the right spots But here's the rub . I wanted to show those 5 questions on the first section all together, since the questions all interrelate and I want the learners to see that. I wanted to show the 11 questions on the section section together. I have the quiz layout set to 'never, all questions on one page' but one there are sections it flat out ignores what you set here. Is there a quiz plugin or behaviour or setting I can fiddle that will allow multiple questions on a section?
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: You don't have to repaginate with one question per page. Page breaks can be anywhere, there should be little add/remove page-break icons between each question on the left. You can use those to get page-breaks exactly where you want. (Repaginate is only there to quickly re-layout a large quiz.)
Comment 2: Ok, that's one thing then. The quiz still presents one question per page, even though the quiz's Layout setting is set to 'All questions on one page'. Once the quiz has more than one section it ignores that setting and just does one question per page. Why is that? Is there a way I can override the behaviour so that it shows all questions in a section?
Comment 3: Hello Tim St.Clair, Does the following video answer your question?
Comment 4: I managed to remove all the pagination so that there was only the sections I had defined, and went into a new attempt. This showed one question per page, rather than the structure I had set. I then went back in to edit the questions and sure enough it had inserted pages between each question again. Removing these via the little arrows icon and saving and starting another attempt showed multiple pages again. I have recreated the quiz as a new activity and added sections as I was building it this time, rather than retroactively applying them, and it has worked now and has kept the paging that I want. I have a feeling there's a particular set of steps I could follow to mess it up again but for now this works the way I want and I'm not going to lose sleep chasing possible ways to break it again. Thanks for sharing the video!
Comment 5: There could well be a bug here. If you are able, please could you perform this test: Go to the Edit quiz page for the problem quiz. Click one of the add/remove page-break icons. Press F5 to reload the page. This will confirm if the edit really worked on the server . If not, it would be an added bonus if you could Set Debugging to Developer level. And/or open the network tab in your web browsers developer tools. Then click the icon again. Can you see the Ajax request in the browser developer tools, if so, does it look like it worked? Are there any errors logged in the PHP error log on the server. (Don't worry if you can't do the extra debugging, but it might reveal what is going on.)

Forum Post: 
Post title: Error reported: abnormal root count
Post description: When I restore a question of an arbitrary question type (not STACK !), I get the following error: 
```text
The PRT named "prt1" is malformed in question id <id> and 
does not have a single root, (Question name "<name>").  Error 
reported: abnormal root count: 0(<>1)
```
 But: This is due to entries in the table `qtype_stack_prts` which have the value "-1" in the field `firstnodename` - obviously created by the `function process_qtype_stack_prt` in line 142 in `restore_qtype_stack_plugin.class.php` . https://github.com/maths/moodle-qtype_stack/blob/master/backup/moodle2/restore_qtype_stack_plugin.class.php The line 142 says `$data->firstnodename = -1` ; // This will be fixed later. So I guess this is a bug? Did anyone encounter this error before? I am using Moodle 3.7.4 and Stack 4.2.2
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: Well, a bug happened in the past, causing you have have some STACK question in the database which has been left in a broken state. Probably too late now to work out how that happened, but you will need to find that question and fix it to get out of this situation.
Comment 2: Yes, you are right - I really can't say anything about the possible history (creation, restoration) of the corrupted stack datasets, that happend before my time. Setting the field `firstnodename` to "0" made the error disappear. What really is odd is that I definitly don't have a
single stack question in this course and yet the function `after_execute_question` in `question/type/stack/backup/moodle2/restore_qtype_stack_plugin.class.php` is triggered during restoration. This also happend with just a single question of the multichoice type in the backup! Do you have any idea how this can happen?

Post title: This forum post has been removed
Post description: The content of this forum post has been removed and can no longer be accessed.
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: I am not sure what you mean by "blank tests", but I can tell you how to delete attempts. 1) Teacher opens the course 2) Goes to the quiz 3) Looks at results. Each of the students attempts will be listed below their names and there will be other information, like when they started the test, how long they took, and the final grade (or there might not be a grade because the test is still open). If you put checkmarks in the checkboxes in the leftmost column on the rows where you want to delete attempts, you can set the "with selected" dropdown box to delete.  This will delete the attempts that you have marked.  My recollection is that incomplete attempts can be deleted just the same as completed attempts. I hope that helps! atw

Comment 3: For that you can use File -> Print
Comment 4: Hello Giang, I may be missing some detail about the problem you are facing, but if I understand correctly the printout you need is not intended for students.  If the copy you need is just for your reference as comparison with other quizzes, why don't you: 1) edit and set the quiz you want to print with the option QUESTIONS PER PAGE "Unlimited" 2) Then click on "Preview" the quiz, mouse right-hand click and select "print". Comment 5: Thanks Cristina Berisso I need to Print egress examination questions leave student can test on paper because In Viet Nam There are subjects there can not test on computer. Please help me!
Comment 6: Hello Giang, Please try what I suggested in my previous posting. The printout may use a few more pages than if it was optimized, but it will work and save you from typing everything by hand. I have used this type of "printed" test for some students with dissabilities who needed some extra time or special assessment settings, or that for some technical reason needed a printed form of the test. If there are multiple choice questions the students will mark with pencil the correct answer (same type of response for the multiple answer questions) and it will be very straight forward for the fill_in_the_blank, short answer or essay type questions.

I am currently using moodle 1.7 & I have been looking to re-sort the jumble that is my question bank & categories. What I have done so far is: 1. Create a new test with the questions I want in an out the way place. 2. Get 1 user to open the test & attempt one question & close the test. (still with me) 3. I then log on as a teacher / admin, open the test back up & click onto the item analysis 4. I can then download the test to text & then copy to excel. Forum Post: 
Post title: Unlock activity completion
Post description: Scenario: In a course we have a quiz with no Grade to pass , and under Activity completion option Require passing grade wasn't checked. We want to change both of these so that learners must achieve a grade to pass. Learners have attempted the quiz so we must click Unlock completion options . Under What happens when you unlock the docs say: Once you unlock options and then click 'Save changes', all completion information for the activity will be deleted and, if possible, regenerated according to the new settings. If the new completion option […] is automatic then, depending on the options chosen, the system may or may not be able to construct a correct current value for everyone. Most other options will be recalculated successfully. Surely changing a quiz' grading requiement is an automatic (not manual) completion option? Because the above doesn't happen, learners who previously attempted the quiz and achieved the newly set passing grade are now shown as not having completed the activity. Is it possible to unlock a quiz' activity completion options and get them to be automatically regenerated? And are the docs above wrong or am I misunderstanding them? Moodle 3.9.14+.
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: It should be automatically regenerated. If in doubt, check on a test course first, before you do it anywhere you really care about. Also, be aware there are bugs (that are being worked on) MDL-58266 , MDL-74533 .
Comment 2: Thanks Tim. I've re-tested and the activity completion isn't getting automatically regenerated (I'm trying this on a test site for now). I'll read through those Tracker issues and see if I can work anything out.
Comment 3: This was my mistake: Student must view this activity to complete it is checked by default and I was ignoring it. Of course that criterion requires manual action by the student so activity completion was not automatically regenerated. When I uncheck Student must view this activity to complete it with just Student must receive a grade to complete this activity : "Yes" and Require passing grade : "Yes" it gets automatically regenerated as expected.

Post title: Quiz eliminating questions
Post description: I'm a beginner, but I'd like to create quizes where the results will determine a certificate. Inside these quizes, some questions, if wrongly answered would prevent the user to have the certificate even if the score is huge. I did not find anything about that in help files. Could someone help and tell me if it's possible ? Thanks in advance. Thibault
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: Please use either the lesson module (which presents one question at a time and can be programmed to only display subsequent pages if correct answers are forthcoming) or use Bernard's " activities linking ". Tim
Comment 2: Hi Tim, Thanks for the answer. My problem is that on that case the trainee will know that the eliminating question is the first one. I'd like to have random quizes with an eliminating question on a random position, I'm not sure that would work ? Thibault
Comment 3: Hi Thibault, Sounds like an interesting way to do a quiz. However, there is no setting in Moodle as an elimination question. Maybe someone can come up with a workaround solution. Perhaps you could set the points for the particularly important questions much higher than the other questions, even score them with a huge percentage. Do you meet your students face-to-face? How do you plan to give them a certificate? Print your own and hand it to them? If so, you can explain why certain questions were so important. Tell us a little more of your aims and situation, and hopefully someone can give you a good suggestion. Don

Forum Post: 
Post title: Future quiz scores counting as "hidden" in the gradebook
Post description: Hello, When a quiz with has an open date in the future, the grade may be hidden in the gradebook, even if the quiz itself is visible to the students on the course page.  This is a problem, because the default gradebook setting at our school is to hide the course total if it contains hidden items.  Even though the future quiz is available on the course page, the quiz is hidden in the gradebook and so the course total is hidden.  We'd like to keep that default setting, so simply changing the course total settings to "Show total excluding hidden items" isn't an option. After much experimentation, I discovered that the quiz's visibility in the gradebook was determined by the "Points" checkbox in the "Later while the quiz is still open" column of the quiz's Review Options setting:  if the box is checked, the quiz appears in the gradebook.  If that box is not checked, the quiz is hidden in the gradebook.  So one solution to the problem would be to check that box, and allow students who have completed the quiz to view their scores before everyone has completed the quiz.  Unfortunately, one of our instructors doesn't want grades to be visible until after the quiz closes, so checking that box isn't an option for her. Is there some way for the future quiz scores to count as empty, rather than hidden?
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: Blair, I don't know if you have noticed some additional conversations in the " Option to Exclude Hidden Items from Grader Report Grade Calculation " discussion. I don't know if that discussion parallels your post. I am puzzled by your statement that "the grade may be hidden in the gradebook, even if the quiz itself is visible to the students on the course page."  I seem to recall that when an item is made visible to students in the course, such as a quiz, it becomes visible in the grade book.  Yet, an instructor can purposely hide this grade, if desired.  And there might be some settings that might hide the activity.  I don't know.  I am just trying to add a few thoughts to this conversation.

Forum Post: 
Post title: How to change many mult choice questions to shuffle-
Post description: Hey all- So I just upgraded to 1.7, and I've come to realize that the thousands of mult choice questions I have are all set to "do not shuffle". I'd like to switch everything to shuffle, and also set this as the default for new questions I import in XML format. So.... 1. Is there any way I can change all these questions to "shuffle answers" without going through each one, one by one by one by one? 2. Is there someway to set the default for new XML imported questions to "shuffle answers"? Thanks for the help in advance-
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: Hi I was asking something similar last week. I got this: In order for imported questions to allow shuffled answers by default, change the file \question\format.php in line 179 from 1. $question->shuffleanswers = 0; to 1. $question->shuffleanswers = 1; In order for newly created questions to have shuffled answers by default, change the equivalent setting to 1 in the file moodle/mod/quiz/mod.html I don't know if that will fix your exisiting shuffle problem and I don't know about the XML issue. regards Paul
Comment 2: Hey Paul - thanks for the help! 1. I changed the format.php but when I import XML files it still fails to set it to shuffle. I did test it with GIFT and it worked perfectly (set newly imported questions to shuffle). Any ideas?
Comment 3: And remember to vote for MDL-6768 in the tracker. This only requires a quick update of CVS and it would avoid future confusion for others. Hopefully if it gets some votes it will get fixed. It needs to be changed for Moodle_16_Stable, Moodle_17_Stable and HEAD.
Comment 4: What did you upgrade from? The only way to do this is by going straight to the database and running a query like: UPDATE mdl_question_multichoice SET shuffleanswers = 1. Note I have not tested this. Modifying the Moodle database can cause serious damage if you do something wrong. Take a full database backup first . I think that Howard fixed it so that in 1.7+ the import picks up the default of do/don't shuffle from the defaults you have set for the quiz on the admin page.
Comment 5: Tim - As regards #2, I'm not sure Howard actually did this. I do remember reading discussion about it being done; however, I just check CVS for Moolde_16_Stable, Moodle_17_Stable and HEAD (the /question/format.php) and from what I can tell MDL-6768 is still an issue (i.e. shufflequestions=0 rather than shufflequestions=1). I hope that you are able to find some time to commit this quick fix. In the meantime, I have encouraged others to vote for it. Thanks for all of your work on the quiz module. Please know that you are making a significant contribution to the Moodle community and that your efforts and those at OU are greatly appreciated. Peace - Anthony. p.s. I essentially did what Tim suggested in #1 to fix my imports and it worked fine but as he notes before doing any direct SQL manipulation of your data you should have a good backup.
Comment 6: Ah, I was remembering the discussion, not the result. We'll have to hope that Howard has some spare time.
Comment 7: Hey Tim- Thanks for the help- --> I've run some test trials of the query you mentioned - it seems to work just fine. If any problem show up I'll let you know. Thanks for saving me endless amounts of time!

Forum Post: 
Post title: Handling Large number of Question Categories at the System Level
Post description: In our current Moodle setup (3.1), we have a large number of question categories. We also have a high degree of question category reuse between courses. As a result we have about 8000 question categories (and growing) in the System context . We are running into issues with how Moodle displays the question categories. It creates a drop down of all categories. This ends up create a dropdown with 8000 items contained in it. Some pages have this dropdown in two places. This is causing both performance issues as well as usability issues. We are working on a way to improve the display of these dropdowns for our site (ideally making it searchable via ajax ), but are unsure what the best way is to tackle the issue. In some places, the dropdown is being displayed with "html_writer" and in others is in a "moodle_form". Many of the locations aren't using renderers. Is there an approach anyone can think of to modify (outside of core) how these dropdowns are being displayed or does it make sense to make a new card in the tracker to add renderers for the question category pages?
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: Wow - that is a huge amount of categories.  I can't imagine ever trying to backup or restore a course...unless you exclude the question bank. Not sure on the category search but there are two very cool plugins (Quick List) and (Quick Course List) that use AJAX to search.  I wondered if they could be duplicated into a new block that search questions - then you would just need a way to be able to select and add to a quiz from the block...

Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: From what I can tell, the issue seems to lie with the `mdl_quiz_attempts`.`layout` field: all the other mdl_quiz_attempts have a layout that runs from 0-9 (randomized order). I could probably post another record for the same quiz, if it were helpful. I do not know what version of Moodle (1.9?) or mod_quiz (no idea) we were running back in 2012.
Comment 2: You are right to focus on that anomalous id. Your guess about 1.9 is one idea. This could be an attempt made in a version of Moodle older than 2.1, and something went wrong during the upgrade. The other possible explanation is similar: it could have come from restoring an old quiz attempt. I can see a few options for dealing with this - most of which assume that you don't need this quiz attempt any more: You could try deleting it using the option in the  Quiz results report. (This will either work or give the same error.) You could try editing directly in the database . Remove '450821,' from '5,1,6,450821,8,2,7,4,3,9,0'. ... etc.
Comment 3: I tried directly editing the layout field in the database (removing '450821,' as suggested); this appears to have cleared up both the error in the cron and the error on the page itself. Interestingly enough, now that that record is not causing an error, it is marked as state = 'abandoned', so double confirmation that cron was able to process it. Thanks for the nudge, Tim!

Forum Post: 
Post title: Questions in multiple categories
Post description: This is probably not the best forum for my question, but maybe someone can redirect it or tell me it can be done. I am setting up a series of short quizzes that students complete after each section of work in learning HTML. The course that we have set up gets them to work their way through several exercises and then complete a short review quiz before moving on to the next set of exercises. I am presently setting up my first quiz with a bank of questions. I have set up a number of categories. Unfortunately, the short sections of exercises cover material from several different categories. So I would really like to categorise questions as section1, 2 ... questions in order to quickly generate a random set of questions for each section. At the end of the course, though, I would also like to be able to use the same question base to generate a set of questions covering all the different HTML categories such as text tags, image tags etc. Is there a way to allocate questions to two different sets of categories? If not, would others also find this helpful? Thanks Len PS if anyone has a bank of questions on HTML that they would be willing to share I'd be grateful.
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: My understanding is that it is possible to nest categories. Thus you create an overarching category Birds, then within that categories for Woodland, Coastal..., then within that Robin, Blackbird...with your questions here. Then you set up tests that pull randomly from all downstream questions. I don't know if that makes sense to you.

Post title: I don't fully understand random questions
Post description: Moodle 1.4.4 I have a bank of questions - around 50 so I want 5 quizzes of 10 multiple choice random questions. Created the first quiz and added my 10 random questions and then did the same for the second. In doing so some questions popped up ... Are questions random to the user or do all participants get the same random questions? Will questions be repeated in quiz 2 or do random questions only take from unsused questions?
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: Hi Darren, My understanding is that "random questions" are selected  randomly  from the fixed pool (the category you use to pull them from) every time the quiz is presented to each student, that is you get a completely different quiz each time a user makes a quiz attempt. How different is the quiz is a matter of statistics. For each of your quizzes, 10 different questions will we selected out of 50, at random.

Post title: global changes in an existing numerical question bank
Post description: Hello, I've created a numerical question bank by importing from a file, having in total more than 250 items. Prepared a quizz with 15 questions randomly drawn and have discovered after the quizz is closed that I was too strict setting the tolerances in the answers. So I'd like now to relax them a bit, by changing its figures. I can do it quickly in the external file, which was generated using an spreadsheet, but don't know if I could then re-import the file keeping the quizz structure. There was 25 student which already submit the quizz. I'm using version 1.6.2. Thanks. Paco
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: The content of this forum post has been removed and can no longer be accessed.
Comment 2: Thansk Pierre. I'll do that and next time think twice before going ahead with a long quizz. Paco
Comment 3: If you know what you are doing, proceed very, very carefully, and backup you database first, you could fix this directly in the database using a query something like 
```text
UPDATE mdl_question_answers SET tolerance = 
[new_tolerance]

WHERE tolerance = 
[old_tolerance]
 AND 
[courseid]
 = (
 SELECT qc.course FROM mdl_question_categories qc
 JOIN mdl_question q ON qc.id = q.category
 WHERE q.id = question);
```

Forum Post: 
Post title: How can I make a quiz with penalty grades for wrong answers
Post description: I want to make a quiz with positive marks for correct answers and with negative marks for wrong answers for some of the questions only (not all the wrong answers) How can I do that?
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: According to the documentation for the Multiple Choice question type ↗ : "With multiple-answer Multiple Choice questions, each answer (choice) may carry a positive or negative grade. If the total grade is negative then the mark for this question will be zero." "With single-answer Multiple Choice questions, you can specify negative or non-negative grades for each answer. A single-answer Multiple Choice question can result in a negative mark if its behaviour is set to Deferred feedback, but not other modes (Adaptive mode, Interactive with multiple tries, etc.)..." If you have more than one question in a quiz, the total mark is the algebraic sum of the marks for each question. So if you have a negative mark for a "single-answer Multiple Choice question in a quiz with Deferrred Fedback behaviour", this negative mark will be subtracted from the marks for the other questions. However, if the total mark for the quiz is negative, the grade in the gradebook will be zero. There might be other question types that accept negative marks, but I don't know about them. Also, I don't think there can ever be any negative grades in the gradebook.

Post title: Quiz Password Modal Doesn't Close
Post description: We are working on using our Moodle v 4.4.1+ for exams. We need to ensure the tests are as secure as they can be.  I've noticed three things I couldn't work around in setting these up.  I was unable to find mention of these on the forums, if these have been posted feel free to let me know. 1) When a student enters the PW and navigates away from the quiz, they can continue their attempt without a password. (we're going to leverage the timer to mitigate, but this isn't ideal) 2) If a student enters a PW for the quiz then enters the quiz, then they use the browser's back button to navigate back to the launch page, the PW modal is still there, with the PW filled in and unmaskable. Also the "Start Attempt" and "Cancel" buttons no longer work. Student needs to navigate away from the launch page and return to get rid of the modal. 3) When using the extra pop-up quiz screen for security... if the student uses PW to get into the test, the student is prompted twice for the PW. If the student uses the browser close window button, the quiz window closes and the modal with the quiz PW form is still there. The PW can be unmasked and viewed. We use online proctors that orally convey the PW and we'd like the student to not be able to freely see it written down. There is a potential that the online proctor is disconnected and the student could unmask and share that PW with students who could open the test prematurely and without proctor. We considered it, but we are unable to use the secure browser for test security.
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: > We considered it, but we are unable to use the secure browser for test security. Do you mean you can't have the Safe_Exam_Browser ? Then you will not have the security it offers. Isn't that logical?
Comment 2: If a quiz is protected by a PW, there shouldn't be any way to access it without that PW being supplied each time access is attempted. Having a special browser for that purpose is one heck of a work around. I'm not too hip to PHP, but we're in the processes of migrating from a PHP based platform that didn't have these issues and didn't require a special browser. And not for nothing after you're done with a form in a modal and submitted the data, the modal should close. That seems logical to me, but the modal persists....
Comment 3: I made a band-aid for the password issue by hiding the pw reveal icon and eliminating the MS Edge pw reveal, but only on the quiz pw form 'cause its an accessibility concern. If anyone is in a situation where you can't install extra software on the students' computers for various reasons, the quiz is not very secure. The quiz password should close when the form is successfully submitted and the student should have to enter the password every time they leave and come back to the quiz. If anyone wants to give a me a quick set-up lesson on modifying the source code or a video series with instructions, I'll take care of it.
Comment 4: i have the same problem too, but we can try to input wrong password first and then quiz modal password will close. Then you will asked to input the password again while the input textbox is in the same page with the quiz.

Post title: Auto-increment quiz time
Post description: We are developing a plugin to automatically extend the quiz time limit for users who encounter a network failure.Given below is the information for the same. Background In a quiz where some time gets wasted due to issues like network failures or hardware crash, the user needs to be given additional time to compensate fairly for this loss. Problem There is no way to automatically quantify the lost time. The compensation of the lost time has to be done manually with the help of user overrides. Proposed solution Monitor the health of the connection using heartbeats provided by websockets Record the connections and disconnections of  a user attempting a quiz Calculate the time lost between connections. Automatically set user-overrides to extend the quiz time limit by the amount of time lost. Implementation details NodeJS, ExpressJS, Socket.IO for heartbeat tracking. Trigger moodle to set user-overrides P.S :  Comments, advice and suggestions are gratefully appreciated.
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: You might find the code in https://github.com/timhunt/moodle-quizaccess_offlinemode interesting. It does a slighly different thing than you are talking about, but there still might be some bits of interest ...
Comment 2: Thanks tim, I will check this code for my reference.

Forum Post: 
Post title: Organizing quiz categories
Post description: I am new to moodle this year.  I am creating quizzes and quiz bank categories so I can create random quizzes.  I have a course and I created a quiz and categories with questions.  This course uses 2 textbooks, so I am wondering about organizing my question bank categories. I am thinking of this structure, please feel free to comment on it... Question categories for 'Quiz: Book 1 Chapter 1 Quiz ' Question categories for 'Course: My Course' Book 1() Chapter 1-MC() Chapter 1-FIB() Chapter 1-Match() Chapter 2-MC() Chapter 2-FIB() Chapter 2-Match() ... so on Book 2() Chapter 1-MC() Chapter 1-FIB() Chapter 1-Match() Question categories for 'Category: My School' Question categories for 'System' Currently, the question banks are listed under the quiz category Question categories for 'Quiz: Book 1 Chapter 1 Quiz ' Chapter 1-MC() Chapter 1-FIB() Chapter 1-Match() And there is a quiz for each chapter so ditto for each chapter in each book. My understanding is that if I put the banks under 'System' then I would be using the same banks for every course I create with these quizzes for every semester.  If I put the banks under 'Course: My Course' then when I copy the course for multiple sections OR for next semester, it will create new versions of the banks?  Not really sure if there is any difference (except organizationally) between course and quiz levels? (maybe being able to create a final exam?)  If I put them under the quiz, then I won't be able to use them to create a final exam? Sorry for all of the questions, but I read the docs and am still not certain? Now that I write it out, I think it would be better to create the banks at the course level so I could pull from them for a final test? MK
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: Some of this organization depends upon what you are planning to use in a quiz within a course. First, I like to create categories for my courses, such as Business, Engineering, etc.  My thoughts are that Business courses might share questions from Business textbooks, so question banks created under the Business category can be shared by other Business courses. Then, for a course, such as Statistics, I make another question bank category for "statistics."  Then, under this category, I create separate categories for different chapters, such as "Ch01-Introduction," "Ch02-Descriptive Statistics," etc.  Finally, I put the textbooks question banks under these.  Yes, I might have more than one textbook's question banks under one chapter. When I create a quiz for Ch01-Introduction, I tell the quiz to pull questions from the "Ch01-introduction" group and "subcategories."  Using this approach, if I decide to add more questions, such as textbook #3 questions, I can keep these in their own group, under Ch01-Introduction, and the Moodle quiz can pull from all three resources.  You can even add another category under Ch01-Introduction titled something like "My own created questions." But a lot of this, once again, depends on how you plan to use your questions.  I run my own small Moodle, and don't have to worry about other teachers, so I can do whatever I think is best for ME. So, just as a suggestion, an alternative solution for you would be something like: System | Course_Category | Category_Topic1 Chapter 1 Book1 -MC() Chapter 1 Book1 -FIB() Chapter 1 Book1 -Match() Chapter 1 Book2 -MC() Chapter 1 Book2 -FIB() Chapter 1 Book2 -Match() Category_Topic2 Chapter 2 Book1 -MC() Chapter 2 Book1 -FIB() Chapter 2 Book1 -Match() Chapter 2 Book2 -MC() Chapter 2 Book2 -FIB() Chapter 2 Book2 -Match() This assumes that you might want to create a quiz for Chapter 1 that might include randomly selected questions from all groups under the Category_Topic. I also don't know if the two textbooks, in your example, parallel each other, but I think that you get the idea. Another advantage of this approach is that it gives you the easy ability to remove old textbook question banks and add new, without the need to do anything at the "edit quiz" level.  Pretty powerful stuff.  Moodle is the only major LMS with this much power in its quiz engine.
Comment 2: Thanks for the detail. This is good stuff. On another note, since I already have question banks and quizzes using these banks, I assume that I can reorganize them without breaking the quizzes I already have?
Comment 3: If you pointed your quizzes to the specific question bank, you should be able to move it around. However, make sure to try one chapter first before moving all. If you aren't using some elaborate method to set up your quizzes, and instead, just picking questing randomly from one question bank, it usually is pretty quick to remove quiz questions and re-add them from a Category_Topic.
Comment 4: The deed is done and it worked fine. Thanks for the support.

Post title: Shown Quiz but Hidden in Gradebook
Post description: I am trying to mark a 10 question quiz as a pass on attempt. Meaning that the student will get full credit for the quiz on attempt regardless of their score. But I also want them to know which questions they got right and wrong. My workaround is to uncheck the "Mark" option under the quiz Review tab under "Later, while the quiz is still open". This shows the quiz and the students are allowed to review their quiz attempt but hides the quiz from the gradebook. Then I created a grade item for each quiz and edited it's calculation as "= Quiz1 /10", "= Quiz2 /10", etc. Then I edited the grade category grade calculation to "=((Sum(ceil( Quiz1 ), ceil( Quiz2 )))/2)*100 This gives me the desired result when I look at the grade book as admin, with the quizzes being graded as either a 1 (for any quiz attempted) or a 0 (for any quiz not attempted) on the grade book but I can still go into each individual quiz and check my attempt. The problem is when I switch to "student" role, the whole category in the grade book is blank.
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: Moving to Quiz forum...
Comment 2: Probably because the quiz does not have an end date and so is still open and you selected to not show them marks while open...
Comment 3: You are right. That was the issue. I checked the Marks option under "Later, while the quiz is still open" and now it displays correctly even in student mode. I ended up deleting the grade items and perform every calculation in the category total calculations. I have a new problem now though in that the course total is blank in student role. Could this be due to the category total being custom calculated?

Post title: Global Quiz Question Penalty
Post description: Just upgraded to v1.9, but I'm as dumb as they come as far as programming. I import all my quiz questions via Aiken format from another document.  Everything is multiple choice, and I want all penalties to be .25. Can this be set globally, so that imports all have this factor after being imported? Failing that, is there a way of doing a "search and replace" to change the factor after they are imported? For either option, I will need directions in some detail, as I don't yet know where all of these files are.
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: If you are happy using a tool like PHPMyAdmin to directly edit things in the database , you can use a command like: UPDATE mdl_question SET penalty = 0.25 WHERE category = [XXX] (You need to replace [XXX] with the internal id of the category these questions are in.) If you don't know what you are doing, and make a mistake, then this could be a way to do a lot of damage. Another way is the export your questions again as Moodle XML format, use search and replace on the XML file to change all the penalties, then re-import these questions, and delete the ones from the Aiken format.

Post title: Quiz "quick pass" and "quick fail"
Post description: We have a private client that wants to implement some changes to their exam format. They want to do a "quick pass" and "quick fail" functionality. You find this type of functionality with license or state exams. This is when you are moving through the test and it calculates the score as each question is answered. Thereby if the student has no way to pass based on the questions they've answered thus far, the exam will end the attempt, likewise, if they've answered enough questions to have passed, it will also end the attempt. The navigation of the questions would be set to sequential. Example: 25 question exam where you needed 20 questions (80%) to pass it would end the test immediately whenever you got a 6th question wrong, or it would end immediately as soon as someone got 20 questions correct. Anybody have suggestions?
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: This functionality is not currently available in the Moodle quiz module.
Comment 2: If it is not sensible that savvy computer science students could uncover the unattempted questions, a quick workaround, yet probably needing to be customized for each different quiz, might be possible in JavaScript . A little fun. A more solid and general solution would probably require the development of a new plugin. Lots of fun.
Comment 3: You could consider https://moodle.org/plugins/mod_capquiz or https://moodle.org/plugins/mod_adaptivequiz (sorry to see that second one is currently unmaintained.)

Post title: Automated Math Question Generator
Post description: I've create a web page that generates math fact questions (1+1, 3 2 , etc....) that can be imported into Moodle using the Moodle XML format. You simply set the limits on the numbers, for example all of the perfect square roots from 4 through 100. Hopefully this will be able to save some elementary and high school teachers some time. If anyone would like to translate this page I would like to make it available for other languages. Link: http://aschool.us/moodle-scripts/math-questions.php Aaron

Forum Post: 
Post title: Question Type: Type to label parts of an image
Post description: Hi everyone, There are lots of tasks where students are required to label parts of a diagram with short answers. Currently, there's the question type of Drag and Drop onto images, but in many cases, we'd want to encourage students to actively think and recall the knowledge rather than to passively choose from a list. I think it'd be great if there's a question type that requires students to type to label parts of an image. My current workaround is to label the parts in the image with questions, which they can't type directly in, and use SHORT ANSWER below the image. It works, but doesn't look good, and can be confusing for primary school pupils. Thank you for reading. Doan
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: Hello Mão, Video Embedded Answers (Cloze) - Short answers onto image https://moodleformulas.org/course/view.php?id=89&section=28 ↗
Comment 2: That is a really nice use of Cloze!
Comment 3: Hello Jon, Here is another use of Cloze: Video Embedded Answers (Cloze) - Multiple choice onto image https://moodleformulas.org/course/view.php?id=89&section=29 ↗
Comment 4: Hi Dominique Bauer, Thank you very much. I'm sorry for my late reply. I'm learning to apply your solution to MR, MCV, MC, which makes embedded answer cloze so much more powerful. It is a bit more challenging for our teachers, but I hope they'll soon get used to it. Thank you again. Mao
Comment 5: Helo Mao, Thank you for your feedback. To facilitate the positioning of input boxes on the background image, you can use browser extensions as shown in the following video: Video Positioning an element onto an image CC BY-SA 3.0 https://nl.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tingatinga#/media/Bestand:Ally-TT4787.jpg ↗ https://moodleformulas.org/course/view.php?id=77&section=73 ↗
Comment 6: Video African animals.
Comment 7: Can you describe or link a description on how to get the answer labels in the right place?  The video won't load for some reason.
Comment 8: Hello Jeff, What video are you referring to? I added some explanations on https://moodleformulas.org/course/view.php?id=77&section=73 ↗ . It's not complete but it can help you get started.
Comment 9: None of them would play embedded on this page for me, but I found them on YouTube, but had trouble following them (are they meant to have sound?) The explanation you posted was very helpful. Thank you!
Comment 10: Got a chance to do it and it worked great! Boxes appeared and everything. Out of curiosity, how did you get the faded, rounded, red-lined fill boxes in the animal image above? That's a nice effect.
Comment 11: @Jeff, If the videos play on Youtube, they should also play on moodleformulas. I mean they are nothing special. Have you tried Mozilla Firefox or Google Chrome browsers? No, unfortunately they don't have sound yet. If you check this example ↗ , you will see that positioning the answer boxes onto the background image is indeed quite simple to obtain. In the example with the animals, I added formatting for the faded, rounded, red-bordered answer boxes. Again, this is not very difficult to do. It would normally be done with three lines of CSS , but since the Atto editor removes the style tag, I prefer to do it with Javascript , which can make formatting look a bit complicated, but in reality it isn't. In the HTML code of the question, for example 'opacity:0.7' means somewhat faded (on a scale of 0 to 1), 'border-radius:20px' means rounded corners, 'border:2px solid #f00' means 2 pixel thick, solid (not dotted), red border where #f00 is the red color in hexadecimal. I've also included a small script to make the answer box expand as you type long answers. This bit is more complex, again not really, but anyway you can just use it without having to know the details of how it works.

Forum Post: 
Post title: Should we record licence information with questions?
Post description: You may have noticed that every time you upload a file to Moodle, you can say what the licence is. (See the screen-grab at https://docs.moodle.org/35/en/Upload_a_file_repository if you have never noticed this.) There is a suggestion ( MDL-64085 ) that we do the same for questions in the question bank. This would be a new field on the edit question form, and would default to 'All rights reserved', like for files. We would not do anything with this information. Just include it in any Moodle XML exports. What do people think?
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: If I were looking for a new question field I would like a metafield that students never saw but gave additional information for question creators/teachers, ie. explaining the purpose and thinking behind the question. I suspect this would be of more use to more people and could be co-opted to include license information if you wanted.
Comment 2: An 'Author's comment' feature is a good idea, but something else. Having licence as a separate field, in line with Moodle's standard system of handling licences like for files, makes it searchable, and so more useful.
Comment 3: Having slept on it I was about to post something very similar to what you said Tim. I can imagine that field being seacrhable in moodle.net and I have an interest in creating questions under free licences. I was a bit focussed on my idea as it is something I have thought about putting into my own question types and I always prefer to go with the standard. Hmmm, perhaps if I do introduce that meta field in my question types it will provide feedback for the idea should it ever get towards core .
Comment 4: Perhaps you should code up a patch for core, and submit it to the tracker?
Comment 5: So much software, so little time.
Comment 6: Tim, I think your suggestion is excellent.
Comment 7: I added this to the ticket... Generally this should probably be true of all content objects. They can be exported (using the Backup function) and imported elsewhere. Having a chain of ownership would help encourage sharing, as well as answering questions about content authorship/ownership in courses with multiple editors.
Comment 8: I agree it is a good idea, for kinds of content. There is probably a lot of additional work to be done before it can be put to effective use, but one has to start somewhere. Author's comments was mentioned too. Risking going off-topic, I would like to add student's comments too. Of course, that's very different as the comments would be created when the question is used, for instance to report bugs. We implemented this in the CAPQuiz module, but it could as well be generalised.

Forum Post: 
Post title: Texas Real Estate
Post description: I was hoping some more experience moodlers could help me with this one. I am using Moodle for a real estate education site , and I am currently trying to enter the Texas market. Texas has a new rule for online quizzes. They require that multiple times during the online course (actually during the quiz themselves) , that the user is asked what there last name is. The user would be required to enter their last name and this would be checked against the last name of the user in the database (their feeble attempt at keeping other users from taking test for random people). If it does not match the user would not be allowed to continue the course. If correct then the user could proceed to the next question. Does anyone have any suggestions as to how I could achieve this feature? Using Moodle 1.6 Thanks in advance for any suggestions.
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: Hi Alvin Having never used it (or even looked at it) I think maybe using a lesson rather than a quiz might be the way to go . . . I have a distant memory of reading somewhere that you can set it up with branches (e.g. if they get the name wrong direct them to a page stating that, give them another attempt and then lock them out if still wrong, if correct, let them continue). Might be worth having a look at it to see if you could set it up to your needs.
Comment 2: (This has to be one of the most bizarre feature requesets I have ever seen!) Probably the only way to achieve this would be to make a new question type that presents them with a box to type their name into, and if they type the wrong thing, does something. I don't know what exactly. Just giving zero marks does not seem to be enough to meet the requirements. Logs them out, maybe, and changes their password to something random and unenroles them from the course? But then what if they make a typo? Whoever invented these rules did not think things through very well. It looks like the kind of regulation that is completely trvial for a dedicated cheat to avoid, but which will cause serious inconvinience to honest people.
Comment 3: I am intrigued. Do you have any more information/reference for this rule? It seems very strange indeed - I just wonder that with further details we may have a better suggestion (or spot the loop hole!).

Post title: Giving a non-standard numerical grade
Post description: Hi, I am trying to set something up where students report a self-assessed score and can track how they improve over time. Thus for example, suppose the first time a student does said activity they self report a score of 76 that becomes their first score. If they then do the activity again and self-assess a score of 86 that becomes the score for their second attempt etc. I would like a way for them to see how they did on the various attempts. I thought of doing this in a quiz using the numerical question type where a student would be asked to input a number and the score would match their input. My problem is, Moodle does not seem to accept scores that are not "standard" from the drop down menu..e.g. 86 (even when I import the question). Any suggestions? Is quiz the best way to do this? Any way around the grading limitation mentioned? Thank you. TD

Forum Post: 
Post title: Backup of question database is huge
Post description: Hi, and by huge I mean Gigabytes! We have a very large site with tens of thousands of users and thousand+ courses. Our question database contains around 2-3000 unique questions and most are at system level as they are shared. All this works fine. We use backup and restore to create a duplicate course for different schools for example. However, when we run a backup (and select the option to backup questions) things recently started to run very slowly and finally we realized the questions table in the database was enormous. What seems to happen is that all backups contain the entire database of questions and when restored these are duplicated so the number of questions effectively increases exponentially! We have a massive AWS server so have managed so far!!! However, we have recently had to use SQL to delete unused questions but this soon doubles up again. Has anybody any ideas or come across this or anything similar before? We are on the fully patched 3.5 version. Thanks Tom
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: Hi Tom, I think you should post in Quiz forum (perhaps just a link to this discussion), because it's heavily related to quiz and question bank. I think Tim Hunt could provide useful informations. Séverin
Comment 2: Thanks Severin, I guess it falls between the two areas or quiz and backup but we will see what suggestions others have.
Comment 3: I have moved this to the quiz forum. You are right, it is an issue.  I also used to use a system level quiz bank.  After fighting back up and restore timeouts, I ended up moving them all down to the course level.  The result is ironically that my bank is bigger overall but when I backup a course, it only takes those questions.
Comment 4: Thanks Emma, it sounds like this is a request for the developers, but it is good to know it is not me doing something strange!!! - i will see if any other suggestions appear.
Comment 5: Why don't you deselect the quiz either in the backup or in the restore process?
Comment 6: Because that of course solves the problem of a large backup, but, then the quizzes are not recreated in the new course. The backup seems to need to backup the entire database and the add to it each time.

Post title: questions in one quiz with different points - How to
Post description: Salam Alykom, The default is that all questions in a quiz have the same weight. How can different points be given to different questions in a quiz? Thanks
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: 1. Select the Quiz Activity. 2. Select the Edit Quiz icon. 3. Where the pencil (edit) icon is displayed, far right side. Select the pencil to edit the points value. 4. Adjust the Maximum grade to all questions point values. 5. Save
Comment 2: Thanks Shirley

Post description: The content of this forum post has been removed and can no longer be accessed.
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: The content of this forum post has been removed and can no longer be accessed.
Comment 2: It is so much easier for me if you can create a diff: http://docs.moodle.org/en/CVS_%28developer%29#Basic_CVS_commands Then I can instantly apply all the changes to my version and see them in context . If you are using some frontend to CVS , e.g. TortoiseCVS or Eclipse, then it is likely to be even easier to create the diff. Here is the diff for this change (assuming I followed your instructions above OK): 
```text
Index: lang/en_utf8/quiz.php


===================================================================


RCS file: /cvsroot/moodle/moodle/lang/en_utf8/quiz.php,v


retrieving revision 1.30


diff -u -r1.30 quiz.php
```

Post title: Quiz Accessibility issues
Post description: I'm in Moodle 3.5.2. When will the accessibility issues be addressed? A couple of things I noticed. When tabbing through to get to a question, the answer is highlighted first. Only when you press the up arrow key can you go back and read the question. This seems incorrect to me. Secondly, When you answer a question with keyboard input only, you can't tab out into the next question. It forces you to the top of the page (am I doing something wrong within the JAWS screen reader?). Where can I address these questions to the maintainers or Moodle?
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: You are addressing this to the maintainers of Moodle. Can I ask, what is your role? Are you someone who regularly uses Jaws to access the web, or are you a non-expert user of Jaws, for example a software developer or tester, who is trying to understand how well Moodle works? If that latter, you need to realise that Jaws is a powerful bit of software that you probably don't know how to use well, and so it is easy to have it in the wrong mode for effectively accessing a particular page, or something like that. Unfortunately, the other thing to realise is that, things change with time, so even if things worked nicely a few years ago (which they did, we got some expert testing done) the web browser, and Jaws, change and there is no guarantee that things still work well, so more testing is welcome. Anyway, your first issue probably comes from having Jaws in the wrong mode. A page of a quiz is not really a form. It is more like a page of content. The second issue: well it certainly used to work properly in the past. If you answered one question, then when the page re-loaded, focus would be on the question you just changed.
Comment 2: I am a web developer testing the accessibility of the quiz through JAWS because we had a client say that it didn't seem very accessible when a blind student went in and took the quiz. I am not a JAWS expert by any means, I learned the basic keyboard interaction and went in a little deeper with the program yesterday. My issue was with the expectation of tabbing through the quiz and hazing the question to the quiz be in focus first, but instead the answers are in focus first. Granted, I can use the up arrow keys to get the question after tabbing to the answer, but is that confusing for a blind person? Do they tab through or arrow through a page more frequently? There must be some place I can learn more about how a user uses JAWs. I would think there would be a tab index attribute set to zero on the labels (quiz questions) so you could tab to the question, tab to the answer, arrow key up and down the radio/checkboxes then tab out to the second question. If this isn't how it's supposed to function then I guess I need to learn more about JAWS.
Comment 3: I just checked the documentation that the Open University gives to disabled students attempting quizzes, and we don't have any guidance at that level. All the advice we give as at the level of how specific question types work. And, I know we have screen-reader users attempting our quiz, because we got a bug report from a student doing a language course, saying that in the drag-drop questions, the French words in the drag items were being read with an English accent because of missing <span lang="fr"> tags. University of Minnesota gives similar advice: https://accessibility.umn.edu/moodle/moodle-tools-activities (but they are wrong about drag-drop questions. There is a way to attempt them with just the keyboard.)

Post title: This forum post has been removed
Post description: The content of this forum post has been removed and can no longer be accessed.
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: It's because some teachers have published their question categories. This problem results from misunderstanding of what it means to publish a category. Some people seem to think publishing a category means making it available for quizzes in their own course. In fact, it means publishing a category all over the site for all the teachers to see and to use. We've had this problem on our site, too - several of our teachers inadvertently published their categories which resulted in some confusion (just in your case). If you are an admin of your site, you can easily track down those "public" categories in the database - search the mdl_quiz_categories table for any records with publish set to 1 . You will then see which courses they come from and you will be able to contact the teachers of those courses and ask if they really wanted to share their questions with all the other teachers on the site. Hope this helps, Przemek
Comment 2: The content of this forum post has been removed and can no longer be accessed.
Comment 3: >Some people seem to think publishing a category means making it
available for quizzes in their own course. In fact, it means publishing
a category all over the site for all the teachers to see and to use. One option I would very much like to see in Moodle is for a teacher to be able to "publish" question categories in order to share them within all of their own courses , not a whole Moodle site. This makes sense a) when you teach a number of related courses where you would like to avoid replication of questions and b) when you work in a large institution where "publishing" categories for the whole institution site might mean hundreds of items among which it woud be hard to find your own categories, especially if each teacher uses their own naming system for categories. Joseph
Comment 4: I work with two different versions of moodle and I have observed a difference in behavior with respect to published categories, as explained below. As expected, both versions allow me to see categories published by other teachers.  The difference in behavior has to do with MY ability to export (or not export) other teachers' categories. When I attempt to export other teachers' categories in version 1.5.2.0, moodle says "Only the teacher can export quiz questions."  I like that behavior because it prevents me from copying someone else's work, unbeknownst to them.
Comment 5: Sounds like this may be a bug. Howard.... have you changed the export settings?
Comment 6: Hi Ray, Assuming this is a bug, how do I find out if it has has already been reported?  If it has not been reported, how do I report it?   I know, the answer to both questions is "the bug tracker," but the bug tracker is sufficiently mysterious to me that I need a more detailed answer! Thanks
Comment 7: How to see if the bug is already reported: Go to http://moodle.org/bugs/ and log in. (I can't remember if it is the same logins as moodle.org or not. You may have to create a new account.) Click on Query Issues from the link on the left. Click advanced query page at the top. Type an appropriate keyword into the Title of bug box. Click Submit query, then scan down the list of bugs. Repeat 4-5 for some other plausible keywords. If you can't find the issue already reported, then you need to file the new bug. You do that by starting with the Add a new Issue link from the menu on the left. The bug is much more likely to get fixed in you write a good bug report. The mozilla project has some excellent guidelines for writing good bug reports: https://bugzilla.mozilla.org/page.cgi?id=bug-writing.html Obviously a few bits of this are not relevant, but most of it is. The key points are: Make it very clear to me what I need to do to reproduce the bug on my server . If I can't reproduce it, I can't fix it. The kind of detailed steps I gave at the start of this message for searching is the level of detail I would expect. Say exactly what you saw that is wrong. Copy and paste any error message. Screenshots are also good. Say what you think should have happened instead. That is, explain why you think what you saw is wrong. Write a summary which is short, but which says exactly what the problem is. (This is hard, do your best.) File this sort of bug under either Questions or Quiz component. Try to guess which of the two is more appropriate, but it is not that important. They all come to me. I think this is a good example of a bug report: http://moodle.org/bugs/bug.php?op=show&bugid=5688
Comment 8: Thank you for your excellent guidance!  I have entered bug 5978.

Forum Post: 
Post title: Save Answer/Response button during exam?
Post description: Hi all! I am wondering if there is a way/or has been a way for students to 'save answer' as they go in a Moodle Quiz. Having a feature that would allow the students to 'save answer' next to each question was something I noticed Brightspace having that eased a lot of anxiety. I understand that the autosave default is 2 minutes (which we have it set to) or that by students clicking over to a new question page (when Layout is set to "new page: every question") this saves their work on the previous page, but if some faculty opt to have more than 1 question on a page or use Long essay style questions - these are both scenarios where students will be on one quiz page for a longer period time. Even having a 'save as you go' button option on the page (and not necessarily next to each question) would be a nice add. We certainly provide 'best practices' to safeguard against this but from a usability standpoint if Moodle Quiz has options for long essay questions or more than one question on a page, I am wondering why not have a 'save question' option' next to each question or on the page to mitigate potential disaster in the event of a connection issue. Would love some additional suggestions or if there is some other settings or features that might address this. Thanks! Marybeth
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: Which Moodle version? latest Moodle version reassure students by showing the time the answers were last auto-saved. And, you can always set the time to faster than 2 minutes. (Open University currently has it set to 30 seconds - of course, if you are going to change it, monitor server load before and after.)

Comment 1: see the documentation It makes sense because when you use interactive behaviour the number of attempts is given by the number of hints in the question.
Comment 2: Yes, I know, and I know also that the adaptive mode with or without penalties allows to a student to have several tries for a question so that's why I asked myself this question, in addition to that this parameter does not take into account the penalties.

information, however I created a test with immediate feedback behavior and I allowed to make two attempts and ofcourse I activated the "Allow redo within an attempt"  and I added a simple calculated question, Then, I tested the test as a student, In the second attempt, I answred false then I answered right but at the end I got the full grade . Comment 5: I think that there is a  difference among adaptive mode without penalties and Interactive mode  with "Allow redo within an attempt" , it  is that  the variable values change  when you make another try, but not in adaptive mode. there values are always the same.
Comment 6: As several people have said now, this option is only useful if you have either build the quiz using random questions ( https://docs.moodle.org/34/en/Building_Quiz#Adding_a_random_question ), or are using a question type with internal randomisation (like Calculated, Formulas, STACK , ...) It is intended to be used in quizzes that have been provided to let students practise their skills. Forum Post: 
Post title: Not Applicable - Multiple choice answer
Post description: We have entered questions on our quiz . However, within the list of answer choices to choose from, we have a choice out there of "Not Applicable". How do we throw that question out of the grading if they choose this answer for the question. We don't want that question to count "against them" or "for them" when the system calculated the total score for that quiz. We want the system to not count that question in the total quiz if they answer "Not Applicable" to the question. It throws our data off when we are doing analysis on it. Thanks, Will
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: Anyone with this problem? Anyone know how to resolve this issue? -Will
Comment 2: Hi William, One reason why your query did not get answers so far is that it is hard to understand why you would want this behavior. If "not applicable" is a correct answer, then it should count as such, no? Or, to put it another way, if your wish was possible, then if the people taking your quiz see a MCQ question with one of the choices labeled "not applicable" they would simply skip it, in order to not be penalize for a wrong answer. I'm finding it hard to imagine exactly why you would want that "not applicable" option anyway. Could you provide a real-world example, please? Joseph
Comment 3: We have a client that wishes to do something like a "graded" survey. It is for child development. All of the people taking these quizzes own or are affiliated with a child care business. If we ask a question such as "How often do you allow a child to prepare breakfast?" Some businesses will not serve children a meal such as breakfast. They expect the children to have eaten before they get there. They will serve them lunch however. This would result in a "Not Applicable" answer because they don't do it. They shouldn't be docked for doing that however. We are using Moodle 1.6.1. When we looked at the Survey module, it was all canned surveys. It wouldn't allow us to create our own. Plus, We couldn't get a certificate of completion as well with it. -Will
Comment 4: Hi William, I am not sure I understand what a "graded survey" is. You either need a survey (and in that case I would recommend installing either the Feedback or the Questionnaire 3rd party moodle plugins ) or a Quiz , but you won't get an N/A option to work in a MCQ questions quiz the way you want. Joseph

Forum Post: 
Post title: Allow some students to review their quiz responses  but not others
Post description: Moodle 3 Hi all, Is it possible to allow only certain students to review their quiz responses and not others?  I wish to allow those students that have failed the quiz the opportunity to review their quiz, but not those students who have passed.  I presume that restrictions set  on the quiz settings page refers to restrictions imposed on  undertaking the quiz but not to review.
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: Suppose your quiz is called 'Quiz A'. In the quiz settings: Common module settings --> ID number: 'quizA'. In the gradebook setup: Add a grade item named 'Quiz A w/o review' with calculation =[ [quizA] ] (no space between brackets) . In the quiz settings: Timing --> Close the quiz: closing time ☑ Enable. Review options --> During the attempt: ☑ Enable all or some Immediately after the attempt: ☐ Uncheck all Later, while the quiz is still open: ☐ Uncheck all After the quiz is closed: ☑ Enable all or some Restrict access --> Access restrictions: Student [must] match [any] of the following Grade: Quiz A w/o review ☑ must be < pass/fail grade or Student [must not] match the following Grade: Quiz A w/o review ☐ must be ≥ leave blank ☐ must be < leave blank Results Until the closing time of the quiz, no student can review his quiz. After the closing time of the quiz, students whose mark is lower than the pass/fail grade can review their quiz and students whose mark is higher than the pass/fail mark can not access their quiz for review. Note In the gradebook, set the weight of 'Quiz A' to zero and set the weight of 'Quiz A w/o review' to the desired value.
Comment 2: Thank you Dominique ... interesting way to achieve this.  I had worked out that the post quiz review options were capable of being selectively applied but I was  manually adding each student.  Your method seems much neater.
