Post title: Importing categories from one class to another
Post description: I was wondering if there's a way to import question categories (not quizzes) from one course to another? What I would like to do is simply copy the test bank questions I've loaded into one course and put into categories and transfer those to another course. It seems that Moodle will only allow me to copy quizzes from one course to another, which won't work if instructors decide to cover some different chapters, or combine chapters etc.
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: Don't copy your questions. Share them! Moodle 1.9 introduced the notion of question context , allowing questions to be shared at the course category and system level. Sharing is controlled by permissions. So, for example, one group of users might be able to create questions in the math course category, while other users can only use those questions in quizzes, and still others don't see the questions at all. Read the question context documenation here .
Comment 2: I've got to weigh in on this one, John, if you don't mind. I've been part of a group of teachers that has been piloting Moodle over the last half of this year for a district wide launch in the fall. I teach six sections of math, so as you can imagine, I have lot's of reusable questions. As I imported and exported questions to move them from one classfile to another, my questions kept doubling themselves, so that a question category that had 20 questions in it, soon had over 100. The system admins had done all their previous development in 1.8, so when I went looking for a solution to my question duplicating problem, I found the question context feature that John describes, that they hadn't known was added. This is a brilliant feature!! Now, all six of my courses are in a course category called "Mr. Lavery," and I use that category for all my questions now. This allows me to create quizzes in any class using those questions. As an added bonus, I can modify the questions in one centralized location and see those changes reflected throughout all my courses. The one wrinkle we ran into, though, is that of roles. You must have the role of "teacher" in whatever context you are trying to use to be able to create question categories . This took us a couple of tries to find. Hope that helps,
Comment 3: You must have the role of "teacher" in whatever context you are trying to use to be able to create question categories. Matt, You don't need the Teacher role in a category context to be able to create questions there. You only need a few question-related permissions. For example, you need moodle/question:add ("Add questions") = Allow in that context to allow you to add questions. By assigning the Teacher role in the Lavery context, you get these permissions, but you get over a hundred other permissions that you don't want or need. Also, you become a Teacher in every course in the category. It's a moot point with a category like Lavery, since all the courses in the category are Matt's anyway. But if the category was say Math Dept, then assigning Matt the Teacher role there would have all sorts of unwanted side-effects (like making Matt a Teacher in all math department courses). So you want to create a new simple role with only the question-related permissions allowed and all others Not set, and assign this role to Matt in the Lavery context. Better still, design a collection of simple roles containing different sets of permissions. Role for question creators, a role for question Quality assurance, a role for question users, etc. Now suppose Matt has been assigned the Question creator role in the Lavery context. If Matt is inside one of his six math courses, where he has been assigned the role of Teacher, the category dropdown menu in the Question bank will have a Category: Lavery heading (the context), and under that all of question categories (algebra, geometry, etc.). Matt will be able to add questions to the category. This ability comes from Question creator role assigned above, not from Teacher.

Post title: Adding Grading Workflow to Quizzes, is that possible?
Post description: Hello there... We grade about 1 million students each year. Our process includes 2 stages, a grading and reviewing stage.  We're about to adopt Moodle and we love the grading workflow, but that's only available for the assignment activity.  In our quiz activities in Moodle, we have open-ended questions that needs the same grading workflow, but we can't seem to find a way to activate such functionality for the quiz. Architecturally speaking, would it be possible for us to create a custom quiz module that uses the existing grading workflow without breaking all sorts of things? is this something Moodle could do? Is this something Moodle could do real soon if we pay for the development effort?
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: 2) Moodle does not currently support this. 3) Moodle is open soruce, and there are partner companies who offer commercial development services ( https://moodle.com/solutions/certified-service-providers/ ) so in principle yes. 1) If I had to do this, I would try to avoid duplicating the quiz module. That would be a huge amount of work, not just to do, but also to keep maintaining. Instead, I would look to see if it is possible to do it with a custom quiz report plugin (which creates additional database tables to store the extra tracking information that you want about each quiz attempt, and which provides the customised grading UI). The details would need to be worked out by whoever implemented this, based on exactly what you need.

Forum Post: 
Post title: What I plan to do to attempt.php
Post description: I am about to do a major refactor of mod/quiz/attempt.php, and before I started, I thought I would post here to make sure I had my plans clear in my head, and to give all of you a chance to stop me if I have overlooked something vital. Why I think there is a problem It all started because I wanted to fix MDL-6368 and MDL-6369 (let question types easily include some CSS and JavaScript ). This caused me to take a long hard look at mod/quiz/attempt.php, and I realised it was a big complicated mess. This makes it difficult to maintain, which leads to bugs. Probably the underlying cause of this mess is that the one file does at least four different things: It checks all the conditions about whether the student can do the quiz (quiz open and close times, delays between attempts, number of attempts allowed, password, IP address, ...) It starts a new attempt, if necessary. It process any data that came from the previous page (if moving between pages of a multi-page quiz, or clicking one of the save/submit buttons). It displays (a page of) the quiz, for the student to enter their answers into. Also, because of 2. and 3. a lot of the time, when you are looking at the quiz attempt page, you are looking at the results of a HTTP POST request, which means that clicking the reload or back button in your browser does weird things. What I am going to do I'm going to split attempt.php into three bits: attempt.php?attemptid=X&page=Y This will just to part 4 above. It will display a single page of the quiz ready for the student to enter their answers. In can only be used to display an attempt, once that attempt has been started. The only checking it will do is to ensure that this attempt belongs to the current user, is still open, that we have not passed the close date, and the time limit has not expired. Instead of checking all the other conditions, we will store in the user's $SESSION a list of attempt ids that have been fully checked. It the student tries to go directly to attempt.php for an attempt that they started in a previous session, it will redirect them to startattempt.php. processattempt.php When you submit the form on attempt.php, it will POST the data to this page. This page just does step 3. above, that is process the responses. Once it has done the processing, it redirects the student pack to attempt.php (or review.php if they did submit all and finish).

Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: Export, exports the *entire* selected category. No export format actually records the category name in the ouput. Import, imports the new questions into the selected category - adding to the questions already there. The bit of code you are looking at is to do with published categories. It ensures that you can only add questions to published categories that you really do have write access to (ie, you are a teacher with write access in that categories 'home' course). Does this help?
Comment 2: Yes, it helped. Now, I know I didn't make the difference between backup/restore and import/export. Thx Nico

Forum Post: 
Post title: Quizzes being linked?
Post description: Hello, I am having a weird issue that pops up occasionally (and then stops being a problem for 6 months to a year)...I'm hoping someone has an idea because I'm pulling all my hair out! In my Word course, we have two tests (set up as "quizzes" in Moodle). They are completely different and both are set up from scratch.  Normally they run fine but occasionally when the course is rebooted for new students those two quizzes become "linked". So if I edit one, it makes all of the same changes in the other quiz. So both tests wind up being the mid-term exam (if that was the last edited) or the final exam (if that's the last one I changed). I wind up setting up the mid-term from scratch before they write that, then doing the same thing with the final exam sometime after the mid-term is completed! I have not had this issue with ANY other course. I have also completely deleted them and the issue is still there. Any ideas???  I'm desperate!!! (Oh, and I think we use Moodle 3.1.1)
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: Hi Nicole, I am a Moodle user like you. I had this kind of problem until I understood the following: quizzes and questions are distinct entities. Quizzes are shells in which questions are placed. Here is how a problem can occur: You make Quizz01 that includes question A. Then you make a copy, Quizz02, and edit it. Heck! Everything is mixed up! Here is what happens: Quizz01 contains question A. When you copy Quizz01, you get: Quizz02 which also contains question A. When you edit Quizz02, you are actually editing question A and simultaneously Quizz01 because both Quizz01 and Quizz02 contain the same question A! Remember that when copying a quiz, questions are not copied. Only the references to the 'same' questions are copied. What you should do: Label your questions clearly, e.g. 'Question 1 of Mid-term', 'Question 1 of Final', etc. Check that your quizzes contain the right questions. Be careful when copying quizzes, because you also need to make new questions either from scratch or by copying existing questions.

What else could explain the fact that my manual regrade adds points and then when I press regrade the not-crossed-out score is the lower one? Thanks, Sarra
Comment 3: What do you mean when you say 'manual regrade'?
Comment 4: Tim - I meant that I manually change their grades on questions (I do this because I want to grade their multiple choice (all that apply) to give them a point for every choice they check if it is correct and a point for every choice they don't check if it is, in fact, incorrect. Moodle has no such option, so I go through and re-grade them all manually.
Comment 5: When you press regrade, you are telling the quiz to regrade the attempt, thus overriding your manual changes.
Comment 6: argh. that's what I was afraid of. Thanks Emma. So...just to check if I understand... ...if I manually changed grades, moodle automatically updates those changes (without my pressing anything), and then when I click "regrade" moodle reverts to the pre-manual-changes grade? The crossed out grade is the one with my manual changes and the non-crossed-out grade is moodle's post regrade, undoing all my manual changes? Is this correct?
Comment 7: Emma is incorrect. A re-grade does not wipe out any manual grading. (This is easy to verify in a test course: Attempt the quiz using a test student account, Manually edit the grade, then regrade, and review - look at the history table.) Not that, in Moodle vocabulary, manually editing one students mark on one question is not a regrade. The crossings-out in the quiz grades report only show changes caused by a regrade. They do not show changes from manual grading.
Comment 8: As I have been following this conversation, I am not sure that we are talking about the same thing.  I did a little experimenting, and I recommend that you too experiment. I have always used the "Regrade" feature when I have determined that I had a wrong answer in one of my questions, and students have already taken this quiz with the wrong answer.  My method is to fix the question's answer, then do a "Dry run a full regrade".  What moodle shows is those quiz attempts that will be changed when I do a "Regrade all."  These changes are shown with crossed out numbers for the "Grade."  At this point, I can pick those quiz attempts that I want change grades.  Usually, if the student's grade will improve, I check these.  If the student's grade will go down, I leave these along because I don't want to penalize those students who had my wrong, correct answer (this is my method, but others might not want to do this.)  Then I "Regrade All". However, if I manually go into a quiz attempt, and for whatever reason manually adjust the points for any one question, this does not show up (in my moodle) with a cross-out.  Nor does regrading over-ride what I had just manually changed. So this leaves me wondering exactly what you are doing, Sarra?  I encourage that you experiment a little to make sure that you know exactly what your moodle is doing.  (I think this is why Tim asked for clarification.)
Comment 9: Thanks Rick for clarifying our confusion!!  I was thinking that nothing had been saved to the final quiz grade and so the regrade was allowing the quiz to update the grades. Perhaps you could share some screenshots?

Forum Post: 
Post title: Integrating Zoomify images into quiz module
Post description: Hi there, I've been using the zoomify tools to display high resolution images online in some online tests I manage. I've hacked this into the quiz module and thought I would throw it out there in case others could make use of it. Zoomify ( http://zoomify.com ) takes a large, high resolution image and creates a bunch of smaller, lower resolution tiles which are then loaded by the Flash movie as the user zooms in. This means that the individual files loaded are small but the resolution of what can be seen is high. This is great for detailed images that you want a student to be able to view but which would be way too large if you loaded up the full size jpg as one file. I've added some code to the /mod/quiz/locallib.php quiz_print_possible_question_image() function that looks to see if a zoomify file is available and if so, it loads the flash code into the page, if not, it displays the image as normal. I have not extensively tested it and have only tried it using the multiple choice question type so I have no idea what it might look like in other question types but it should be fine. I've attached the source code to this post. Simply replace the existing quiz_print_possible_question_image() function in /mod/quiz/locallib.php to give it a try. You will need to download zoomify, convert an image (works well converting .tif, not sure about other file types), zip up the directory that zoomify creates, upload this to your course, unzip it, create a low resolution .jpg to go along with it, upload that file to the same parent directory as the zip archive (and the new unzipped folder) and add the low resolution jpg to the question as a figure. The zoomify.swf needs to be uploaded to /mod/quiz also. In theory, now when the quiz module looks to display the figure for the question it will find the filename of the low res figure in the database , then check to see if a high res zoomify version is available and if so, it should display it.
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: Hi simon: It looks great!, but a have questions: 1. It's free zoomify? 2. Why is necessary Moock.org?
Comment 2: Hi Miguel, Zoomify has a free version (Zoomify EZ) which works very well if you want to take images and individually put them online on a webpage using zoomify as a stand alone flash component. If you want to integrate zoomify with your own flash movies or do more complex server-side integration or have a lot of images to convert then that is when their commercial products come into play. I have only used the EZ version. The moock.org scripts are needed to implement flash plugin detection so that your page can cope if the user doesnt have a flash plug in or has an early version that doesnt handle the zoomify viewer. With plugin detection it will display a message and the lower resolution jpg image rather than having an blank spot on the page with a broken plug-in icon, or similar. This isnt necessary but it is a good way to gracefully cope with the different browser capabilities of your users. Simon.
Comment 3: Thanks Simon: I will try it!.  Very good hack!

Forum Post: 
Post title: any other examples for embedded answers (cloze) ?
Post description: In the embedded answers - moodle gives one format of using it. I need a different one, maybe someone has. For example, I have a text, and I need the students to fill in the write answer: I (to walk) ___________ down and street and (to see)__________ my friend Joel coming towards me. I was happy to see him and he (to be) ______ happy to see me. So the student has to put the write form into the empty places. Does anyone has the write format for it? Galia
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: Try this: I (to walk) {1:SHORTANSWER:=walked} down and street and (to see) {1:SHORTANSWER:=saw} my friend Joel
coming towards me. I was happy to see him and he (to be) {1:SHORTANSWER:=was} happy
to see me. There are other clever things you can do with feedback for incorrect answers, and multiple correct answers; have a glance in the online help for further examples.
Comment 2: Great! I'll try it. Thanks!

Post title: Can teachers and editingteachers attempt quiz'?
Post description: Hello, I'm relatively new in moodle and while setting up a course I found difficulties I cannot seem to solve while testing through at the moment. I was now testing all possibilities I can think of with permissions, rights, completion settings and so on. Am I right that there is no possibility a teacher-role account can attempt quiz' and get it shown as completed (if done so) in the progress completion bar or in the progress window of the (editing)teacher/manager? As a teacher I can see the quiz and attempt it as in answering the questions and get a screen that shows the percentage achieved, time needed and so on. Thanks in advance for answers and this forum in general, it really helped me in getting into the platform and understanding a little more each day! Dominic

Post title: Playing MP3 within a quiz
Post description: I have built a spelling quiz for our 8th grade social studies teacher.  The quiz plays my voice saying the state that they are to type in as the answer.  When I record my voice in mp3 and click on it it plays back just find, but when my students click on it, it just sits there.  I have loaded the lame_enc.dll on each computer to no avail.  Any ideas, anyone?
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: I think we had a similar problem like this once.  I seem to recall that the mp3 files were loaded and linked to a place that teachers had access rights to, but students did not.  What version of moodle are you using?  Are your sound files uploaded in the site files or course files area?
Comment 2: Great answer Don.  We also had Firefox not play files due to a security issue, but IE would play the files.  We solved our problem by storing all of the files in the course files or Moodle site files area instead of elsewhere on the network.
Comment 3: Thank you for your quick reply.  We are on 1.5.2 .  All my sound fines are course-specific so they are accessable to students.  This morning I am at our second Moodle site and attempt to replicate the errors that I experienced at my first site.  When I logged in as myself, admin, everything on the sounds worked properly.  Next I logged in at a 'test student' and suprisingly, everything works.  So now it looks as if I am missing something to do with my sound drivers on each of the lab computers.   I know that this summer our techs went through each computer but I don't know what they actually did.  Now is the time to findout.  So my next stop will be with out techs.  Thank you all for your help. Bill Click
Comment 4: Bill, Do you play those MP3 sound files 1) using the Flash MP3 sound player incorporated into Moodle, or 2) do you just put a link to the MP3 files which opens the brower's default audio player? If #1, have you enabled the multimedia filter in Admin/Configuration/Filters ? Joseph

Post description: Hi there, for a quiz (in Moodle 4.0) we want to present the solutions of the questions after a number of test attempts. So somebody can attempt the quiz. Forum Post: 
Post title: Awarding Grades to the best X answers from Y Questions
Post description: Hello, I have a question regarding the grading of a Quiz where marks are awarded to the best 3 answers only, from 5 Questions available. All equal marks. Can this be done within the Quiz Activity itself (in 3.9)? For example, if each question is worth 10 marks, then the max grade for the quiz is 30. If a student scores 10, 5, 3, 7, 10 then their total grade for the quiz should be 27/30. It would be preferable if there was a solution within core moodle, but I am interested in plugins, if anyone knows any? Many thanks, Michael
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: I just came across a possible solution to this problem. You can download the quiz responses from the Quiz administration > Results > Responses page as a CSV or Excel file, then use the formula SUMPRODUCT (LARGE( question grades array , {1, 2, 3, ... X})) to get the sum of the best X answers. The YouTube video Sum the Top 5 Values - Excel Formula explains how to use it. Then create an Assignment activity with no file upload requirement as a place to return the computed 'best of' grades to students, Download a grading worksheet from this assignment, and use the Excel function VLOOKUP (or better yet XLOOKUP) to map the computed grades from the from the Quiz results into the assignment grading worksheet, and import them back into Moodle.
Comment 2: Hello Michael, A plugin would be nice, but I don't think there is one. This could possibly be done with the Quiz Subscores workaround method ↗ . It's a bit complicated to set up but it works. You will need to modify the formula in the gradebook to extract the top three questions.

Forum Post: 
Post title: Moodle2word-template
Post description: how can we use this plugin for a customize question type? Is there any provision to do changes in the word template.
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: The Moodle2Word template (which I maintain) is fairly easy to update to add a new question type, although it requires a small bit of VBA code to be added for each new type. The custom question type you are targeting will also probably need two small methods to be added to support import and export to Word format, see the All-or-Nothing Multiple Choice Question code for an example. However, the main effort in supporting a new question type is mapping the HTML table elements generated from Word into the corresponding Moodle Question XML elements used in the custom question type in the plugin Microsoft Word File Import/Export (Question Format) . This requires XSLT (rather than PHP) programming knowledge. You can easily see the required XML by exporting a question from Moodle into XML , but then you have to define a Word table structure that incorporates all of the components. If the custom question type is similar to an existing supported type, it is quite easy. But if it isn't then there is much more work involved.

Forum Post: 
Post title: Quiz report log ip addresses
Post description: If the wrong forum, please point me in the right direction... Two students take a quiz, suspicious because same questions correct/incorrect.  Look at the ip addresses and they are exactly the same. My question - does the ip address being exactly the same confirm that the same computer was used for taking the test? Or are there set ups that would present the same ip address? I couldn't find, in the forum, exactly how this ip address in the report is obtained. thank you
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: That totally depends on where they are accessing the site from.  It is quite possible for two different computers to use the same ip address.  If they are not on the same network as the Moodle site and are accessing over the Internet but from the same location, chances are that the ip address will be the same.  If they are on the same network as the Moodle and accessing the moodle site internally, then the ip address would most likely be different. However, just because they are on the same computer, does not mean that there was any cheating.  One student would have to log out for the other one to log in. When you are setting up the quiz, you can randomize question and answer order which would stop students sitting next to each other to be able to copy.  However, students are pretty ingenious and could easily be taking screenshots and texting each other pictures of the questions or they could just have taken the quiz together at the same time with no supervision.
Comment 2: Thanks for the reply. My example was if both used the same computer say in the lab or if one borrowed the others to take the quiz or if they shared and apartment or dorm room, etc.  The individuals insist that they were in two different towns, and that each page of the quiz submitted within two minutes of each other was - A submits page 1, within two minutes B submits page 1, etc., was coincidental.  The only way I can think of that occurring with the same computer is using two browsers. I reminded the faculty that if shuffle had been in place it could be a deterrent but that nothing is fool proof and perhaps 'virtual' proctoring should be considered in the future. Again, thanks for the quick response.
Comment 3: If they claim to have taken the quiz from two different towns and the logs show them having the same ip address and it is not a local ip address (ie: they used a vpn to access the network and then logged in), then they are lying plain and simple.

Post title: Re-trying incorrect answers in embedded cloze quiz questions
Post description: I would like to know if there is a way for students to re-try incorrect answers in an embedded cloze quiz questions.  I will briefly explain the situation. 1)  Currently, I have the quiz set so that students can attempt the quiz twice.  The quiz has multiple questions. Each question contains a text with gaps (6-10 items) for students to fill in . 2) After the students submit the quiz, they are returned feedback which present the items they got correct or incorrect for each item. 3)  When the students retry the quiz, the students must re-enter all of their answers, even for the items they got correct. My specific question is: how can I change the Moodle settings so that when a student retries a quiz, they only have to correct their mistakes within each question, instead of having them redo the entire question? Thank you!
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: A couple of options: A) use a different setting for How questions behave. Either 'Interactive with multiple tries' (Add some hints to your question first) or 'Adaptive'. B) Use the quiz option 'Each attempt builds on last' (hidden behind Show more...)
Comment 2: Thank you!  Your guidance worked perfectly.
Comment 3: I'm trying to work this out too but more importantly I am trying to work it so that as an assessor I don't have to re-mark the same questions multiple times. Drives me bananas.

Forum Post: 
Post title: Roadmap for future question type INDIVIDUAL
Post description: Today we have the question type RANDOM, with which we can accomplish individual quizes. Especially for numerical questions it could be neat to have another framework for attaching individual parameters of files to questions that use the same question text. This is a feature that my collegue statistics teachers have asked for and together we have come up with a possible model for the solution. As we are dealing with statistics, it comes natural to have individual stuff as individual measurement data on file. Each student gets its own file and then analyzes it according to the question text. For educational reasons it could be a good idea to have the student use the very same data file for a number of questions and quizes. In statistics this gives us the possibility to show the students how the use of different statistical tools end up with different results. We have come up with a specification that contains these key points: As data is to be reused between questions, it should be stored at category level (or simular). When an individual question is created, the individual items are chosen from the individual items that the category offers. The first time a student takes an individual question from the category, he/she will be assigned an individual dataset from that category. Whenever the student later takes another individual question from that category, he/she will reuse the same dataset that was used the first time. An individual dataset will contain a limited number of named items. The names and types of the items are defined by the teacher at category level. Example: The category "Some Category" can have four item definitions for its datasets: "number" as parameter; "bloodpressures" as file; "time for recovery" as file; "age group" as parameter. I intend to have the parameter number as an automatic default, having number=1 for the first dataset, 2 for the second etc. For each dataset the teacher then needs to upload a file 'bloodpressures' and a file 'time for recovery' and set the parameter 'age group'. If the student later gets the dataset item 'age group' for a question, the student will also be bound to always get the items 'bloodpressures', 'time for recovery' and 'number' from this dataset if he/she later have an individual question that uses any of these. My plan is to start by constructing a page for editing datasets (datasets.php). It will be reached from the "Editing quiz" page as shown in the attached example. It will store dataset definitions and datasets in these tables: CREATE TABLE `prefix_quiz_dataset_definitions` ( `id` int(10) unsigned NOT NULL auto_increment, `category` int(10) unsigned NOT NULL default '0', `name` varchar(255) NOT NULL default '', `type` smallint(6) NOT NULL default '0', PRIMARY KEY  (`id`), KEY `category` (`category`) ) TYPE=MyISAM COMMENT='Options for multianswer questions' CREATE TABLE `prefix_quiz_dataset_items` ( `id` int(10) unsigned NOT NULL auto_increment, I continue by creating the quesiton type INDIVIDUAL. When editing the question the teacher provide a question text and also pick the relevant dataset items by names. It is thereafter necessary to define the actual question type and the answers for each one of the datasets in the category. It would be useful to use some kind of file import to define these answers. I cannot offer any format for this but I hope others can come with ideas here. When the questions have got their answers they will be ready to use in quizes. I will go ahead with this now. If you wish I can have things checked in as I proceed or have a huge bunch of code submitted when all is done.

Forum Post: 
Post title: restoring an attempt sended by mistake
Post description: A student mistakenly submits his attempt when he has answered a few questions. He would have had a long time to complete the quiz. What is the best action a teacher can take to allow that student to reopen his attempt and complete the quiz? Thanks a lot, Luigi
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: I would do a quiz, user override, and give this student a second attempt. Be careful, depending on how you set up the quiz, the student might see which questions on the first attempt they answered correctly. When giving the student a second attempt, you can decide if you want the highest grade, or average grade to be the student's final grade. You can also delete the first attempt, which then gives this student a new try. Or you can tell the student that the questions answered on the first attempt will be carried forward into the second attempt.  You would have to do this manually. Or, you could tell the student "That's it!  Be more careful on the next quiz."

(2) determine if a given string like  x="ab" is in a list like ["0a","1a","ab","b1"] and (3) where in a string like "0a1aabb1"  the string "ab" is located? Forum Post: Post title: How do I do this within Quiz? Post description: I want to have a poem and then have four questions about the poem.  I still would like to sort everything.  Is there a way to lock a description with the questions that go with it?  Maybe quiz isn't what i really need, I just don't have a handle on this kind of thing yet.  Appreciate any and all help. BTW , I want to have several of these poems and then questions for each. bill Comments associated with the post: Comment 1: Bill... Need a bit more information, such as, What kind of questions about the poem?  T/F, matching, fill-in-the-blank, multiple choice, essay, etc.  Are the poems lengthy, medium, short?  Also, do you want the poem to appear with the questions beneath it or can you "launch" the poem in its own window so the student can have it open while he or she answers the questions associated with it?  That kind of information would be helpful in answering your question (at least, it would be helpful for me)... madea madea@mmsi.com Comment 2: Thank you madea & Timpthy for your help.  madea, your mention of "launch" got me to  thinking a little differently.  And than you Timothy for your response.  I think that I understand things a little better and am ready to try a few ideas that have now occured to me. Comment 3: Dear Bill If the poems themselves do not need to be shuffled (same as your "sorting"?) then this is achievable. But there is no tiered, shuffling of shuffled sets of questions (containing immovable descriptors). So assuming it is okay that all the students get the same poems in the same order, then.... In between the poems you can then add "random questions" which are placemarkers for questions drawn at random from a specified category. Hence after poem one you would add four random questions from the category of questions "questions about poem one." And after poem two you would add four random questions from the category "questions about poem two". The categories would have to contain four or more questions. If you want the students to be given questions about diffferent poems either drawn at random from a set of poems, or at least in a radom order then (since there is no facility for binding questions together and shuffling them) you would have to put the poem and the question(s) in the same moodle question. This would mean that you would have only one multiple choice question about each poem. But you could also 1) Have a poem followed by four questions as part an essay question. I don't know about these but I guess it provides the students with a box to submit an answer, a bit like an assignment. The students might then write four answers inside that one box. 2) A poem followed by four questions each with A,B,C,D responses followed by a short answer question to which the correct answer would be "BCDA," or whatever meaning that the answer to the first question is B, the second C etc. You could also set answer variants so that the question also accepts "bcda" and "B C D A" and "B,C,D,A" as correct answers too. This in GIFT format (for only two questions) is Jenny kissed me when we met
jumping from the chair she sat in
Time you thief who likes to get
Sweets into your list put that in
Say I'm weary, say I am sad,
Say that health and wealth have missed me,
Say I'm growing old but add,
Jenny kissed me


1) This poem is about
A. The first world war
B.  Food fetishism
C.  Crime
D. The ravages of time

2) The author is ........about being kissed by Jenny.
A. remembering
B. reminiscing 
C. reverting
D. revamping
{ Type the answers to question (1) and (2) into this box: =%100%DB =%100%db =%100%D,B =%100%D B =%50%da =%50%dc =%50%dd =%50%ab =%50%bb =%50%cb =%50%DA =%50%DC =%50%DD =%50%AB =%50%BB =%50%CB =%50%D,A =%50%D,C =%50%D,D =%50%A,B =%50%B,B =%50%C,B =%50%D A =%50%D C =%50%D D =%50%A B =%50%B B =%50%C B } That would get very tiresome for more questions! I think that Joseph has written a question type that uses regular expressions. Perhaps that could be used. 3) You could also have a poem followed by 4 questions each with four answers followed by a multiple choice questions with 16 responses four of which would be correct. This in GIFT format (for only two questions) is Jenny kissed me when we met
jumping from the chair she sat in
Time you thief who likes to get
Sweets into your list put that in
Say I'm weary, say I am sad,

1) This poem is about
A. The first world war
B.  Food fetishism
C.  Crime
D. The ravages of time

2) The author is ........about being kissed by Jenny.
A. remembering
B. reminiscing 
C. reverting

{ ~%-50%The answer to question 1 is A ~%-50%The answer to question 1 is B ~%-50%The answer to question 1 is C ~%50%The answer to question 1 is D ~%-50%The answer to question 2 is A ~%50%The answer to question 2 is B ~%-50%The answer to question 2 is C ~%-50%The answer to question 2 is D } If you created moodle questions containing both the poem and questions by one of these methods, then you could also create permutations (with the question order reversed, or the correct answers in different places) and have them chosen at random. But there is no way of achieving two tiered shuffling, or shuffling sets, where one part of the set (the poem) stays at the top. Tim Comment 4: Ok Timothy, here's what I did.  I built the class link to the quiz.  The setup I told it to not shuffle the questions, but I did tell it to shuffle the answers.  Then I stated building the actual quiz.  I created a description resource for the first poem.  Then created the four questions in the same category name as the poem.  I then selected these four questsions and then added these 4 random questions to the quiz.  Then I created the next poem description resource and it's 4 questions.  Again I created the questions in the same categoty name as the poem then selected these four questions and then added these 4 random questions to the quiz.  Now I go to preview the quiz, and the random questions that i added selectively by category name are all randomized.  Nothing lines up.  The questions are not the correct ones for the poem.  And of course I don't just do two poems to try it out.  I should know better. Any ideas as to what I am doing wrong?  Or is this just the way it is when you randomize?  I may be stumped.......... Comment 5: Bill If you did not shuffle (randomise) the order of the questions (see first quiz set up screen) then the order of the poems should stay put. What is the setting of "shuffle questions" in the first set up page of the quiz? If you are going to randomise the order of the questions using the random questions function then you must make sure that the questions are in different categories. Did you create seperate categories for each of the poems? Tim Comment 6: That's what I didn't quite understand.  I was building a quiz and equating that with category.  Now I am splitting out my differing 'categories' within a quiz into their appropriately renamed category and it is all working.  Thanks for enlightening me.  Maybe soon I will know enough to use this product to its true potential.  I hope.  Still in the learning stages, but learning as I go. Thanks to all for your patience and assistance, and especially you Timothy. Label:

The button does exactly the same thing that the link "Next" does albeit in the button format. I am not sure what impact this can have though on the function of the return key. Forum Post: 
Post title: Is it possible to give a quiz without access to the Internet?
Post description: Hello, I was wandering if there is a way to give an online quiz to a class without letting them them to connect the Internet . - other websites accept from our moodle system Lets say we give an online quiz of 2 hours in 2 classes with PC's in a network and the moodle system "sits" In the same network (in the campus). is there a way to let these 2 classes to connect only to moodle if so how can we do it? is there some configuration with moodle system or with the server ? Thanks
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: Although no trick is fool-proof, I've used this one in the past: Disable DNS resolution on all the classroom PCs, then add a manual "hosts file" entry for the Moodle server. To disable DNS resolution in Linux (and Mac?), you can replace their /etc/resolv.conf with a new copy that looks like this: #give a false domain to search search thisdomainwillneverbefound.dom #use the local workstation to resolve DNS lookups nameserver 127.0.0.1 To specify one site that the use should have access to, add an entry in /etc/hosts similar to this one (with the real internal IP and fully qualified domain name of your Moodle server, of course) : 192.168.1.200 mymoodleserver.mydomain.dom If you have a classroom of similarly named Linux workstations (their names only differ by a number, e.g. "compy-01" thru "compy-50") , these files would be simple to distribute, too. Get your two files (resolv.conf and hosts) setup how you want them in your working directory and then...
Comment 2: seems complicate but I'll try that, thanks a lot

Post title: Embedded Answers scoring problem
Post description: Hello, we have a problem with the scores in the Embedded Answers quiz question type. We use Moodle 3.1. Attached, the MS doc with coded exercise (in Italian), screenshots and other data. This is the case (just one example, but it's a recurring problem for all other Embedded Answers exercises): A text with blanks to be filled (20 items). The score is 6 points for the "perfect" execution (i.e. 0.3 for each correct answer - but you know Embedded Answers lets you enter the total score (6), but not the partial (0.3) for the single item). I created it, I tried it out several times and also disabled the penalty for wrong answers. Now, if I do everything right, that is 20/20 correct answers, I get 6/6. However, if I perform only 10 right answers I always get a very strange 1.57 out of 6, whether the 10 items left are wrong or blank (i.e. I omit to fill them). I can't explain. Of course it should come 3 out of 6. Any help? Thank you for your kind attention

Forum Post: 
Post title: Scenario: using category-level question categories
Post description: A rather typical scenario - at least in our university - is that a department wants to maintain a department-level question bank that their teachers can use in their courses. Editing the inter-course question bank is limited to a few specialists. We tried to solve this by putting question categories in the course category context for department, but regular teachers who have roles only in their courses can't access it to add questions to their quizzes. Assigning every teacher a role in the department course category is a nightmare. Is it possible to allow users to use questions stored in higher-level contexts without being assigned a role in that higher-level context? Or how this is supposed to be working?
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: "Is it possible to allow users to use questions stored in higher-level contexts without being assigned a role in that higher-level context?" No. Not possible. This is a problem. If you find the recording of the session Thomas Korner, Luca Bosch and I did at Moot global (or Moot DACH) you will see this is something we plan to try to fix. However, there are no easy answers.

Comment 1: Hello Anamaria, See: https://moodleformulas.org/course/view.php?id=35&section=25 ↗ David Galiana has done some nice work with the Formulas question type and Geogebra. Here is one of his example: https://moodleformulas.org/course/view.php?id=78&section=45 ↗ See also : https://moodle.org/mod/forum/search.php?id=5&words=&phrase=&notwords=&fullwords=&hfromday=1&hfrommonth=1&hfromyear=1&hfromhour=1&hfromminute=1&htoday=1&htomonth=1&htoyear=1&htohour=1&htominute=1&forumid=&subject=&user=David+Galiana ↗ and https://dgaliana.gitbook.io/preguntasstem/geogebra ↗
Comment 2: Thank you! All the best, Anamaria
Comment 3: Please can you tell me how can I add the graf of function f(x)=x^a1 to this question? Thanks
Comment 4: You need to include into the script: // Create a function graph for f(x) = x**a1 var graph = brd.create('functiongraph', [function(x){ return x**a1;}, -10.5, 10.5] );

Post title: PMatch N Choose K
Post description: Is there a way to write pmatch questions to account for a user inputting a few answers from a short list of possibilities (like a combination problem where there are N total possible answers and they need to input K of them)? For a very simplified example question: "what are any 4 of the first 8 letters of the alphabet?" A, B, C, D, E, F, G, H are all possibilities, but I'm unsure how (if even possible) to make an answer that will check for at least any 4 of them. As more of a closer to useful example, I have been doing this to help account for partial credit (although it isn't doing the same thing my question was about, I felt it was kind of related): "Atoms are composed of three subatomic particles, each with a different net electric charge: one positive, one negative, and one with no net charge. These particles are called __30x1__ , respectively. (Please enter your answers as a comma separated list: e.g.     green, purple, yellow) match_mw (proton? electron? neutron?) - 100% match_mw (proton? neutron? electron?) - 66.666% match_mw (* * neutron?) - 33.3333% .....etc. for all possibilities" Thanks for any advice!
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: This can be done, and there is an example here: https://www.open.edu/openlearncreate/mod/oucontent/view.php?id=52747&section=2.2.1 , the bit near "2.24 A response match"
Comment 2: Ah, okay. I just need to separate all the options with a pipe operator and list them all multiple times (for the number of responses I'm looking for). match_mow (A|B|C|D|E|F|G|H A|B|C|D|E|F|G|H A|B|C|D|E|F|G|H A|B|C|D|E|F|G|H ) I had previously tried nested match_any: match_all( match_any (A|B|C|D|E|F|G|H)

Forum Post: 
Post title: Quiz Error when Next button was used
Post description: A student of ours got an error message when she clicked on the Next button to navigate to the next question in her quiz. Although the error message states that the test-taker used the browser navigation buttons, I know our student didn't do this from reviewing her exam recording. The message: "You have entered
data outside of the normal sequence. This can occur if you use your browser’s
back and forward buttons, please don’t use these during the test. It can also
happen if you click on something while a page is loading. Click Continue to
resume." When she clicked "Continue" as prompted by Moodle, it took her to her Moodle profile, and she wasn't able to resume the quiz. I also tried reproducing the error but was unsuccessful (I did this by navigating away from the page as a student user, multiple times, via the browser back and forward buttons, but wasn't able to get the same error message to pop-up). Any insight on what may have caused this error to populate outside of the reasons specified by the error (since I determined that was the case), would be appreciated! Moodle Cloud version 3.8.2
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: Note, it says "... This can occur id ...". It does not say "... This can only occur id ...". It is just one possible reason why this can happen - the one where the user can easily do something about it if that was the cause - which is why that particular cause is the one we explain. If the cause was something else, then sometimes you can work it out be careful analysis of the logs (Moodle logs and web server logs together.)
Comment 2: Hi... In my case, it's happening when I finish answering all questions and again navigate to previous page through browser back btn and again click the finish btn. Why should this cause error in moodle? Is there a solution for this?
Comment 3: Hi Aparna, If you used the browser back button, that could cause the error. That is specifically what the error message states (see my first post). Always use the navigation buttons provided directly in the quiz to navigate, never the browser back and forward buttons. Is there anything else that you're doing that may also be causing the error that you can think of?
Comment 4: Thanks for your reply Danielle... I know we should use the nav btns, but we can't restrict the end users. How can we prevent users to see this error page, because we launch quiz from a different application. We don't want to show the users any other page other than the attempt page and when this error occurs user is able to see the inner features of moodle like site navigation, profile etc.

Thanks for the help Peter
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: I find myself having to put together a new question type in the very near future (ie, days), so I'll keep one eye on the docs. I'm more concerned about the differences between 1.8 and 1.9. There's clearly some considerations but I'm unsure if they have been documented anywhere yet.
Comment 2: Ahh.... that'll be this then: http://docs.moodle.org/en/Question_Engine_Changes_in_Moodle_1.9
Comment 3: Hi Peter, 1- The only experience I have in writing a question type plugin was the regexp question type which is basically an extension of the existing shortanswer question type. So I started from the shortanswer question type and did the necessary modifications in its various files. This is of course only possible when a new question type is fairly close to an existing one, at least to start with. 2- I am very interested in you new plugin, although I do not quite see what it might look like from the short description you give: "... a question type where the student marks themself against a model answer so that no tutor intervention is required? " Would it look more like a shortanswer type or a Multiple Choice type? I'm puzzled and would like to see some real-world examples. Joseph PS.- I agree with Howard that an important consideration is whether to start developing such new question type plugins for 1.8 or straight away for 1.9, considering the differences.
Comment 4: Hi Peter, I may have a (non-development) solution for you.... I don't have time to outline it in detail here. I've lost your phone number, can you give me a ring so I can quickly go through it with you and if it works perhaps you could post the method here... Edit: Found a simpler way.... 1.8 Put each learner in a group.
Comment 5: Hi Ray Thanks for the response, I will contact you directly and feedback any progress back to the forum. Peter
Comment 6: Hi Joseph Thanks for your post. The question type which I am looking towards would be more like a short answer than a multiple choice question. I have a course which has been paper-based for 30 or so years and we simply want to make an online version of it. It is available in over 50 languages, so having a standard format which would work with Importing questions and answers in a standard format where I am not familiar with the language is key for us. A question would look somthing like this: 1. What name did Jesus give to the Scripture? (John 10:35) Type your answer below: Submit button Student then sees: 1. What name did Jesus give to the Scripture? (John 10:35) The student's answer The model answer Please score your answer: __/1 The complexities that I see which may cause a problem, but are undoubtably solveable, are that: I would like the student to be able to see a form with the Question, Their Answer, the Model Answer and their score at any stage after the quiz for the purpose of printing it or review; There are also notes to the correct answers, but I presume this is where feedback comes in (I haven't used it up till now); Some questions have more than one part eg: 20. List four things from the following verses that God’s Word does for His people. (1) (John 15:3) (Eph. 5:26) (2) (John 17:17) (3) (Acts 20:32) (4) (Acts 20:32) The concept seems so simple to me, but I think that making it a reality may take quite a lot of work.  As you point out, it would be worth keeping the 1.9 developments in mind and I think that while we wouldn't need the funcitionality that the new version brings, it may prevent later upgrade issues? I have seen Ray's post and have tried to contact him.  While I think that his workaround may help in the short term, having to set up groups and monitor new enrolments etc. is one of the reasons that I would like a new question type which stands on its own without any further intervention required. Thanks Peter
Comment 7: Instead of developing a new question type, I have been working on setting up a student marked quiz going along the lines of a suggestion of using the Essay question type and Overriding the student role to be able them to grade the quiz manually and view quiz reports and it works really well, except... When the student goes back in to the quiz, they are able to see the results tab and view, mark and edit other students' answers. Can anyone advise me how we can ensure that the student can have those permissions (Grade Quiz Manually and View Quiz Reports) but only see their own results and only grade their own questions? I have basically finished setting up the course now, so I would ideally like to move on with this method if at all possible rather than starting again. I am using Moodle 1.8 Thanks Peter
Comment 8: Not currently possible - unless you put students in groups with one student per group, and switch the quiz to separate groups mode.
Comment 9: Hi Tim Excuse my ignorance, but I haven't worked with groups before - can this be set up to happen automatically or is it a manual process? Thanks Peter
Comment 10: I fear it is probably manual. Although there is some sort of upload interface in admin somewhere, that may be the easiest way to do this.
Comment 11: Hi Tim and others I have been in contact with Moodle HQ about building an automatic group creation plugin which would mean that each student would be put into their own group at enrolment.  As I understand it from what Tim and Ray have said in the past, this should mean that they would not be able to see anyone else's Grades etc. Well, I have done a bit of testing on this, creating different student profiles and putting them each in their own groups; setting the course to Separate Groups mode and then doing a quiz in the different student profiles. It appears to me that when I go back into the quiz after completion (as student) and select the Results tab, the Overview is affected by the Separate Groups and I only see the logged in student's quiz, but Manual Grading doesn't appear to be picking up the Separate Groups functionality. Is this a bug or have I missed something? Thanks Peter
Comment 12: It is a known bug ( MDL-12547 ) that may get fixed in the next few months.
Comment 13: Hi Peter, I'm going to be working on the documentation in the next week or so, hopefully finishing up by the end of next week. There's nothing wrong with the TEMPLATE type as it stands so you could go ahead and use it as a starting point now, but it would be easier to use with some more documentation, both inline in the code and in the wiki/README, so that's what I'm going to be working on.
Comment 14: Thanks, Adriane I will keep an eye on these. Regards Peter
Comment 15: Realistically, I am not going to get time to work on these docs any time soon. Adraine was employed as part of the Google Summer of Code and successfully wrote four question types using the incomplete docs and looking at the code for other questions, so it is not impossible. And it is great that she is going to use her experiences to improve the documentation. It would be great if other people who have written question types could similarly improve the docs. I will review any changes made to those docs, and add any clarifications I can.

Post title: dinamic quiz
Post description: Greetings! I want to create a new plugin to manage a quiz in the following way: When a student clicks on the start of the quiz, he receives one intermediate level question, If he answered a wrong answer, he gets an easy question, if he succeeded, he goes back to medium, he succeeded in a medium question - he gets a difficult one, and after several difficult questions in a row, he ends the quiz. I would appreciate any help and information regarding similar plugins such as: If there is a plugin that displays one question each time and only when the question is submitted, the next question is received. If there is a plugin of difficulty levels for the question. Any information would be very helpful. Thanks!
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: I'm not aware of any branching functionality that Moodle quiz can perform, but the tool offers the capability to make questions conditional upon other questions: https://docs.moodle.org/38/en/Building_Quiz#Making_questions_conditional_upon_other_questions
Comment 2: There is a Moodle Plugin that has the functionality. Adaptive Quiz: CAT (Computer-Adaptive Testing) implentation for Moodle for a teacher to create tests that efficiently measure the takers' abilities. You need a rather robust set of questions in the Question Bank that are orgranized by rigor. This is probably why we have not tried the plugin yet. Still working on the quality of the questions, which is easier to measure with question statistics today.

Forum Post: 
Post title: How to add embedded shortanswer fields on PDF  /image
Post description: Hello everyone, I need to develop a quiz containing questions in the form of an image with fill-in-the-gaps fields all over the image. Imagine a tax return with a lot of fields to be calculated and filled in the respective fields. Imagine an accounting student learning how to fill in such a return. We need to put a description with the case, then the student to calculate the respective figures and to fill in the form. And I imagine a quiz of at least 15-20 questions of this type. Of course we need Moodle to check whether all the calculations in the forms are correct or not. Drop and drag on image is not enough - we need Cloze's shortansers on an image or on a PDF, but I am not sure Cloze has such an ability. Assignment is not OK - we need a quiz in order to get evaluation immediately and not manually. Can you recommend me a way to do this? Thanks a lot.
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: Hi Vera, I would recommend using the Formulas question type. With it and using a table, you can layout and create the look of the actual tax form you want to use for testing. With this question type, you can set things up so that there are multiple places where the student will have to input an answer. Further, with careful planning, you can set up your question so that it randomly gives different versions of the question to each student to help cut down on cheating. Here is a look at part of a question from years ago.
Comment 2: Hello Vera, AL's suggestions are excellent. You can place answer boxes over an image for any question type, but you have to use custom formatting with CSS and JavaScript . It's not difficult but you have to get a bit familiar with the coding langages. For text images, PNG format is more efficient than not JPEG. PDF's are special. You need a reader to display them. You may be able to superimpose answer boxes over a single page PDF, much more difficult, if at all possible, if the PDF has more than one page. Anyway, it would be much easier with a PNG image You raise an interesting question. Can PDF "forms" be displayed and filled in in Moodle? Probably not, but that remains to be checked. And let's suppose they can, could the data entered in the form be retrieved by Moodle? Anyway, if I were you, I would consider AL's suggestions which will give you a sound solution.

Forum Post: 
Post title: e-mail mentee/parent on completion
Post description: Hello, I've seen a couple different ways to e-mail specified addresses when a student completes a quiz. But from what I've seen they all involved manually putting in an e-mail address. I would like to have the results e-mail to the mentee/parent when the quiz is completed. Has anyone done this before or have any ideas of a good way of going about it? I'm kinda new to Moodle but I feel that many would benefit from this being built in to Moodle.
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: I support this option if it was available in Moodle. CS
Comment 2: There is a plugin for this I'm sure called "Quiz Email Notification". Get it from going to moodle.org and on top left you'll see Modules and Plugins. Get it from there I think Steve
Comment 3: Unfortunately, that hack won't do what the OP is looking for if I understand it correctly i.e. an email to be sent to a dynamic address (e.g. the students parent) rather than specific addresses. We don't have parents/mentees in our organisation so not something we thought of or looked into. There is "official" work going on along these lines so might be an idea to add a feature request. See this thread and in Moodle docs here . Regards
Comment 4: The official "Email Notification" code that is being built into version 1.9 of Moodle will send notification emails to any "role" that has the email attributes set in the "role override" section of the quiz or course. If you visit the feature request linked at the top of the docs page previously mentioned, you will find a patch for version 1.9 which will almost run on 1.8 of moodle too. I have not tested as I developed this feature on 1.8 and we created it for 1.9 as the "official" version. So it might be better if you request the patch for version 1.8 that I have here and I can post it in this thread if you like. My 1.8 patch does not take note of groupings. So to notify anyone, you would need to have them as a registered user in Moodle and all in a common role. It is designed to notify supervisors and teachers of all quiz submissions. It does take note of the groupings, but it would be a pain to group by every parent or student so that you can have an email notification to a separate parent for each student.... is possible I guess, but I would not want to administer it. This feature (as is) is more than likely not what the OP wanted if I read it right. Unless he is talking about a small group of parents for a larger group of students and all parents receiving all student notifications (or a different sub-group of students each). Another way of wagging the dog would be if you can control the mailboxes of each student and perhaps duplicate emails with certain subjects. This would also be a bit of a pain in the ..... but could use the "confirmation" feature to the student him/her self and copy to someone in the mailbox processing. This is also messy. Personally I would not do that as it is a maintenance nightmare. Hope this helps Graham
Comment 5: The way you could do it based on the 1.9 work is to use groups, and create lots of groups that just contain the student, and the parent or mentor. Then set the quiz to separate groups, and set the parent/mentor role to get email whenever someone in their group completes a quiz.
Comment 6: I have 1.9 and that kind of configuration. But when a news student register and have no group, when he finish a quiz all teachers receive the notification. It´s possible when a student without group finish a quiz only the admin or nobody receive that notification? thanks
Comment 7: Ah, that sounds like a bug. Could you file it at tracker.moodle.org, and I will look into it when I get back from my Christmas Holidays. Thanks.
Comment 8: ok, thanks. here it is: http://tracker.moodle.org/browse/MDL-12776

Forum Post: 
Post title: Forcing Review of Quiz Results in Respondus Lockdown Browser
Post description: Hi All, I am planning on utilizing the Respondus Lockdown Browser for the quizzes/exams I give in my class this fall, and I've had no plans setting this up. However, I have not been able to find a way to restrict students to using the Lockdown Browser when they review their quiz/exam results. My plan was that I would allow students to review their results only for a short time while we discuss commonly missed questions in class, and then turn this review option off as soon as we were done. This way, the students would only be able to review their results in a Lockdown environment for a short period of time while I am present. I would then be able to protect the integrity of my exam questions. However, based on my experience messing around with Moodle, it appears that as long as the settings are configured so that students can review their results, they can access their results in any browser regardless of whether the original quiz was taken in a Lockdown environment. Another faculty member indicated that restricting review to the Lockdown Browser used to be an option in Moodle, but I can't seem to find it, nor can our IT department. We are currently using Moodle 3.2. Any help or workaround solutions are greatly appreciated! Thanks!
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: This  is a known limitation of the available options. You are not the first person to ask for it, but it has not yet been implemented.
Comment 2: Hi Andy, Did you ever find a way to do this?  When we were using Moodle 3.1, students had to review the exams in LockDown Browser.  I don't know if it's something that changed in Moodle 3.3 or if it could be because of the new Boost theme we're using.  There was never a setting to make this happen in the past, it just worked that way.  It's quite a problem for us now that it is not working.  Any insight would be appreciated. Linda

Post title: "Correct" and a red cross can appear simultaneously in a calculated question. Why have it so?
Post description: In a calculated question (Moodle 1.9), it seems to me that an answer is marked as "Correct" if it falls within the tolerance band of the exact answer. However, it is marked with a green tick if it falls within the tolerance band of the rounded answer (i.e. the answer rounded to the required number of, for example, significant figures). On occasion, this leads to an answer marked as "Correct" but given a red cross and, at other times, to an answer marked as "Incorrect" but given a green tick. The frequency of occurrence can be minimised by increasing the number of sig figs but I wonder why this is how things are set up. What advantage does this offer that outweighs the confusion engendered when it's first encountered? I'm new to this, by the way, and find Moodle impressive but I couldn't find the answer to my query after digging round for a bit. Graham
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: Can you give us a specific example of a question (Export it as Moodle XML perhaps, or just tell us the exact settings for creating it) and the answer you need to type to see this problem. Even better, put that information into the Moodle bug tracker: http://tracker.moodle.org/
Comment 2: Thanks, Tim. Here's how to generate the situation. I'll look into how to produce XML and I'm happy to submit the bug report but thought I'd check first that it wasn't my lack of experience shining through. 1. Set up a calculated question such as "What is 2 times {A}?" with a formula of 2*{A} 2. Use defaults of 0.01 relative tolerance and set correct answer format of 3 sig fig. (I also set grade to 100%)

Comment 8: Pierre, Thank you for your responses. I agree 100% that the main goal is to check that the student is within the desired tolerance of the exact answer. Consequently, this should be the criterion for the award of Correct/Incorrect and also the Green Tick/Red Cross. The significant figures can determine the accuracy with which Moodle presents the correct answer but this is not the place to add a judgment about the number of significant figures given by the student. I woud be delighted to see this impemented. If I can help, let me know though I guess my skills may limit this to helping with any testing. Graham

Post description: Dear Tim: I have never seen a discussion about this, so I hope you will favor me with some information! I am interested in updating the quiz module on my 1.6.1+ instance (installed around Aug 15).  I don't want to update the entire codebase because I have customized quite a few things!  But from the changelogs, you have done some things lately with quiz that we probably want to have installed. Is it safe to just update the quiz module?  How can a person tell if it is okay to just update the module files as opposed to updating everything?  If you have time, could you give some advice? atw
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: Hi A.T, I'm sure Tim will answer you with more details, but I will drop my 2 cents on this, ans we have done this a couple of weeks ago. We run Moodle 1.6, and we have customized some pages. However one of the most used tools in our Virtual University is the Quiz module; So, as soon we realized that some bugs were present (regrading was losing student responsed, etc. etc.), we did a quiz module upgrade without upgrading the entire Moodle. However, I would like to give you two hints:
Comment 2: By this, do you mean the questions that we have in the pools themselves? Thanks! atw
Comment 3: Yes sir!
Comment 4: In theory it should work, because the interface that modules use to connect to the moodle core, is stable. In practise, it does work, as long as the version of the module and the version of core are not too different. On a stable branch like 1.6.x the odds are very good (but as was said, read the release notes). However, it is a bit of flexibility that not many people take advantage of, so it is not as well tested as using the using the version of the quiz module that shipped with the release. So be even more paranoid than usual about backing up before the upgrade, so you can undo it if anything goes wrong, and testing that everything is working after the upgrade. The OU was running 1.6.1+ quiz with 1.6 Moodle + OU changes for a while, but then we have only been using Moodle for a few months, and not many courses are using quizzes yet.

Post title: How do i display the log IP address on the Quiz report download?
Post description: Hi, I would really appreciate someone's help on this one. I have been using Moodle quiz for some time now and i would really love to have the IP addresses of each student displayed in the Quiz result download . I need this to help monitor if students take quiz outside of the assigned location. We sometimes allow the students to do quiz within a confined location. I know we could use the "Require network address" under the "Extra restrictions on attempts" settings but the challenge with that once it is in use, it doesn't allow the use of password under the group overrides. The lecturers use the password group overrides to ensure that only students who attended the lectures appropriately are allowed to take the quiz but once the "Require network address" is in use any one in that location is permitted to take the quiz which defeats the aim. By the way, the quiz is done on BYOD.
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: The IP address may not be fixed for the whole quiz attempt - particularly in the case you want to detect. If you want to see the IP address for each student throughout the quiz, look in the Moodle logs.
Comment 2: This is what I do, i.e., look in the logs.  One can request the logs for a particular event, the quiz, and export them to Excel for further analysis.  In my case, I don't want students to be in the same location, so I sort the exported list by IP, and then look for duplicates.
Comment 3: Wow, i must say thank you. That's was useful indeed

Post title: Moodle Quiz from Word 2013/2016 Template (moodle_quiz_v21_en.dot template)
Post description: I am trying to install the word template for moodle quiz ( Document and ). This is not working for me for word 2013 or 2016. Is there any fix for this?
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: Perhaps you could start with telling us exactly what is not working?
Comment 2: Can you create a step by step tutorial to install the Moodle Quiz for Word 2016 Template, it does not work in my Surface pro 4 MS Word. "the macros can't be found or  has been disabled because of your Macros security settings" In MS-word -Trust Center I "enabled all macros" In MS-word -Add Ins the template was added. Still does not work... Help
Comment 3: Hello, What version of Word/Office are you using? The trouble with Macro-based solutions is complexity. The various MS-Word quiz solutions that have been developed over the years are fragile. This is because a lot changes inside of Office/Word at each release, e.g., new security policies, changes to the document models on which the macros are based, etc. These macro-based solutions are developed by the open-source/Moodle community, and there are inadequate human resources to update them to follow the changes of Office. One possible solution is to install inside a virtual machine (you'll need IT support help to do this) an old version of Word (e.g., Word 2007, Word 2013, etc.) for which the macro-based solution was developed.
Comment 4: I installed a Oracle Virtual Machine and then installed MS Office 2013. However the error is the same. I am using Tablet SURFACE PRO 4 in laptop mode. Help...
Comment 5: OK - I have another option that's a little more experimental, but doesn't rely on macros (it's based on the same code as the Macro version, however). Inside the VM with Office 2013 (or if you already have Office 2013 installed in Windows 10 you don't need to use a VM) can you try to install the VSTO version of Word-Moodle-Quiz as a setup.exe using the following instructions at: https://github.com/fuhrmanator/word-moodle-quiz#installation--updates - here's a copy of those instructions: Installation / Updates The solution now is a VSTO (Visual Studio Tools for Office) Document-level customization (in Word). It requires .NET 4.0 as well as some VSTO 2010 files to run. To successfully install this on your Windows machine, follow these steps: In Windows, add `http://profs.etsmtl.ca/` to the "Trusted Sites" zone (do not require https: ). For more information, see how to add sites to zones . In Internet Explorer (I'm not sure it works with other browsers), download and run setup.exe . You should see a warning that the Publisher cannot be verified . This is normal because currently there is no certificate for this tool. However, you can verify that it's indeed From: `http://profs.etsmtl.ca/cfuhrman/MoodleQuestions/MoodleQuestions.vsto` If you don't trust this tool, then do not install it. * Download the customized Word document to start creating your quiz questions. If you have trouble installing with the SETUP.EXE file, you can alternately 1) Uninstall the installation if you installed an older version, and/or 2) try installing the MoodleQuestions.vsto . Note this version comes with no guarantees of its stability. Use at your own risk. Documentation The Document-level Customized version of the tool is not yet documented, but it supports most of the functionality documented by Frankie Kam . With a lot of help from my students, I developed this VSTO version (but haven't touched it much for a few years). I tested it again on my Surface Pro 4 just now with Office 2013 (didn't try in Laptop mode though!) and it's working for me (but I'm not using a VM!). Hope this helps!
Comment 6: Finally my problem was solved, thanks.
Comment 7: I was evaluating the VSTO it works in MS-Word 2007, 2013 and 2016. However it slowdown MS-Word in all versions and there are some features to improve, such as, after exporting to XML adding a new question, the VSTO add the new question at the beginning and not after the last question even when you put the cursor at the end of document. Thanks for your effort in helping  moodle users.
Comment 8: Thanks for the feedback! Were you able to import into Moodle the XML generated by the tool? Currently (like many open-source efforts) nobody is working on the VSTO maintenance. However, I occasionally get new students looking for projects and so I can direct them to this project. The best way to put your feedback (improvements) is to create issues directly on the GitHub project: https://github.com/fuhrmanator/word-moodle-quiz/issues
Comment 9: Hi, I'm working for the local Education Authority of Champaign, in France, in charge of teacher's formation. I've tried MoodleQuestions.vost on Moodle 3.1 and Office2016 on Windows10 today, and it works well. I'm searching for a solution to make Moodle Quiz simple, and this
solution would be ideal. But i'm searching for a solution for teachers
who do not often understand English. Is there any possibility to translate MoodleQuestionsdocm, and the rest of the program ?
Comment 10: Moodle has language packs.  It sounds like you are using a plugin, so this might be better directed to the plugin authors but I will leave it here for now in case Tim has any insight.
Comment 11: You could consider the WordTable plugin , which supports localised Word templates for creating questions. The labels in the Word templates are derived directly from the Moodle language packs (as far as possible), so should be familiar to users. The templates are separate from the plugin, so are kept on a different website www.moodle2word.net . At present, they are a bit fiddly to install on a PC, because the automatic installer VBA code recently started being treated as malware, so you have to do it manually. I haven't got around to re-creating all the templates for different languages, but English, French and Spanish versions are currently available.
