Forum Post: 
Post title: Quiz Review, Quiz Restrictions not honored
Post description: Version: 2.9 - When setting up quiz restrictions such as IP Address, those settings are not honored when reviewing the quiz. The open/close times are but not the IP Address restrictions. How can this be changed? Is there a little code that can be modified to check for ip address during a review?
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: It can't be changed (without altering the code). That is how it is designed to work. (Whether this is the best way it could work is something that has been discussed in the past, without any firm conclusions being reached.)
Comment 2: That really stinks! We will be probably end up losing this feature for one department because as soon as a quiz is over they will go to another device in another room or hallway and screenshot/copy/paste the entire quiz. This just happened and is how I noticed it. What areas need to be changed?
Comment 3: "That really stinks!" That may not be the most effective way of procuring support.
Comment 4: Hah! That was just my initial reaction,  I was really hoping it was a bug. If there is an access rule for any module in Moodle it should be honored no matter what, at least, that's what I believe.
Comment 5: This may be the type of thing to report as an issue in the bug tracker. That is not to suggest it might be fixed, just that any unexpected behaviour is good to have documented. One of the very nice things about Moodle is that there is heaps of automated tests. This is not of direct and obvious benefit to end users but it does mean that stuff is effectively documented, even if it documents a test failing.  I write as a man recently seduced by the glory of Behat and Mink testing whereby a ghost in the browser does all the clicking for you and never gets bored of doing it.
Comment 6: If you look near the top of attempt.php ( https://github.com/moodle/moodle/blob/master/mod/quiz/attempt.php#L81 ) you will see that it basically involves calling the prevent_access method of $accessmanager. If any messages are returned, display them as an error, rather than continuing to display the page. You would need to add similar code at the top of review.php. just after this bit might be a good place: https://github.com/moodle/moodle/blob/master/mod/quiz/review.php#L58 Well, to do a better job, you would also need to find every place where it prints a link to the review page, and stop showing those links, because generally speaking it is bad usability to show someone a link that just takes them to an 'access denied' error. However, that is a refinement that you could add later after getting the important bit of blocking access to work.
Comment 7: Thanks! I will take this and work it out, even if they get an access denied error it will be better than them being able to view all the answers/questions in an unmonitored environment.
Comment 8: Thanks again! I managed to get working, they can no longer review the quiz when not on the specified subnet. I also created a new language string which displays a better message than an error page. Could this be added to core? Should there be an option to restrict review access based on the access rules instead of all or none? I am also working on removing the "review" links throughout. Teachers would still be able to review though on any subnet.
Comment 9: We discussed adding this to core once before. You are not the first person to ask for this. However, the number of people who want it is quite small. So, it is a trade-off between add yet another option to the already complex quiz form for everyone, in order to satisfy a few people. Oh, I just had a worrying thought. Does this make it impossible to review a quiz that has a time limit or a close date? If we do implement this in core, probably the best way is a new option in the Extra restrictions on attempts section: Restrictions apply to reviews as well as attempts: Yes/No.
Comment 10: That would make sense, not enough users have requested it. I have not yet tested it yet though for after the quiz is closed or time limit, in our case though, we do not allow review once it is closed. If we do encounter that issue, then I will more than likely have to make more changes so that it only checks the ipaddress access rule. That is what I was thinking, adding a check box to the extra restrictions page, I will probably end up doing it for ours, then apply the patch after each update. Thanks!
Comment 11: Hi! We got version Moodle 3.09. Can you help me to how to modify the code if I want the same restrictions to the quiz review? (the most important is IP restriction) Thanks is advance, Csaba

Post title: offline quiz response form(s) pending assessment not working
Post description: ```text
Hello everyone.

I have a moodle 3.9 in production, for a long time the quizzes have been done online but due to a problem with the 
server
 we had to do them on paper as before.

In the offline quiz activity you can scan the results and the plugin corrects each submission.

The problem is that after scanning several, a point has been reached where when uploading new results, read the files (zip that contain jpeg) they are still being processed and even 1 day later they are still the same, clearly they don't take that long so it looks like the process has stopped or collapsed.

Can anyone who has experience with the subject and a similar problem give me any idea what the problem might be and what we could try to fix it?

Greetings.
```
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: I would guess that you either have a corrupted or incorrect file in one of the zip folders that caused it to fail or you might have hit a timeout somewhere. You could look at your scheduled tasks page and see if you can manually start the specific task (not sure which one but hopefully you can figure it out.). If that doesn't work, you might try restarting your web and database services on your server - failing that reboot...(backup first...)
Comment 2: Thank you Emma. I saw 3 scheduled task that affect offline quiz, 1 of them have an error writing on database. I will try to execute all an after that i will try again to upload at the quiz exam. Greetings.
Comment 3: I checked the cron that have an error is Answer sheet evaluation for the offlinequiz-plugin. The exact error is: Execute scheduled task: Answer sheet evaluation for the offlinequiz-plugin (mod_offlinequiz\task\page_evaluation_task) ... started 22:50:02. Current memory use 6.1MB. ... used 11 dbqueries

Forum Post: Post title: Sub question level feedback for Cloze questions Post description: TLDR : How to set a sub-question level feedback for Cloze type questions ? As per the documentation, Cloze type question either have answer option level feedback or a General feedback across all sub-questions. Is there a way to set a sub-question level feedback instead of the option level feedback ? Explanation : For normal MCQs , a line starting with '####' provides a common feedback for the question. In the Cloze subquestion, there is either an option to put a feedback after each answer option, beginning with '#" or there is an option to provide a 'general feedback' across multiple questions. Is there some option to use the #### type feedback for Cloze sub-questions instead of the # after each choice ? Sample sub-question of a Cloze type question : This is Sub question 1. {:MCV: %-25%Wrong answer#Feedback ~ %-25%Another wrong answer#Feedback ~ =Correct answer#Feedback ~ %-25%Another wrong answer#Feedback } Sample Regular Multiple choice question :

Question text of a normal MCQ

{ ~%-25%

wrong answer 1

~%-25%

wrong answer 2

=

correct answer

~%-25%

wrong answer 3

####

This is the question level feedback

} Comments associated with the post: Comment 1: Also, the "Clear my choice" link to clear the radio buttons appears for normal MCQs. But does not appear for sub-questions of a Cloze question. Is there a way to get the same for the Cloze sub-questions ? Comment 2: Hello July, I think these options are not available. They sound like good suggestions to me, but it's up to the plugin author to incorporate them. If you want an immediate solution and are a little adventurous, both of your suggestions can probably be accomplished with a simple JavaScript code. Note that there would be a security issue with the first one, since the feedback would be available in the question's DOM before the students answered the question. If you don't mind this problem too much (for example, if the feedback contains only non-sensitive information such as "Well done, good answer" or "Hmm, you should revisit this topic"), maybe I could help you with the code a bit later. Comment 3: @Dominique, Sounds good! The JavaScript option will be just fine. Since the quizzes are anyways for test preparation, the feedback or the answer explanation in the DOM would not be a problem. There is no urgency. Whenever you find time, a JS snippet would be great. Currently, I have used an inefficient work-around for the feedback. I have just used the same feedback lines across all the answer options - so it effectively works as a question level feedback. However, since the explanation can be a little lengthy at times, it increases the upload file size and the database size... Thanks! Comment 4: Hello July, I wrote some JavaScript code to get the "Clear my choice" link. I did it quickly, because like everyone else, I have a thousand other things to do. So the code could probably be simplified a bit, but it seems to work fine. https://moodleformulas.org/course/view.php?id=89§ion=11 ↗ I will do the sub-question feedback a little later. Comment 5: @Dominique Works perfectly ! Thank you !! Couple of small changes I made : [1] Included the ```text   ``` in the 'Additional HTML' field and omitted it from within the individual questions. [2] Created a .js file in the root folder and added the JS there. So, only ```text ``` is included in the individual questions Label:

Post title: Hide Feedback
Post description: Hi Tim, I'd like to give feedback to only a few students. Is it possible to input the feedback but only those students which I selected will get the feedback? The other students are not allowed to view the feedback notes. Cheers, Michael
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: This is not really possible. Two possible work-arounds: 1. Set up two separate quizzes with different feedback settings, and get each group of students to do the appropriate quiz. 2. Use the manual-grading feature and add the feedback by hand for those students who you want to see it.

Comment 3: Thanks a lot Tim. The idea was to get feedback on our "feedback" from only a few persons. During that time, others shouldn't be able to see our feedback notes.

Forum Post: 
Post title: Maximum number of users taking a quiz simultaneously
Post description: I read, from https://docs.moodle.org/20/en/User_site_capacities (no page seems to exist for 3.0+) : ... The exact number of users depends on your hardware/software/network combination. Usually the amount of memory installed (RAM) is the deciding factor but a faster overall processor speed will also help in reducing waiting times for pages to load. The general rule of thumb for a single server is that the approx max concurrent users = RAM (GB) * 50 and the approx max browsing users = Approx max concurrent users * 5. As an example, a university with 500 total computers on campus and 100 concurrent users at any time will need approx 2GB of RAM on the one server to support the number of concurrent users... Our government has state wide exams. According to the above rule of thumb and with a 100 000 / 50 = 2 000 GB = 2 TB web server or bigger, could 100 000 users take exactly the same quiz simultaneously? Also, would the waiting time for feedback during the quiz be reasonable? Best regards to all.
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: 100,000 simultaneous users taking a quiz is a big ask. Don't just rely on rules of thumb. You really need to know what you are doing. Talk to some experts. E.g. Catalyst IT in New Zealand.
Comment 2: I would say 100,000 simultaneous users taking a quiz is a massive task. Not just to ensure technical performance but to manage the "human factors" side of things. This discussion from a while ago contains information on how Catalyst have worked on some massive systems https://moodle.org/mod/forum/discuss.php?d=345901#p1395008

Post title: Question categories should belong to the same context as their parent (tool_health)

Post title: Preventing Teachers from Regrading Quiz Attempts in Moodle
Post description: Hello everyone, I'm currently hiring teachers to manually grade essay-type quiz questions for students at my center. These teachers are compensated based on their grading activity. However, I’ve noticed that some teachers are regrading attempts that were already assigned 0 points - either automatically (when students leave the answer blank) or manually in a prior grading round. This creates inaccuracies in both records and payment. Is there a way to automatically restrict teachers from grading the same quiz attempt more than once in Moodle - either by locking the grade after the first grading or by disabling access to already-graded attempts? Thank you in advance!
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: As I recall, when you use essay questions and view attempts, Moodle shows which students have questions that "need grading." But maybe your teachers are grading differently, or it may have something to do with the Moodle version or even something to do with the theme. Let us know what version of Moodle you are using. Also, post a few screenshots that show the problem. That being said, I don't think there is any way in the standard Moodle to prevent a teacher from re-grading an essay question that has already been graded. Let's see if others have more ideas for you.

Post title: old questions to 1.6 'missing type'
Post description: Hello from Siena Italy! I've got 1.6 on a new server and have opened clean courses from version 1.43 to the new version.  I found a big problem. The old simple multiple choice quiz questions all show 'missing type' and for the life of me, I can't find an option to select a new multiple choice type for the old questions (100s!).  The edit icon does not show any type menu. Any suggestions? Thanks very much, Linda
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: The reason is that question types used to be stored (in the database and in backup files) as numbers. Now they are stored as names. So all you need to do is to open the backup file in a text editor, and look for where it says something vaguely like <QTYPE>2</QTYPE>, and change that to <QTYPE>multichoice</QTYPE>. Sorry, can't remember exactly what the format is, and I can't be bothered to check. The tag something like <QTYPE>, I can't remember what the old number is, but 'multichoice' is definitely the right name to change it to. Some people were talking to me about restoring 1.4.x backups to 1.6 at the UK MoodleMoot, and I think they said that there were a couple of other bits of the file format that had to be tweaked, but it is all easy to do with a text-editor and search-and-replace, if I remember right.

Comment 4: Actually, we should fix the code so that it just works. After all, if the value in the <qtype> is a number, then that can't possibly make sense in modern Moodle, so we can assume that this is an old backup file, and apply the conversion from the table.
Comment 5: Well, I went to try to fix it, and I found that it had already been done. But for some reason it is not working. Could you attached you Moodle 1.4.x backup file (or email it to me privately), so I can use it for testing?

Comment 10: The backup XML format changes because new features are added, which require new data to be stored, backed up, and restored. When people implement new features they are supposed to ensure that the old backup format is still supported, but if they forget, then it ca be almost impossible for someone else to recover the situation, because that other person can't be sure exactly what changed. Even if you want to start with a clean 1.6.1, you could still use backup and restore to copy your old messed around with 1.4.x version into a clean install of 1.4.x. Then upgrade that clean install to 1.6.1. Then, if you like, use backup and restore to copy that upgraded site into a completely fresh install of 1.6.1. Or, as someone else suggested, go via a 1.5.x version. There were lots of changes to the quiz between 1.5 and 1.6, so it is pretty miraculous that restoring 1.5 backups into 1.6 works. Expecting 1.4 backups straight into 1.6 is clearly too much to expect. Obvously it would be nice if it worked, but if it doesn't and if there are workarounds, then making it work is not the best use of the limited developer time.

Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: Building adaptive quiz question databases: Questions used in adaptive quizzes must be tagged in the question bank with a difficulty score. All questions should be labeled as adpq_n, where n is a positive integer. The range of the scale does not matter. However, each level requires adding items. Forum Post: 
Post title: Remedial quizzes.
Post description: Hi, I am a completely new to Moodle and I am currently doing my due diligence as to whether Moodle is the LMS for us. Our courses are modulised and there is a quiz at the end of each module. The quiz is remedial, so if a learner does not get the correct answer to a question they are immediately taken back to the course slide where they can find the information for the correct answer and they cannot move on to the next module until they get 100% in the previous module. Can Moodle perform this type of quiz? Rgds Graeme
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: Not sure if it can. If you get a new LMS, perhaps better not to try to replicate what you already have. Moodle allows both specific and general feedback on any question so a student can understand why they are wrong. This can be immediate or deferred and is viewed within the quiz. Wouldn't this be sufficient for your students? You can also use activity completion criteria so a quiz pass is required before moving to the next section.
Comment 2: Hello Graeme. You can set up your Moodle quiz so that if a person gets a question wrong the individual feedback for that question links to the place where the correct answer can be found. You can also set it up so that they cannot move onto the next module until they get 100% in the quiz,as James says.
Comment 3: Hi Graeme, If you use a Lesson activity instead of a quiz, you can do exactly what you are wanting. When setting up answers to questions in the lesson activity, you get to select where you jump to for each possible answer. Correct answers would be set to go to the next information or question page, while each wrong answer can be set to loop back to the same page or another page with an explanation of why the answer was wrong and then go ask the question again. When setting up the lesson, Handling of retakes would need to be set to 'Use maximum' so they could eventually wind up with 100%. There is also a plugin, Content pages, (mod_icontent) that lets you present information and ask questions that allows for re-attempting the question if your initial answer is wrong.

In that case, I guess I am in the minority that would rather not have this clever picking up of quiz settings as my quizzes mostly use deferred feedback but for testing immediate feedback is better...

Forum Post: 
Post title: Cannot view quiz!
Post description: I currently have two pilots systems running for a client - both are using the same code base, and the same MySQL (but distinct databases) and were installed at the same time (1.5.3+). Quizes were working on both systems until this weekend. Now on one of them - the one used by a couple of schools - a member was creating a whole load of quizzes when suddenly they do not now appear! you can edit, create and add questions but not view - neither as student or teacher. If you use the "info" tab you get a blank screen and if you are a student you also get a blank screen. Anyone else seen this?
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: Hi John Had something similar to this except it is in the back up and restore of a course that has a quiz section (the only quiz in the whloe database ).  We can enter questions, but cannot view them in the restored course.  The original quatiosn indicated they backed up OK but for what ever reason - will not restore. The only response I got  was that people have backed up and restored many times - in effect saying the issue does not exist. I am very interested to see if you have a solution, as at the moment the quiz module is a liability and one has to use an alternate means of testing participants.
Comment 2: Dear John > in effect saying the issue does not exist I did not mean to suggest that your issue does not exist! Thanks for telling me your Moodle version. Had you been using an unstable development version i would have suggested that the version is the problem. As you are using 1.5.3 I have no idea. I am using 1.5.2 and 1.6 dev and they work very reliably for me, and many thousands of moodle users. That does not deny the existance of your problem but the way you are describing your problem makes it sound like the norm and that in my humble opinion, is far from the case.
Comment 3: Issue solved - it was my fault perhaps for trying to make it too easy for my users! The problem (feature?) was in the config.php file. We wanted to allow users a more memorable URL so we had set up virtual hosts on apache pointing to the same insatallation which works. However in our zeal I edited the config.php as follows $CFG->dbtype = 'xxxxxx'; $CFG->dbhost = 'xxxxxxx'; $CFG->dbname = 'xxxxx'; $CFG->dbuser = 'xxxxx'; $CFG->dbpass = 'xxxxxx'; $CFG->dbpersist = false; $CFG->prefix = 'mdl_'; $CFG-> wwwroot = '/kmoodle'; # this MUST be something like http://hostmame/... $CFG-> dirroot = '/var/www/html/kmoodle'; $CFG-> dataroot = '/var/www/kmoodledata'; $CFG->admin = 'admin'; ... It was the change to $CFG->wwwroot which broke it - it seems that you MUST have a proper, full, http:// URL here for the quiz to work. It appears that other parts of the site worked but I may be wrong as it was not extensively tested. Does anyone know whether this is the case and whether there is a solution? So now, although users can access the site with a friendly name (one different one for each school taking part), once in the URL changes to the generic one - it would be nice to be able to retain the school specific one. If you want to take a look try any of the below - the Guest course allows Guest access. http://web1t.e2bn.net/kmoodle http://thurleston.moodle.e2bn.org/kmoodle/ http://claydon.moodle.e2bn.org/kmoodle/ Thanks.
Comment 4: John, thanks a lot for letting us know the resolution of the problem. This now sounds very much like the issue described at http://moodle.org/mod/forum/discuss.php?d=27794#142217 . The explanations there may hold the answer to whether there is some way for you to keep your nice URLs and still make the pages work.

Forum Post: 
Post title: importing quiz questions from eCollege
Post description: I've been working with Respondus trying to find a way to convert exams retrieved from eCollege into a format that will be recognized by Moodle. Has anyone found a "easy" method of doing this? Thanks
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: Dawn, Can you privately e-mail me an eCollege formatted exam you mention. Bryan
Comment 2: Dawn, Until one of the Moodle developers gets the IMS QTI import working, I would recommend the following for multiple choice questions: In Respondus open your quiz under any of the personalities Click on the Preview & Publish tab Select the "Print Options" side tab Choose "1. Select format: Exam" then "Save to File". Choose "1. Select format: Answer Key only" then "Save to File" under another name. Open up the files in a text editor or word processor. Reformat the "printed" exam to match the "Aiken Format" (See the Moodle Help for details on the format). For other question types,  follow the first five steps to saving the quiz to a file.  Then open the files in a word processor and use "Find and Replace" to reformat the quiz into one of the other available (already developed) file formats.  I use Microsoft Word extensively as I can search and replace formatting charactes such as paragraph marks, line breaks, tabs and spaces. I assume similar operations are available in other word processors. Hope this helps... Cheers,

Post title: Quiz question comments on manually graded questions
Post description: My quiz was all "essay" questions which I have to read to grade. I used the "manual" grading for that, and added additional comments to each question. I don't see how I to allow students to view those comments.
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: After you complete grading, the student should be able to see your feedback by going back to the quiz. Since you mention "comments" instead of feedback, were you using Moodle Comments of some sort/somehow? If they cannot see your feedback, I don't know of anything else to suggest trying. In the future I would suggest that if you want students to answer multiple essay questions, then I would using the Diary plugin. It can be set to help you out by doing some automatic grading, but the teacher can easily override it, and any comments are always visible to the student. You can also set up a Glossary of common errors that gets included as part of the automatic grading. Currently a Diary activity can also be set to give automatic time based writing prompts, which I see as being an enhancement when students work on essays. I have future plans to not only have time released prompts, but to also have performance and teacher released prompts, to allow an individual to go on the the next writing prompt.
Comment 2: Hi, AL Rachels, Thanks for the detailed response. I think I meant feedback and it did work. My confusion was that when I set it to make me look like a student, I didn’t see feedback even though I had teeted the quiz as myself. But there
Comment 3: Yeah, I learned a long time ago to always have another student login name and password for myself as just changing from admin/teacher view over to student view does not always give complete and expected results. I always put him in a group by himself to keep his results away from the real students. Depending on the circumstances, I would enroll and un-enroll him if needed. As you guessed, Diary is a plugin that would need to be added by an admin. https://moodle.org/plugins/mod_diary Please note that even though it says it has Automated testing support, that is undergoing a total rewrite at the moment, and, due to health issues with my eyes it has been going rather slowly. Post title: Using quiz grade items
Post description: I was very excited about this feature and had big plans but am a bit confused... I hadn't realised that a quiz grade item is NOT a gradebook grade item... I want to in some way check the grade a user achieves on each quiz grade item - e.g. they must get 50% on each quiz grade item in order to pass the quiz or course. I was planning on doing this using grade calculations but since they are not grade book grade items it looks like that's not possible... Is there any way to calculate a grade book grade item / course completion / activity completion etc. off a quiz grade item? If not I guess I'll be building a plugin to meet this requirement.
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: I had the same issue, I thought they were separate gradebook items too. That would have been the truly useful functionality I have been looking for. Currently, the only way to have a separate gradebook item is to create each question as a separate quiz.
Comment 2: I already answered Andrew in developer chat, but just repeating here because it is probably good if more people know: This would be great functionality to add. It was not done from the start, because it better to get improvements into Moodle as a series of small steps - and even the basic feature added here had to be quite a big step, so took some time to get in. Before working on this, it might be good to have a chat with someone who knows a bit about the gradebook from a developer's point of view. While it might make sense to start by adding this as a plugin, while we work out what code is required, unlimately, we almost certainly want to add this funcionality to the standard Moodle package.

Post title: Conditional quiz questions
Post description: Hi Moodle users, I am trying to format a question for a quiz in Moodle. It goes something like this: Input a value:_____ If your value is lower than 0.7851 you must choose 'yes' to get the answer correct, or 'no' if the value is higher than 0.7851 to get it correct. I have spent the day digging into the various options, and the STACK questions seem promising, but I haven't got anything to work yet. I am using version 4.4. How would you approach this problem? Any advice here would be greatly appreciated!
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: I am unsure about your exact question type that you want to create, but in your example, a True/False question could be used. As an example, "Calculate the area of a rectangle with sides of 1 and .7851. Is the result greater than .78?" This would have a "true" answer. Moodle does include a few "calculated" question types. I like the Calculated-multichoice type, but you also have "Calculated" and "Calculated simple." Perhaps Dominque will see your post and offer some of his own plugins.

Forum Post: 
Post title: A few questions about the Quiz module
Post description: Hi all, for a new project I have to set up some quizzes and I'm wondering of Moodle can do everything I need it to. For the most part it seems fine but there's a couple of things I can't figure out easily. 1) Is it possible to set up "classification" questions? Similar to matching but more flexible allowing multiple answers to be matched to a single "question". Eg. Standard matching: 1=A, 2=B, 3=C, etc... Classification Matching: 1= A,D and E. 2= B,C, F. 3= H,I,J etc.. 2) Is it possible to set up hierachical decision trees as questions? Furthermore, in addition to being able to display the usual test results, I need to display results/statistics in the following fashion: How many students took the test. How many passed. How many failed.
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: 1) Re: allowing multiple answers to be matched to a single "question" - have you tried using multiple choice questions with multiple answers allowed?  You can set each correct answer to a percentage of the total credit (i.e., choosing the two correct answers worth 50% each gives a student full credit) 2) By hierarchical decision trees , are you picturing that when a student chooses an answer on question one, the next question is based on his answer?  For example: 1. What kind of animal is a cat? a. reptile   b. amphibian     c. mammal - THEN - 2a. What color are its scales? a. green     b. brown     c. yellow - OR - 2b. What kind of skin does it have? a. slimy      b. dry - OR - 2c. How many legs does it walk on? a. two        b. four Or did you have something else in mind?
Comment 2: Re: 1) Multiple choice with multiple answers isn't quite what I'm looking for, I suppose it could do in a pinch though. 2) That's exactly right.
Comment 3: In Moodle 1.7, the matching question has been extended in the way you want. It was not possible before that. Could you give a more specific example of what you mean by a hierachical decision trees as questions? (What would the question look like, What would the student have to do?) Results processing: I don't know about the gradebook. Within a single quiz, there are the various reports under the 'Results' tab. None of them do what you want, but each result is a plugin, so in theory you could write some new ones to do what you want. You could probably cope with the PHP by copying other reports. The hardest part is working out how to get the data you want from the database .
Comment 4: I'm using Moodle 1.7, but I can't see how to set up matching questions with anything but a 1 to 1 match. Is there a setting somewhere I'm missing? Or is this an extension I need to download from somewhere and add. Thanks to both of you for your answers so far.
Comment 5: http://moodle.org/mod/forum/discuss.php?d=50289

Forum Post: 
Post title: System variables in Formulas question types
Post description: Hi, I would like to create a quiz which links together several different formulas type questions, but which would use a common set of randomly generated variables. For instance if I have 3 questions, I might have a variable "a" which is randomly generated for a particular user, but then the same value of "a" is used in all three questions.  Is this possible? Alternatively, is there a way to access system variables (such as User ID) within a formulas question type?  If that is possible, then I can generate ahead of time a series of random variables, and then use the USER ID to select which value to use.... thanks in advance, Mark
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: Moving to Quiz forum...
Comment 2: Hi Mark, With the formula type question, the setup you describe can be done in just one question instead of 3 separate questions. In other words, you can make one question that requires the student to provide multiple answers. I know I have made some questions that required up to a dozen inputs from a student. As for the USER ID, I am not sure. I know that the Generico filter can get you users first and last names which makes it possible to personalize lots of things in Moodle, but I am not sure about it getting the USER ID. If I were to guess, I would say it probably could.
Comment 3: Hi Mark, I agree with Al. No, I far as I know, it is not possible to have the same set of randomly generated variables in different Formulas type questions. I do not know how to access system variables, such as User ID, or if it is readily feasible. However, you should consider using the "Parts" in the Formulas type questions. You can have as many parts as you want. Parts can use the global variables and local variables (displayed with 'Show more'). Parts have their own text and feedback, and can
have multiple answers. They can be thought of as different questions sharing the same random variables. Note that parts can only be displayed on the same page and that they share the same [Check] button. If required, the quiz can be attempted during different sessions, with the same set of random variables, by setting the quiz's 'Attempts allowed' to 3 for example, 'Grading method' to Highest grade, 'Each attempt builds on the last' to Yes and the 'How
questions behave' to Adaptive mode which allows students to check one or more answers at a time.
Comment 4: Hello Mark, Dominique is right, it is not possible to have the same set of randomly generated variables in several questions. But as Dominique pointed out you can have as many parts as you want in one unique formulas question. And I must add that a part is not just an input, a part can have several inputs for instance student can enter all the numbers of a matrix as just the answer to one part of a formulas question. Another advice when the question has several parts is to use the adaptive behaviour because even if the question has one unique "Check" button students can just enter an answer for the first part and use the Check button to test this answer. There will be no penalty for the not yet answered other parts. Also if a student has the same wrong answer to one part for several "Checks" there will not be multiple penalty. You are the first one to ask the ability to access system variables like user ID. Of course it could be done but to be honest I don't think I will be able to find the time to do it. In fact for several months I have not been able to find the time to work on the formulas question type code. My problem is that you can't just say "This afternoon I will work on Formulas", to be productive I need to find some hours during several days to first remind me of the current state of the code, read my notes and my todo list and begin to work, and when something is finished I need to do some tests to verify I have not broken something. This explain why for instance I have not yet been able to work on the feedback problems submitted by Dominique Bauer (Sorry Dominique !). On the contrary I am still working on some Moodle coding smaller tasks that only require a few hours of work, for instance this week I submitted a new feature: export of multichoice questions with Aiken format ( MDL-21904 ) but this is all I can currently do.
Comment 5: I might be a little off-target from what Mark is asking, but I do want to add some ideas that might help. If the question is "Can a set of variables, such as x, y, z, be used across a group of questions?" the answer might be yes.  I say this because this is what I am doing with the Calculated Multichoice question type. For example, if one wants to use two randomly, let's say x and y, which might take on the values 4 and 5, and then ask: For a rectangle with sides of 4 and 5, 1) What is it's area?, 2) What is it's perimeter, and 3) What is it's maximum distance between corners?, this can be done.  All questions would use the values 4 and 5. There are a few qualifiers for what I say. 1) Calculated Multichoice doesn't create the random variables on the fly, you create this "set" of randomly generated variables when you create the question. 2) The questions that are going to use the same set must be in the same question category . Also, the Calculated Multichoice question type takes some study, like 8 hours of experimenting, to start appreciating what it can do. (So Jean-Michel, I can appreciate what you are saying about needing a block of time to get back into an issue.) Having said this, I do want to add that I find this Calculated Multichoice question type to be one of the most powerful "Moodle built-in, supported" question type, meaning that it is not an add-in. Well, hope some of this is helpful. (Actually, I am thinking about giving a presentation at one of this year's MoodleMoots on this topic. Might anyone find this useful?)
Comment 6: Thanks everyone for your comments and suggestions! I wanted to keep the separation between the different questions largely because they were related to specific aspects of an overall problem (i.e the first question was deriving strength parameters for a soil, while the second part was using the strength parameters as inputs into a design problem.  In the end I decided to work around the issue by getting the students to input their values from the previous question as inputs into the different parts of the second question (i.e. the parts of the second question then had multiple answer inputs) and then used the grading variables to code in the correct response. A bit of a faff, which would have been slightly easier I guess within one contained question! Jean-Michel, thanks for developing the formula question type to the state it's in at the moment - I find it generally very useful! Best wishes, Mark

Post title: Student complain about Quiz Questions answered but system didn't save (Moodle 3.0.4)
Post description: Hi all, We have some students who came complaining that they answered essay questions in one exam but Moodle didn't save their answer and got zero for it. I try to understand how the Quiz autosave work.  For example, if the student computer crash what happens to the question student answered? I set the autosave time to be 1 minute and we are using Moodle 3.0.4 Can someone help me understand how the quiz autosave work? Thank you in advance.
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: I can't answer your questions, but I would suggest looking at Moodle's logs to see if you can detect what these students were doing. Maybe someone else can answer your question about how essay questions get autosaved. I don't use essay questions.
Comment 2: Thank you for your help
Comment 3: Was the quiz timed, i.e. did it have a time limit? If so, what happens when time expires?
Comment 4: The quiz is timed. What happened to that student is that there is nothing save on quiz essay question. Not even on the review attempt.
Comment 5: Code is here: https://github.com/moodle/moodle/blob/master/mod/quiz/yui/src/autosave/js/autosave.js and here https://github.com/moodle/moodle/blob/master/mod/quiz/autosave.ajax.php . If you really want to understand what is going on. Anyway, autosave saves teh student's work. Automatically. Every 1 minute. Well strictly speaking, 1 minute after they make any change. It does not bother to save data if nothing has changed recently. If the something crashes, and the student goes back in, then they can continue from the most recently saved data. Data is also saved whenever the student moves to a new page in the quiz (and that has worked since before auto-save was implemented.)
Comment 6: Thank you, I will take a look into the code.
Comment 7: Tim, would I be right in thinking that this is a good reason to have a single question per page. If you have multiple questions and there is a problem with client side auto save the server side save would run less frequently?
Comment 8: I don't understand your question Marcus. The thing is: if the quiz auto-save fails with an error (e.g. because your session has run out) then a warning is displayed on-screen, in an attempt to avoid sudents accedentially losing work. This is one of the reasons the reported symptoms should be impossible. Of course, they are happening, so I must be missing something, and hopefully someone can work out what is really going on here.
Comment 9: I had one student report to me a while ago that an "incorrect" multiple-choice answer was being picked. Then, about a month later, he reported that he solved his problem. I don't know if this is related to the few posts about answers not being autosaved. Here is what the student said: "I was also the one that emailed about possible answers changing with the mouse scroll button. I found out what I was doing wrong. After I would answer a question, I would click off to the right before I would scroll. Well sometimes I was not off of the blue {... Rick colors his region blue} before I clicked so my answer would change."
Comment 10: Yes Rick, using my proctor hat I've seen student do this, or using the down arrow key to scroll the page but instead change option because. It is, I believe, the only way of "moodle changing my given answers". But I also think this issue is unrelated with OP doubt, and I must say We have had the same complaints many times. That's why we do strongly advice 1 question per page, specially on essay questions.
Comment 11: Great to hear this, Hugo. Also, it is not an "all or nothing" situation, meaning "all questions on one page versus one per page." A quiz could have any number of questions per page, such as four or five, whatever seems to make sense. My example above is actually the only student who has reported this to me, over a period of 10 years and 3000 students. However, I use true/false or multiple-choice questions most of the time. Your post makes me wonder more about essay questions.
Comment 12: Hi Guys, i am in the same spot. 5 students at random. is this a plugin issue with the quiz plugin? it started happening at approx the same time. regards, Shpetim Aliaj
Comment 13: Which plugin did you add?
Comment 14: Hi Rick, its the default one. the issue is that the student says that they submitted the quiz/exam and the answers are not saved. it happens randomly. the quiz are 1.2 1.5 hours long and i changed the session.gc_maxlifetime = 14500 a bit bigger then the 4 hours timeout on moodle. the issue is that it is happening at random. we changed the autosave to 1 too. there is a quiz on Saturday on that course and will see the outcome but it looks like this is a problem with the quiz plugin. is anyway to force the student to save the quiz every minute? regards, Shpetim Aliaj
Comment 15: they did not say about any errors on quiz page so it looks like something is failing internally. the resources on moodle are good pcu idle is >96% and ram utilization OK less then 1/2 memory. regards, Shpetim Aliaj
Comment 16: cron is setup every 2min
Comment 17: Have you thought about upgrading? 3.0.4 is a very old version...
Comment 18: Sorry for the misunderstanding we are still at 3.6.x and moving to 3.9.x but this seems to be logic issue. There has to be a mechanism to force the browser to update the data students enter on quiz, as currently they say its not their fault,  server side its not the fault if there is a timeout or connection drop from students or browser issues. Pretty difficult situation that this times are amplifying. regards, Shpetim Aliaj
Comment 19: Well if there is a connection drop then that is tough. Are all the questions on one page? I thought the quiz did autosave now but it might be when switching pages maybe?
Comment 20: We are planning to upgrade the Moodle at either the end of this year or early next year. Thanks!!
Comment 21: My logic was that with one question per page, the student responses will be written back to the server more frequently than if there are multiple questions per page.
Comment 22: True. In combination with the Settings > Timing: When question expires set to Open attempts are submitted automatically , one could set a fairly tolerant exam. That was how it used to be. Now I see an additional mechanism auto saving work, even unsaved forum posts. Due to this the quiz has become even more tolerant, I believe. I am still not often enough in release 3.9 to confirm the exact behaviour of  its quizzes.

Post title: Moodle 1.6.5 Moodle XML Import FIX for Short Answer Question Errors
Post description: Hi All, I'm posting this in case any one else is having this same problem. I don't know if this has been resolved (or is even an issue) in newer versions, but this is what is happening in version 1.6.5 for us. ERRORS ON SHORT ANSWER QUESTIONS - HOW TO FIX XML FILE The Moodle XML file is reporting errors on short answer question imports. It will state in the import dialog that there was no matching grade for this question type. Here's how you fix this: First, delete ALL of the questions you just imported from the question bank (that category that you just imported questions into).

Post title: Adaptive mode
Post description: I am so sure this question has been raised, but I have not seen it yet when I search for it. The adaptive mode is not working in the way I assumed it would. It appears to calculate the penalties based on the question's total marks. So a 3 mark question (with 33% penalties) has -1, -2 applied at try 2 and 3 respectively. The problem is when you have partial marks coded. So I have one example where a student, on her 3rd try, got an answer that would have scored 2/3 if she gave it on her 1st try. The penalty though meant she scored 0, even though she actually worked out a 'valid' answer. My original thought was that the adaptive mode would give 2/3 - 66%, which is 0.68/3. This was important for her, as it was the difference between a pass and fail on her paper. I've had this on other questions. I had a whopper 13 mark 'Moodle formulas' question in adaptive mode that did not work as I thought at all. If the student got, say 5/13 on the first try, then fixed questions so that they would get 10/13, the score became 5.71/13 and not what I would expect 6.7/13. So this is clearly something that is coded into the core and can't just change, so I wonder what my options are moving forward? Is there some other plugin that does what I am thinking? Maybe my thinking is wrong? Maybe students should be penalised in the way it is happening? What I wonder is whether the adaptive mode was considered initially for simple pass/fail answers, and not partial grading which the calculation questions and pattern-match question types afford students. kind regards Gareth
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: Which question type is that?
Comment 2: It is not a question type but a quiz behaviour Joseph - it applies to all question-types.
Comment 3: Sorry, but it does depend on the question type. You wrote "So a 3 mark question (with 33% penalties) has -1, -2 applied at try 2
and 3 respectively. The problem is when you have partial marks coded. So
I have one example where a student, on her 3rd try, got an answer that
would have scored 2/3 if she gave it on her 1st try. The penalty though
meant she scored 0, even though she actually worked out a 'valid'
answer. My original thought was that the adaptive mode would give 2/3 -
66%, which is 0.68/3." Please export that question and attach it to your next post so I can try it out.
Comment 4: The way you observe adaptive mode working is the way it is intended to work. I think adaptive mode was initially considered for 'Assessment for learning' rather than 'Assessment of learning'. If you are focussing on that, then you are more interested in the process the student goes through, and their ability to learn from feedback, than the exact details of the scoring algorithm.. Still, a reasonable and self-consistent scoring scheme was devised and implemented. If need an option to change this, then you can use the fact that question behaviours are plugins. You could make your won behaviour plugin, which implements a different scoring algorithm. (Hopefully, you can do it be subclassing standard adaptive behaviour, to minimise the amount of code you need to write.)
Comment 5: Hello Gareth, I had a whopper 13 mark 'Moodle formulas' question in adaptive mode that did not work as I thought at all. I remember having the same kind of thoughts about scoring in adaptive mode. However, I use the Formulas question a lot in adaptive mode and eventually I think the scoring works the way I want. I think maybe it depends on how the parameters are set. Tim Hunt is responsible for the "Adaptive mode (multi-part questions)" plugin. This plugin is required for the Formulas question to work. If I understood correctly, it is quite complex. Everyone who uses the Formulas question is indebted to Tim Hunt for his outstanding work on his "Adaptive mode (multi-part questions)" plugin. I'm just guessing his suggestion to write your own plugin stems from the fact that he seems to view any question about his plugin as a criticism rather than a naïve question. Of course, you can always write a new plugin, but I guess that's not exactly the answer you were expecting. If you'd like, I could help you try to clarify how the Formulas question scoring works in adaptive mode. But I'll have to get back to you a little later, because if I don't take care today of the things my wife asked me to do, I might... oops I have to go!
Comment 6: I think that is a wrong guess. Knowing what is, or is not, possible to do with plugins is not necessarily obvious until you have a lot of experience with how Moodle works, so I tend to feel it is worth pointing out when it is possible. Of course, creating new plugins requires having (or hiring) certain skills, so it is not the most immediately useful advice, but I still think it is worth being aware what is possible. (And, if you come from a background of closed source software, the extent to which Moodle can be customised with plugins might not be something you realise.) Also, I had failed to connect the points in this thread. If this is using Formulas (and hence Adaptive multi-part, rather than just Adaptive), then making a custom version of the behaviour would be non-trivial (and that is an understatement!)
Comment 7: Dear Tim and Dominique, Thank you both for your responses - I (or I should say we if I include my colleagues) are deeply indebted to your work on Moodle. I find myself in the unenviable position of being a 'power' end-user, but a programming noob. This means I MacGyver things together and spend time finding out what is available to do what I want, but in reality I'm like a guy in a wheelchair watching a game of Rugby for the first time and wishing I could play, even though I do not even know the rules. I'm clearly also not an English major and my metaphors could use some work. thanks to both of you! Gareth ps - maybe one day I can join you on the field as equals - I really do want to be able to play and not just watch
Comment 8: Hello Gareth, I'm sorry for the late reply, I've been busy a bit longer than expected. Adaptive mode itself works well, at least it follows simple logic. Suppose the students have three tries. They get 100% on the first try, 66% on the second, 33% on the third and 0% on all subsequent tries, or 1, 0.66, 0.33 and 0 point for a question worth 1 point. The scoring of the Formulas question depends on how you organize sub-questions. If several sub-questions are in the same part, a zero mark is attributed as soon as one answer is incorrect. It's an all-or-nothing kind of behaviour. If the sub-questions are in different parts, the score awarded is the sum of the scores for each part, which are awarded according to the adaptive mode rule. It is important to tell students to modify their answers only if they intend to immediately check them. For example, if students clear an incorrect answer and click the Check button, they lose a try (say 33%) on that sub-question because an empty answer box is interpreted as an incorrect answer. If the student got, say 5/13 on the first try, then fixed questions so that they would get 10/13, the score became 5.71/13 and not what I would expect 6.7/13. Suppose the penalty is 33% per try, and students have answered all questions and clicked the Check button. If they got 5 correct answers, they will have accumulated 5 points. Note in passing that the accumulated points can never decrease. If they change their answers, click the Check button and have 5 more correct answers, their score will be 5x1 (first try) + 5*0.66 (second try) = 8.33, not 5.71 or 6 ,7. Overall, it works pretty well. Feel free to ask further questions if my answer is not clear.

Post title: Bank of random questions. Can I change the minimum of 4 questions in a question bank for a random question?
Post description: Hi. I'm administrating a moodle platform that was poorly designed. The way it worked before showed repeated questions to students, and now at least I was able to low the chances of a question to be shown twice to the same student. I'll explain the problem briefly: I have a bank of 20 questions, the system is supposed to show 5 random questions to students (there should be 25 questions to be able to use 5 random questions that have 0 chances of being repeated, but I don't have that amount). The old administrator just did 5 questions from the same 20, which is the worse that what I thought (once it was explained to me by my boss how it works now and has worked for years now, I said "we might have a problem here"): I divided the 20 questions in 5 groups of 4 (where the intersection between each bank is empty) and was expecting it to work great, but it didn't, since each random question requires at least a bank of 5 questions. so 4 banks of 5 questions where the intersection of those is empty and one bank of the 20 questions seems a little better since the probability of getting the same question twice is now lower, I still don't like it one bit. Can I lower the minimum of questions to 4 in the configuration? I wasn't able to find it yet. Another option would be to use the same bank but to remove the question that was asked every time a question is made, but of course this seems unnecessary since the problem would be solved being able to tweek that. Thanks a lot!
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: Hi Gastón, I think the simplest thing to do would be to create five more questions. It might help to know what subject the questions are supposed to cover as it might help with recommendations of what to do.
Comment 2: Hi, Al. Creating 5 more questions is not easier at least to me than just changing a value on a configuration file 😊 But if that was a possibility I wouldn't have made the question in the first place, but maybe I should have clarified in my subject: "there are only 20 questions for each of 5 courses",and those are it... anyways, it doesn't make a lot of sense to me that it requires 5 questions from a question bank. Maybe the system is smart enough to remove the questions that it has already shown, but I highly doubt it, since I checked and saw repeated questions, but that could be another problem... I don't know.
Comment 3: Hi Gastón, So far as I know, there is NOT a configuration file that controls that. I do know that before I retired, I made sure all my question banks had at least 30 questions each. I created practice quizzes that randomly would select five questions and my students and I never saw a question get repeated for a student until they had seen all the questions once. Sorry, I can't be of more help.
Comment 4: Hi Al, thanks for replying back. Can you please tell me if this 30 questions banks were all the same for different questions? Let's say you have a page with 5 random questions... do those questions use the same bank? I'm currently trying to explain what I did to solve the problem, first I have to find an intelligible set of words for that and sort them correctly xD
Comment 5: I finally figured it out! the final questionnaire has to have 25 random questions from a bank of 100 questions! The first thing I did was to create 5 pages of 5 random questions each... That wouldn't be a problem if I didn't have to test a couple of things, what I did for that was to create a bank of x questions, I don't remember how many and the bank of questions for all the 25 questions was the same... it happened to be that when I created a second or third bank of a few questions of the same subject (thinking that if the intersection between n banks of questions is not empty then questions may be repeated to the same student). So when I read in another thread that a bank of 1 or 2 questions could be legible for a random question I realized I was doing something wrong with my random questions and then it hit me... I was using like 5 random questions with a bank of 4 questions and then they would definitely be repeated... dividing the 20 questions in 5 banks of 4 questions wasn't a bad idea after all, since I couldn't find information of people saying that the questions wouldn't be repeated, but the fact that I had this problem tells me that probably moodle is smart enough to demand for more questions in a question bank than random questions, hence, checking before actually attempting and knowing that they would definitely repeat themselves if having less questions in the question bank than random questions feeding from it.

Post title: antilog and pH
Post description: I apologize for my "noobie" question.  I've been using Moodle for my chemistry students.  We are currently going over Acids, Bases, and pH.  For the pH calculations, I have no problem of converting the concentration to pH (using the log10 calculation), but I'm having difficulties reversing the calculation (using antilog, [H3O+]=10^-pH).
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: In many Moodle plugins , "log" is natural log.  When it is: pH = log(H3O+)/log(10) You can check it works by doing 10^pH.  Some plugins prefer something like power(10,pH). You need to see the documentation for the specific plugin.

Forum Post: 
Post title: Multiple correct answers in Formulas
Post description: A question in the addon Formulas asks for the mass of the condensed water. Strictly mathematically, the answer is a negative number (because from the air perspective the mass of water vapour has decreased), but I would like the same positive number to be accepted as well. Is there a way for two different answers, say m and -m, to be accepted as correct in the same input field?
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: Marko, Yes, there is a simple way. For any given part, given: (Ref: https://dynamiccourseware.org/course/view.php?id=22&section=17#tdm_20200320_2354➚ ) _a : target answers _r : student answers The question automatically calculates the following: _d = diff(_a,_r) : differences between elements of _a and _r _err = sqrt(sum(map("*",_d,_d))) : absolute error _relerr = _err/sqrt(sum(map("*",_a,_a))) : relative error In "Simplified mode", the question suggests the following grading criteria: Relative error     == or <     some specified value, for example 0.01 (i.e. 1%) or
Comment 2: Thanks. In the end what I used was r = map("abs",_r); a = map("abs",_a); d = diff(a, r); err = sqrt(sum(map("*",d,d))); relerr = err/sqrt(sum(map("*",_a,_a)));

Post title: Question Banks - Textbook Publishers
Post description: Hello, I am using Moodle 3.4.2+ (Build: 20180502) . I was wondering if I could format test banks from a textbook publisher (linked below) to upload in Moodle. When I tried uploading these banks, I got an error message that the format was incorrect. I would really appreciated the help so I do not have to typed all these questions in manually. Best. Mike Helmick
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: Hi Mike Many textbook publishers will provide test bank questions that you can import/export into the Moodle environment. I would first look for those resources as it will save you a lot of time! Here is more about the importing of questions. If you need to do it question by question, you need to convert to a GIFT format prior to uploading. See more about that here .
Comment 2: Mike, I've done this quite a lot (1000s of questions) and have found that one of the most effective ways to work with publisher test banks if they cannot be exported in a Moodle format is simply to re-format them as GIFT . It's easy to use, friendly syntax that any text editor can assist with. You can even add categorization and feedback. It's our go-to at StraighterLine.

Post title: Algebra expression validator for calculated questions
Post description: Dear experts, I am looking for some algebra expression validator for calculated questions. Sometimes I get too complicated expression with many parenthesis, and it's quite difficult to sort it out. Thanks, Miro
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: As I have checked,  notepad++  helpful editor, which validates parentheses in algebraic expressions.
Comment 2: Hello Miro Not sure if this link will help, it has been very useful to me to see if my algebra expressions work and are compatible with moodle: https://www.mathjax.org/ The live demo is where I try and test my expressions
Comment 3: Hello, thanks for the hint, but it did not help. I need editor which controls parentheses, and notepad++ works well for that. Example of the complicated expression for one of my calculated questions: 
```text
(4844/(7.55-log10(((1000*{p})/101325)*((4*(({n0A}-{nrA})/{n0A})*(({n0A}-{nrA})/{n0A})*(({n0A}-{nrA})/{n0A})*{n0A}*{n0A})/(({n0A}+{n0B}+(({n0A}-{nrA})/{n0A})*{n0A})*(1-(({n0A}-{nrA})/{n0A}))*({n0B}-{n0A}*(({n0A}-{nrA})/{n0A})))))))-273.15
```
 But anyhow, if someone could advice online editor checking parentheses in algaebraic expressions, I would be glad.
Comment 4: You may find formulas question type useful if you site admin can install it ( https://moodle.org/plugins/qtype_formulas ). You can just split the equation in any logical part as you like, and it is just like normal programming. For example: frac = (n0A-nrA)/n0A; ans = (4844/(7.55-log10(((1000*p)/101325)*((4*pow(frac,3)*n0A*n0A)/((n0A+n0B+frac*n0A)*(1-frac)*(n0B-n0A*frac))))))-273.15 No curly bracket is requred
Comment 5: Thanks for your hint, but: https://moodle.org/plugins/qtype_formulas is for Moodle 2.7, 2.8, 2.9, 3.0 ... and we have 3.1, 3.2...
Comment 6: According our experience, Formulas is working fine with Moodle 3.2.2+ It seems that plugin info has not been updated.
Comment 7: Hi, thanks, that is nice; but according to our Moodle maintenance policy, the plugin has to have clear info about Moodle version to be approved for the installation by admin. I  (we) need fully functional plugin to ease the work with calculated questions.

Forum Post: 
Post title: Something for TIM HUNT
Post description: Hi Tim Please allow me to draw your attention to this conversation http://moodle.org/mod/forum/discuss.php?d=55792 Once you have seen this post you'd appreciate that the following lines are an exce rpt from moodle help file for gift format Feedback: Feedback can be included for each answer by
following the answer with a number sign (# also known as a hash mark)
and the feedback. 
```text
     What's the answer to this multiple-choice question?{


     ~wrong answer#feedback comment on the wrong answer


     ~another wrong answer#feedback comment on this wrong answer


     =right answer#Very good!}


     


     Who's buried in Grant's tomb?{
```
 For Multiple Choice questions, feedback is displayed only for the answer the student selected. For short answer, feedback is shown only when students input the corresponding correct answer. For true-false questions, the imported feedback is saved so that it will display if the student chose the wrong answer.
So, in the last example above, the student would see the feedback only if they selected TRUE as their answer.
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: Actually, it is Howard that look after the import and export code. Hoefully he will see this. If you want to make sure, please file a bug in the tracker. And if you want to make it easy for us, please suggest exactly what the new version of the help should say, so we can just copy and paste it. Thanks.

Forum Post: 
Post title: Is it possible to make sections in quiz
Post description: I need to make different sections in quiz like I have a quiz which has 2 different sections 1. The Web - Terminology & Definitions 2. About Search Engines what i want to do is that when The Web section ends, the user can check his score for this section and can continue to the another section which is About Search Engines. And both sections score will be generate a single report for the whole test. Is it possible with the quiz module of moodle.
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: > Is it possible with the quiz module of moodle. No it isn't.
Comment 2: Then there is any other module or option to do so.
Comment 3: Hello all, I too would appreciate a "sub-quiz" -feature a lot! At our University we'd like to be able to calculate sub-results for certain quizzes but still use only one quiz. Really awesome it would be if the sub-results could be fetched also to the gradebook. :D
Comment 4: No argument from me, this is a very desirable feature. It is just a big change, so it is not going to happen until someone has the time and motivation to do it. The new gradebook in Moodle 1.9 lets an activity in Moodle report several scores against several different learning outcomes. So the required change is to extend the quiz to let it do that. The steps involved would be: 1. Work out a new quiz editing interface, so when a quiz is created, you can say this question counts towards this score axis - and do this in a way that does not make the interface impossibly complicated. 2. Change the database structure, so that the new information about the structure of the quiz and the students scores can be stored. 3. Change every place where scores are displayed to display the extra information in an appropriate way. The hard thing here is working out a user interface that is usable.
Comment 5: How about using the " lesson " module? I think this module does show your current score as you move along

Forum Post: 
Post title: Quiz attempts and results not showing
Post description: I am using  Moodle 1.8.3.  Recently I gave a quiz in one of the courses but its results are not showing.  When I check the reports(logs) I can see entries of attempts by the students.  Students can see their scores.  But I ( teacher) don't see any attempts against this quiz.  What is even more strange is that I used the same questions ( by sharing the categories) to give a quiz to another course of mine and everything worked fine there.  I compared the quiz and course settings of these two courses and made sure that they are same.  I am not very new to Moodlle and I have given quizzes earlier.  This is the first time I am experiencing something like this.  Can anyone help ?
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: I have noted one difference between the two courses. In the course where it failed to show results and attempts, all the student accounts were cretaed before the upgrade to 1.8. ( In the other one, where it worked fine, the student accounts were created after the upgrade). I looked at the logs ( reports) and clicked on "quiz close attempt" entries. The result was "No such attempt ID exists " error message in most of the cases and in one case I saw the answers and the score of the student.
Comment 2: Are you sure that the upgrade did not encounter any problems? Recent versions of Moodle log all the upgrade output into moodledata/upgradelogs. I am not sure if 1.8.3 is recent enough, but if it is, can you check.
Comment 3: My Moodle server is hosted and maintained by another institute and I am accessing it via internet. My administrator had told me about several problems they had encountered while upgrading. One problem was that the old courses were not available after the upgrade. I do not know how they solved it. Before the upgrade I had once faced a problem with the quiz and I reported it here . This course has all those students ( plus two more students; even their quiz attempts were not shown) . I know this is rather strange; I am considering deleting all these user accounts and the course and launching one afresh with new student accounts.

Post title: Calculated questions mod -> dependencies in questions
Post description: Hi, I'm dessigning a modification for the quiz module in order to extend a bit the functionality of the calculated questions part. The idea is that a calculated question can be dependant of previously answered question (also a calculated one). For example: This question is answered with: a = b + c This question is answered with: d = a + c As you can see, the second question result is dependant of the "a" value that the student got at question 1. So this value must be stored and carried among the entrie quiz. I would like to ask dev people for some basic guidelines of the best way of implement this mod on the quiz module (files to mod, data structures to use, database usage, etc...). Every suggestion would be welcome. Greets!

Forum Post: 
Post title: Managing large banks of tests.
Post description: We are using Moodle for administering lab test for out first year french courses. We have up to 15 sections of the same class, which means they have the same tests.  I'm using question banks and randomization to ensure seperate tests for every student, but sometimes the dates of the tests change. Is there anyway to set the dates of several activities at once?  Quizzes, or assignments? Also, is there a way to make one test, and then put it in all of the courses?  I know I can copy material from one course to another, but that is a slower process, and I haven't tested it much.  I know for a fact that it doesn't copy the labels for the topics....and for 15 sections, that is a pain. Thanks for any help. Thomas
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: Hi Thomas, You should take a look at the Course Program block . This will allow you to specify dates from a central window by course.
Comment 2: Right now I am the IT person, but I'm also centrally managing the tests and activities.  But I only work here 8 hours a week, so not much time to get things working. I'll take a look at the Course Block, it looks promising.  Copying tests and quizzes from a fake "Test Course" that I have created to all the individual sections also seems to work pretty well....providing the dates don't change after I copy. ;) Thanks for the help.

Forum Post: 
Post title: Viewing/Reviewing a Quiz Without Having Taken it?
Post description: A student joined my full-year course in mid-year.  I told all students they can review (for the final exam) by looking at all the quizzes (which I have set to expose all Responses Scores Feedback Answers after the quiz is closed). However, this new student cannot see anything, because she never took the quiz in the first place! As a temporary measure, I disabled the quiz-close-date, let her "take" the quiz by simply starting it, then clicking Submit.    Then I re-enable the original close-date, and she can see the answers. But is there a more elegant way to allow students to see quiz questions and answers even after it's closed?
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: There is no way to do exactly what you want, but why not make some new revision quizzes using the same questions, but set to have immediately feedback and let the students answer each question as often as they want. That way the can revise by actually doing the questions, rather than just passively reading.

Post title: How can a student point out a faulty question
Post description: How can I allow the students to ask me to revise a given question in a quiz? I used to have that activity after each quiz but I'm no longer able to reproduce it. There was a list of all requests, with a link that would take me to that particular question and from there, there was the possibility to edit the original question. That request had its own opening and closing dates, but it was somehow connected to the quiz. Right now, all I can do is to create another activity where the students can indeed post their requests, but there will be no link to the particular question for that particular student -- which is a big deal, since the question might be faulty for the particular values of the joker that student had. I have to open another browser tab with the results from the quiz and look for each student. Thanks in advance!
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: My students select the Flag icon on the question while taking the quiz. When a course/quiz is launched for training I review the Quiz>Results>Response report to see if there were any question that have a high incorrect responses. In that view the Flagged Questions are displayed with a little red flag. When ever I see the red flag I reach out to the student and ask them for their feedback/concerns. Kind Regards.
Comment 2: Shirley, Thanks for the prompt answer. I've seen the red flag, but my students usually ask for a regrade only after they have access to the right answers, which happens only after the quiz is closed. I'm looking for something they can do after that, and that can take me directly to their question (with the particular values for the jokers, etc.), since there may be a problem with those values. Best, Sergio
