Forum Post: Post title: Quiz Score Breakdown by Category Post description: Hello everyone. I asked a while ago about by-category score details for quizzes and saw that many other people wanted this as well. Anyway, I made a quick way to do it that: gives you the option to show the score details to the user for each category in the quiz in the order the category appears in the quiz works with multiple-page quizzes can easily be tweaked in format and content If anyone's interested, give it a try and let me know what you think. It should also work in moodle 1.7, but I have not tested thoroughly in later versions. Hope you don't mind the big post. A zipped pdf of the instructions is attached as well. Adding Question Category Grade Breakdown for Quizzes in Moodle 1.6.2 Add a new column showcategorygrades to the quiz table. This will be used to make the category grade breakdown optional. ALTER TABLE mdl_quiz ADD COLUMN showcategorygrades int2; ALTER TABLE mdl_quiz ALTER COLUMN showcategorygrades SET STORAGE PLAIN; ALTER TABLE mdl_quiz ALTER COLUMN showcategorygrades SET DEFAULT 0; Add the following lines to quiz/config.html html to show the control for toggling the showcategorygrades property when configuring quizzes in your moodle . // SRC: Set the category grade control if it is not set Add the following lines to quiz/mod.html to show the control for toggling the showcategorygrades property when editing a quiz. // SRC: Set the category grade control if it is not set if (!isset($form->showcategorygrades)) { $form->showcategorygrades = $CFG->quiz_showcategorygrades; } … quiz_fix_decimalpoints) { ?> : showcategorygrades, ""); helpbutton("showcategorygrades", get_string("showcategorygrades", "quiz"), "quiz"); ?> Add the following line to lang/en-UTF8/quiz.php. This is the English translation for the control label in the forms you edited in steps 2 and 3. $string [ 'showcategorygrades' ] = 'Show category grades' ; Add the following lines to quiz/review.php. This is what will actually show the category grade breakdown in the quiz report. // SRC: Add categories string for breakdown section label $strcategories = get_string( "categories" , "quiz" ); // SRC: Load all the questions for the category breakdown if report is paginated if (! $showall && $quiz ->showcategorygrades == 1) { $allquizquestionids = quiz_questions_in_quiz( $attempt ->layout); $ sql = "SELECT q.*, i.grade AS maxgrade, i.id AS instance" . " FROM { $CFG->prefix }question q," . " { $CFG->prefix }quiz_question_instances i" . " WHERE i.quiz = ' $quiz->id ' AND q.id = i.question" . " AND q.id IN ( $allquizquestionids )" ; if (! $allquestions = get_records_sql( $sql )) { error( 'No questions found' ); } // Load the question type specific information if (!get_question_options( $allquestions )) { error( 'Could not load question options' ); } // Restore the question sessions to their most recent states // creating new sessions where required if (! $allstates = get_question_states( $allquestions , $quiz , $attempt )) { error( 'Could not restore question sessions' ); } } if ( $showall && $quiz ->showcategorygrades == 1) { $allquestions = $questions ; $allstates = $states ; } … // SRC: Category breakdown if it is enabled. if ( $quiz ->showcategorygrades == 1) { $categorybreakdown = array (); $gradescale = $quiz ->grade/ $quiz ->sumgrades; foreach ( $allquestions as $question ) { if (! isset ( $categorybreakdown [ $question ->category])) { $categorybreakdown [ $question ->category] = array (); $questioncategory = get_record( 'question_categories' , 'id' , $question ->category); $categorybreakdown [ $question ->category][ "categoryname" ] = $questioncategory ->name; $categorybreakdown [ $question ->category][ "maxgrade" ] = 0; $categorybreakdown [ $question ->category][ "scaledmaxgrade" ] = 0; $categorybreakdown [ $question ->category][ "rawgrade" ] = 0; $categorybreakdown [ $question ->category][ "scaledrawgrade" ] = 0; $categorybreakdown [ $question ->category][ "grade" ] = 0; $categorybreakdown [ $question ->category][ "scaledgrade" ] = 0; } $categorybreakdown [ $question ->category][ "maxgrade" ] += $question ->maxgrade; $categorybreakdown [ $question ->category][ "scaledmaxgrade" ] += $question ->maxgrade* $gradescale ; $categorybreakdown [ $question ->category][ "rawgrade" ] += $allstates [ $question ->id]->raw_grade; $categorybreakdown [ $question ->category][ "scaledrawgrade" ] += $allstates [ $question ->id]->raw_grade* $gradescale ; $categorybreakdown [ $question ->category][ "grade" ] += $allstates [ $question ->id]->grade; $categorybreakdown [ $question ->category][ "scaledgrade" ] += $allstates [ $question ->id]->grade* $gradescale ; } $cattable ->align = array ( "right" , "left" ); foreach ( $categorybreakdown as $catinfo ) { $categorypercentage = round (( $catinfo [ "rawgrade" ]/ $catinfo [ "maxgrade" ])*100,0); $cattable ->data[] = array ( $catinfo [ "categoryname" ], round ( $catinfo [ "scaledgrade" ], $CFG ->quiz_decimalpoints). "/" . round ( $catinfo [ "scaledmaxgrade" ], $CFG ->quiz_decimalpoints). " (" . $categorypercentage . "%)" ); } } … // SRC: Print category breakdown if ( $cattable ) { echo '
' . $strcategories . '
' ; print_table( $cattable ); } Create a new file in \lang\en_utf8\help\quiz named showcategorygrades.html. This is the help file for this setting.

Show Category Grades

If you enable this option, a question category grade breakdown will be displayed on the quiz results page.

Categories will be listed in the order they appear in the quiz.

The intention is to provide students with more detailed feedback regarding their quiz performance.

Post title: Subnet Limitation
Post description: Currently, subnet is defined as a varchar 255 for quizzes.  In my use case, I need to extend that to a varchar 2,000, which I hope will be enough to acommodate our campuses, but with continued growth, it may not.  My question is two fold: 1. If I change the structure of variable in the database to a varchar(2000), will it break anything else?  (Which includes the weekly builds we implement from Moodle 3.3 STABLE branch) 2. Does the form in the quiz where we set the subnet from have an input limitation which is coded other than from the definition of the field size set in the database. Any answers from the development side would be greatly appreciated, as I am currently at 247 characters, and still need to add additional campuses, so have had to begin reducing security to entirely too many IP addresses.  ie. instead of 1.2.3.4, I have had to implement 1.2.3. just to cover what we have, and additional IP addresses are coming online as our needs grow.
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: I think just changing the size of the column in your database should be safe. I can't think of anything that would go wrong. I don't think browser limit text input boxes.
Comment 2: Thank you for the response.  PHP does allow a limit to be placed on the size of an input field, but it is usually put in place to avoid breaking something like these types of limits.  I hope fingers crossed that expanding the size of the field does not cause issues, but I am not sure where else to ask, and I do know you answer a LOT of questions on here, so I will have faith that this will resolve my issue without creating new ones. As an aside, would I be safer to request an improvement in tracker to be certain it would not cause issues, or is it a try and hope for the best by making the change and seeing if anything goes wrong?
Comment 3: I agree with Tim that it is unlikely to cause a problem.

Forum Post: 
Post title: Duplicating a course with questions saved at the wrong level
Post description: I'm using Moodle 2.7.1 A teacher has created a new course with about 50 quizzes and over 300 questions. But, she has saved all the questions to the course level question bank. We now want to duplicate the course and the backup and restore files are of course huge. I can move all the questions to a system level question bank.  But if I go to the course, they all still appear to be in the original question bank at course level. In future, we will be careful to add questions from the system level course bank, but is there an easier way to solve this problem now, other than going through and editing every question?
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: Actually moving the questions to the system level will make the issue worse, not better.  With the current design, when the quiz is included in a course backup it includes the entire question bank up to the system level.  This means that if you move all the questions to the system level, they will now be included in every course backup that has a quiz regardless of whether the questions are used in that course or not. If you want to avoid huge course backups, then keep all your questions at the course level. However, I would also advise you to upgrade as overall Moodle performance has improved greatly and we are not seeing near the issues with backups as we used to.

Forum Post: 
Post title: Page Break
Post description: Hi all, I'm facing a problem with page break in Moodle quiz. I created quiz with 30 questions with the Shuffle checked. Then I decided to have the page break after question #20. I want to do this due to a number of reasons. I don't want to use random questions because I want to be easier to track the questions on Statistic. I know that there is a Repaginate. However, Repaginate only allow to break the page in even number of questions per page. In this case, I have different questions per page. And even I used Repaginate, the page break is also not working when the Shuffle is ON. I think I used this before and it works before because I created this quiz since we were on MOODLE 3.2. Now we are on MOODLE 3.3 and I go back and found this issue. My question is How do I have a page break working with the Shuffle ON? Please help, Thank.
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: You probably need to split the quiz into two sections . (Which version of Moodle are you using?)
Comment 2: Hi Tim, I'm using 3.3 right now. I can split it into 2 sections, however, the shuffle can only be shuffle from questions in that section. For example, I have Section 1: question 1-20;  Section 2: Question 21-30 So from section one any question from 21-30 can not be shuffled in the section 1 and versa. What I meant to do is to have all 30 question shuffle randomly and since 30 questions gonna make the page is too long, I want to have a page break within 1 section. The problem that I recognized here is the Shuffle feature make the page break be disable. It wasn't like this before.
Comment 3: It is probably not very obvious, but in a section that is shuffled, the page breaks are controlled by the setting Layout -> New page [ever X questions] in the Quiz settings.
Comment 4: Thank Tim, That's mean that I can't set up the quiz the way I want.  It's just not possible now. Right?
Comment 5: A way around it might be to create subcategories with the questions you want on each page and then use the random question to select all questions in the subcategory. Page 1 pulls 20 random questions from subcategory 1 which only has the 20 questions in it that you want. Page 2 pulls 10 random questions from subcategory 2 which only has the 10 question in it that you want.
Comment 6: Hi Emma, I thought about that. However, I really want to avoid random question due to responses tracking. There are limitations on tracking student response using Random question. Anyway, I really appreciate your help. Thank you!!
Comment 7: I think what Tim is saying is that you "can" add page breaks.  (Sorry to speak for you Tim, especially if I am not interpreting what you are saying correctly.)
Comment 8: Wrong: I told you that you can set up the quiz exactly the way you want (once I had understood what that was). As I understand it, you want a quiz with 30 fixed questions, in a random order, with a page-break after question 20. Right, so make a quiz with 1 section. Add the 30 questions. Turn on shuffle. In the quiz settings, under Layout, set New page every 20 questions.
Comment 9: The Moodle quizzing engine is without a doubt the best quizzing engine of any major LMS.  Flexibility in setting up the appearance of a quiz is just one of many great features.
Comment 10: I totally agree that Moodle is the best LMS.

Forum Post: 
Post title: Display item ID # on Quiz Edit page
Post description: I notice that when I preview a quiz, the numerical item ID is shown in small text alongside the question number.  For me, this is a much-appreciated feature.  Is there is a way to also display that number with the question on the regular quiz edit page, both on the left side (quiz content) and on the right (item bank content)? Thanks, Jim.
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: That would of course be easy to do. The only reason it is not done is that it would clutter up the page even more. The general way Moodle works is that it hides its internal IDs from users. So I was surprised when Martin started printing the ID number on the quiz preview. What do you use that information for? You can already get at the id number by hovering over the edit icon and looking at the URL that is then displayed in the status bar (all the way at the bottom of the browser). A compromise might be to put the id number into the lable for the edit icon so that when you hover over it the little tooltip says "Edit #11" rather than just "Edit".
Comment 2: Hi Gustav, Its an organization issue I suppose.  The item ID is the "true identity" of the question.  The number in the quiz is a temporary alias.  The title (usually the content) of the question works as an identifier if the questions have titles or are dissimilar in wording and you wrote them.  In my case I am tasked with creating item banks and quizzes for anyone who needs help (which right now is everyone).  My first item bank (2 weeks ago) had four subcategories in CNS anatomy (not my area).  Many of the questions were slight variations on one another and used the same response set.  I had begun with 1.4.4, and previewing and testing two random quizzes and a final was very confusing.  When I changed to 1.5 one of the (very many) improvements was that in the preview I could finally see the item ID and know at a glance which item was which.  I couldn't help wishing I could see the ID's with the item bank list on the edit page as well, especially since the list of items is ordered differently depending on the itembank selection: Anatomy Ch 15 displays all 82 items a different order than selecting Ch 15.1, then Ch 15.2, etc. So for me at least, the numerical ID is very helpful when dealing with large numbers of items (we plan to use very large numbers of questions), especially in an unfamiliar content area. I just tried watching the URL while hovering over the edit icon -- I think your compromise might be a good way to go, but a switch at the quiz, course, or admin level might also work: if you don't want the clutter, you don't have to have it, but if the ID is useful to you it can be switched on. Oops! Watching the URL brought up another issue: I had mentioned item ID for both sides of the edit page, but it applies to the quiz side for non-random questions only.  One shouldn't be able to edit a question or get an ID from the quiz listing for a random question -- no need to change anything from what you get now, it wouldn't make sense (item ID might display #? or some such thing).  It makes sense when previewing to have an item id that refers you back to the item bank for editing, because that is an actual instance of a selected item.  But outside the preview, the random question in the quiz is only a placeholder for an item to be selected at run-time.  I realize at present there are ghost placeholder items created in the item bank, but this will likely be replaced in some future version with a cleaner structure.  1.5 already gives the visual impression of having got rid of the the ghost items -- are they added to the item bank from which the random items are to be selected, or are they kept in a separate "random placeholder" item bank (which avoids altering the user-created item bank)? Thanks, Jim.
Comment 3: Hi Jim, Gustav I was grateful of the item id too, and agree that it would be nice to (optionally) see it in the quiz edit page.  Optional transparancey seems like a nice thing to have generally. One reason for this is that I am using back up and restore to populate the quizes of many classes and I am not sure of the rules regarding the when editing a quiz question in one course will affect the questions in other courses. Another thing is that if I edit a random question using the new (very pleasant) edit at quiz review functionality, then I don't know which of the bank of random questions, often with the same name, has been edited and which still need to be corrected.

Post title: Published test -- unable to view answers
Post description: Hello all!  I have published a test on Moodle for another instructor to use as well.  However, she is unable to view the answers and/or edit the answers.  Of course, since I originated the test, I am able to view and edit questions and answers but would also like for her to be able to do the same for her class.  Any suggestions on how this could be made possible? Thanks in advance for any help! Donnah
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: To be precise, you have published a category , not a test. The fact that your colleague cannot edit the category (or the questions in it) is a feature, not a bug. When you publish a category, you make it available to others in read-only mode. If you want others to be able to make changes, then you must give them a copy. The easiest way to do this would be for you to export the category in one of the allowable formats (e.g., GIFT), and give the file to your colleague. Your colleague can then import the file into her category. If she truly cannot see the answers to the questions in your published category, that's a bug. What version of Moodle are you using?
Comment 2: Thanks John for your help!  This worked...

Post title: In multiple answer question- grade only if all correct answers are selected
Post description: In Multiple choice question, where multiple answers are allowed, can we set the grading in such a way that it will give marks if all the correct answers are selected and no mark even if one wrong option is selected? Right now it is asking to giving the grade percentage for all the correct options. Kindly suggest if any other question type supports such type of grading.
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: There is an all or nothing question type in the plugin directory I believe that will do this.
Comment 2: Thanks Emma! I found the following question type with your keywords 'all or nothing': https://moodle.org/plugins/qtype_multichoiceset Is this the one you were referring to?
Comment 3: You can game this, by setting the wrong answers to -100%. We used to do this when we still used MCQ style questions. Gareth
Comment 4: It has been a while, so my memory of how this would work, could be wrong. I do remember it drove me crazy when they changed question behavior, years ago, and I had to change all my questions. If I'm not mistaken, in current versions of Moodle, by setting wrong answers to -100% and actually giving a wrong answer, it will cost the student double points for not getting the question right. In other words, if I give a ten question quiz and they get half right and half wrong, their final score will be ZERO, instead of the expected 50%. Let us say I give a ten question quiz. Typically, our grade starts at zero, and as we answer questions correctly, we gain and add points to our score. So, if I answer correctly for the first five questions, with each correct answer my expected total goes up 10%, so that after five questions I am sitting at 50%. Now on question 6, I give a wrong answer and my total goes down to 40% because the penalty for a wrong answer is to REMOVE whatever value that question had towards the total. With each succeeding wrong answer, the total goes down another 10% until after 5 right and 5 wrong, we wind up at zero. Note that doubting my poor memory, I did make two questions and created a quiz. As I tried the the results were: For two correct answers, I got a two point total grade. For one right one wrong, I got a zero total grade. For two wrong, I got -2 total grade.
Comment 5: Hi Al,
Comment 6: It was a standard, multiple choice questions with default settings and default points of 1. In the question I did the following: I created one correct answer with 100% score and feedback of Correct. I created two incorrect answers with -100% score and feedback of Incorrect. I duplicated the question giving me a total of two questions to place in my quiz. I placed both questions on one page. Taking the quiz as described above gave those results. I will include the questions here so you can see and try them.
Comment 7: Yes

Forum Post: 
Post title: How to Get Cumulative Score for all Quiz attempts
Post description: Hello all, I have a platform where users answer 10 quiz questions. Each question carries 1 mark. Each user has 10 attempts maximum. I want to be able to sum the scores of all 10 attempts to get a total score of 100. So for instance, if a user scores 8 in each level, his cumulative score will become 8 x 10 = 80 Is there a plugin that can do that or can someone point me in the right direction on how to manipulate the code to achieve that? Thanks
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: Hello Goodluck, Under 'Grade' in the quiz settings, you can set the 'Grading method' to 'Average grade'. This will give you the average (mean) grade of all attempts.
Comment 2: Thanks Dominique, However, I do not want the average of the attempts. I want a sum (total) of all the scores of all the attempts. So, if attempts 1,2 and 3 have scores 6,5 and 10 respectively, the total score will be 6+5+10 = 21 Is there a way I can code it into the 'Grade Method' ?
Comment 3: Let me see if I understand. Student #1 takes 10 attempts and gets 2/10 on every attempt, or a total of 20 points. Student #2 takes 2 attempts and gets 10/10, or a total of 20 points. You want their final grade to be the same, right?
Comment 4: I am only a user and I would not know how to code this. Maybe a workaround would be enough, depending on your needs: Click on the quiz Click on 'Attempts: xx' ' Download table data as': Microsoft Excel (.xlsx) In Excel, add two columns, say M and N, with typical cell formulas: Cell M2:  =IF(A2=A1;J2+M1;J2) Cell N2:  =IF(A2=A3;"";A2) where column A contains the name of the student, or you could use column E with the email address, and column J contains the grade for each attempt. You could then import these results back into Moodle.

Forum Post: 
Post title: Equations as answers
Post description: I have a bunch of WebCT questions that I want to translate to GIFT format.  The trouble is that many of the answers are in the form of equations. A typical question would display roughly as follows: "Question:  In the given circuit V = 5 < 125, Xc = -25j, Xl = 15j, R = 5.  Which equation describes the current? Answers: A   I = (5<125)/(5 - 10j) B   I = (5<125)/(5 + 10j) C   I =" etc.
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: Sorry for a rather quick reply Robert, here are some quick and poorly referenced pointers Escape (\) the equals signs to prevent the "correct answer" issue For simple syntax, use the algebra filter @@@x^2@@@=@@x^2@@, check out the moodle forum "mathematics tools". http://moodle.org/mod/forum/view.php?id=752 . For more complicated symbols such as the angle signs, use the TeX filter. I use http://meta.wikimedia.org/wiki/Help:Formula for a reference here. The only shortcoming I have found is the filter won't work on equations on the right hand side of a matching question. I have found the filters quick and easy to learn.  I never want to go back to point and click equation editors again.
Comment 2: Hi John, we dealt with this : The only shortcoming I have found is the filter won't work on equations on the right hand side of a matching question. With a new question type :renderedmatch. It's in CVS /contrib, pretty easy to install. You can have tex or any other html on either side of the matching question. It also does distractors.
Comment 3: Thanks Michael I'll give it a whirl when I upgrade. Keep up the great work.

Forum Post: 
Post title: Quiz module - let the instructor allow the student to continue and finish even after timeout.
Post description: Greetings, Here is a request from one of the faculty I support: This is a quiz feature request to let an instructor let a student continue a quiz that has timed out before completion. Several of my students reported losing their quiz data. I'm not certain, but I think my students' problems occur because they are failing to perform a "submit and finish" for a variety of reasons. (Some students mistakenly believe that the countdown timer stops after submitting and exiting before doing a "submit and finish" and they time out. Other students just lose track of time. My apologies if these scenarios cannot occur.) When I investigate, I see that their exam is still open, but that time has expired, and their score is zero. I am unable to recover the quiz but I am gradually discovering the degree to which I can see through WebAccess item analysis what the student had been attempting at the time of timeout. I usually have to come up with some compromise with the student. So the request is for WebAccess to let the instructor allow the student to continue and finish even after timeout. The version they are now is 1.6 but are going to 1.8 soon.  I don't see this capability in 1.8.  Thanks for any input on this request. Steve Murray
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: Please don't cross-post. There is currently no place in the database to store per-user settings relating to a quiz. So implementing this would be hard. You can probably fake it in 1.8, because there is an 'ignore time limits' capability, which was intended as an accessibility feature. However, you could use that here. Assign that to the students who have gone over time, who you want to let off, then regrade the quiz. That should work.

Post title: continue attempt after  power went out
Post description: Hi Dears ,, I made exam for 200 STU , and during exam electricity went out ! some students tried to continue their attempts when the power went out, and the system did not save the answers ,, how can I check problem ! BR
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: I have had this happen to me with students a few times with Moodle. Yes, students can be in the middle of a quiz, the power goes off and then on, and students can continue. The "clock" continues running if you are using timed quizzes. Whether or not Moodle has saved the answers depends on two things: 1) If students have been using the "next" button to progress through a quiz, and 2) the "Auto-save delay" setting. I am not an expert on this issue, so perhaps other folks will provide additional thoughts.

Post title: Essay questions adding general feedback post quiz.
Post description: My workflow has always been Write question (save question), run exam, mark exam, update model answers & general feedback to questions (save question). Publish quiz with feedback (General feedback check-box). Spot the problem. Yes, that's correct, no student  receives my model answers, examples of best answers from the students,what was needed for full marks and why certain types of answers received lower marks. I have performed numerous tests and exams with this workflow. Some students have asked me to post feedback, I have always confidently answered "yes I've done that, just reveiw your quiz". No wonder they walked off scratching their heads. I only found this out by accident when I adapted and old essay question which also the marker's rubrik. Following the test I wasn't able to get rid of the old question rubrik, I then noticed the same phenonmena for the general feedback regarding the question.
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: My guess is you are on Moodle 4.x: Have you tried regrading the atteamtps of your students after changing the feedback? (I have not tried this out, but for other changes to become visible, you have to regrade. Just make sure, you don't enter the student answer template, as this could lead to some unexpected problems.)
Comment 2: In my recollection, if you change anything in a question after a student has attempted it, the change will not show up to the student when browsing that attempt. This is true from before 4.0. I have only ever looked at changing the text, but I imagine it will be the same for feedback.
Comment 3: In Moodle 4.x: Write and save question. Run exam. Mark exam. Update the question's general feedback. (This will automatically create a new "v2 (latest)" version of the question. Keep "Always latest". *) Results / Regrade all (That is for the whole quiz but, of course, only the updated questions will change.) Students will see the updated general feedback when they review their quiz. * If you edit the quiz again later and select "v1" for the essay question and then "Results / Regrade All", students will see the first general feedback for the essay when they review their quiz. In fact, you can have multiple versions of the question but you will normally use the "latest" one. It works like a charm!
Comment 4: Questions and their versions are very different in Moodle 4.X onwards.
Comment 5: This is exactly what I needed! I tested it out this morning. Works wonderfully. Thank you ever so much. Problem solved for the future.
Comment 6: This seems like a benefit of question versioning that I had not thought about.

Post title: import quiz from another moodle db
Post description: today I had problems with the database , when the students after taking the quizzes, moodle did not save the attempt and reported an error writing to the db. Being in the midst of an emergency and with exams in progress, I restored a backup of the database to the previous day, losing around 500 quizzes taken after the backup. Now I have a copy of the db where the missing quizzes are saved, It is possible to import missing quizzes possibly also importing the data directly into the new DB If I import the records in the mdl_quiz_attempts and mdl_quiz_grades tables into the database, do I risk doing further damage?
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: Restoring the database during an exam is a nuclear kind of a reaction to non-responsive database! If you somehow survived that, I wouldn't repeat another restore. What you could try is to restore the whole site Site restore to a different Moodle instant and investigate. Still there's a problem: If people work in the production server the test site will be an old snapshot. You may be able to get the results of the exam and enter it to the grade book manually. Given deep insight in to the working of the Quiz it might be possible to "inject" only those attempts in to the running system. I can't even guess how demanding it would be. If the exam asked for file uploads the job is going to be doubly difficult. To the original problem, it is likely that the synchronous exam overloaded the server. Too late for the current problem, the long term solutions are discussed in the Hardware and performance forum.

Forum Post: 
Post title: Question shuffling...
Post description: Is there any chance of making the Shuffle option a question category option rather than a Quiz option? The issue I'm encountering is that using Shuffle precludes using any multiple-choice questions that include All of the above, None of the above, Both a and b, etc. It's currently an all-or-nothing proposition. You either have shuffle on for all questions or off for all questions. However, if this were turned into a question category option, you could then have banks of questions where question answers can be shuffled, and those that remain static, and pull from different banks as needed. It would allow the best of both worlds, so to speak... within a single quiz. Thanks.
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: Dan, you are making a very good point there. Making the "Shuffle answers" option be a category property will however also not please all people because some people might want to use one and the same question differently in different quizzes. This at least is the objection that was made when I last raised this issue. The solution would be to have it as both a quiz option and a category option. Answers would be shuffled only if both quiz and category chose this. From the point of implementing this an easier alternative to making it a category option would be to make it a question option. Given that it is really a property of the particular question which makes it unsuitable for shuffling, having a question option to turn shuffling off even if the quiz has it on would make a lot of sense. Do you agree?
Comment 2: By all means. I hadn't thought of making it a question option, but that does make the most sense...
Comment 3: This is now in Moodle 1.6. Matching, Multiple choice, and Random short-answer matching questions have an extra option to enable or disable the shuffling of answers. Answers will be shuffled only when this is enabled both at the quiz level and at the question level. It is enabled by default at the question level in order to be compatible with the current situation.
Comment 4: Excellent! Question: I notice that 1.6 is shown as "unstable". What is the anticipated timeframe as to when 1.6 will be a stable release? I'm not sure whether we should stick with 1.5 and forge ahead without this option, or hold off until 1.6 is released.
Comment 5: You can find information about the future of Moodle in the Roadmap . The beta for Moodle 1.6 is planned for the end of this month and, given the large number of new features, I would expect it to stay in beta for several weeks after that.
Comment 6: Hi, I just looked at this in the latest 1.6 CVS version. The default is "No" which means (as I understand it) that the answers would not be shuffled even if "Shuffle Answers" in the Quiz settings isset to "Yes". Is this at odds with the post above? May I suggest the following for the help file text... "If you set this option to "Yes", then the order of the answers is randomly shuffled each time a student
attempts a quiz containing this question - provided that "Shuffle answers" in the Quiz settings is also set to "Yes". This option is not related to the use of Random Questions."
Comment 7: What I had meant in my post above was that for all existing questions the question-level shuffleanswers option is set to "Yes" initially, so that they will continue to work as in the past. I agree with you however that it would be a good idea to also set the option on the editing screen for new questions to "Yes" by default and I will now do that. I will also introduce new help files for these question-level shuffle options. One problem that has always bothered me is that "Shuffle answers" is really a bad name for this option in the case of Matching questions. In matching questions the answers are of course always shuffled, the option controls whether the question-answer pairs are shuffled in addition to that. So a better name for the option would perhaps be "Shuffle question parts". Can someone come up with a better name?
Comment 8: What I had meant in my post above was that for all existing questions
the question-level shuffleanswers option is set to "Yes" initially, so
that they will continue to work as in the past. OK sorry, I'd misunderstood that. Potential alternatives for "Shuffle answers" Random answer order Randomise answer order Random answer options order Randomise answer options order I think it's probably too much to expect for a small label to convey the difference between the m/c and matching question behaviour. How about updating the help file? "If this option is set to "Yes", the order of answers within
each question is randomly shuffled each time a student
attempts this quiz. This only applies to questions that have multiple
answers displayed i.e Multiple Choice or Matching questions. The behaviour depends upon the question type: Multiple Choice: The answer options are shuffled. Matching: The first part of the option to be matched is shuffled. NB the second part i.e. in the drop down list, is always shuffled on each attempt irrespective of the the status of the "Shuffle answers (or whatever it is to be called)" setting. This option is not related to the use of Random Questions."
Comment 9: When I read Dan's post I felt the category approach might be unsatisfactory for an similar proportion of users to the current arrangements. Gustav, I think your idea is a good one. My further suggestion is that the current settings remain as they are and that the option in the question itself is to disable the shuffle option for that question, if shuffling is enabled for the Quiz. In this way questions which do or do not allow shuffling of answers may reside in the same category if required. Time for me to shuffle off now....
Comment 10: A similar but not totally related issue is points. In particular for matching style questions which I usually grade at one point per word. I would like to see a question have a default point value. That way, if I add a matching question to a test it will default to a certain number of points. Then if another teacher wanted to use the question but assign it a different number of points for their quiz they could. I'm not totally convinced that this minor convenience is worth the development effort, adding a field to the data structure, etc.
Comment 11: Anthony, thank you for that suggestion. In Moodle 1.6, when editing a question, you are now able to set the default grade for the question. Of course you can still, as usual, override this default grade when you use the question in a particular quiz.

Forum Post: 
Post title: Dynamic random quiz
Post description: As far as I have got into my first use of the quiz module, I do see how I can create a static quiz containing a number of questions preselected at random from a superset of existing questions. However, except for shuffling, a participant reruns the same quiz each attempt. For practice/review I had in mind a dynamically generated quiz. Does this exist at present? Namely, for every attempt, a student receives a different selection of questions from the superset, not just a shuffled version of the preselected. Recording grades is not a priority. Suppose the superset consists subsets for each chapter. Suppose each subset contains 100 questions. Thus Quiz 1 would have a parameter set to dynamically construct a new quiz of, say, 10 questions from Chapter 1. Quiz 2 ditto for 10 questions from Chapter 2 Then for cumulative review: Quiz 2-R  ditto with 10 questions randomly drawn from Chapters 1 and 2. Perhaps additional parameters could specify a weighting factor for each chapter's contribution.
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: Create multiple questions. You'll see how it works. You can grade or not. I will take a pool of 100 questions and select a quiz with 10 random questions. I have the answers and questions scramble too. I let them take it as many times as they want and count the highest score. When the quiz closes, they get to review and check which ones they missed. This rocks as a means of reviewing for a test. They get lots of practice and immediate feedback. I have used these features and like them a lot. I have never weighted the questions, but that is easy enough when you have the questions selected for the quiz and you are ready to "save grades."
Comment 2: I didn't understand your reply. When you said "Create multiple questions. You'll see how it works." did you mean create multiple quizzes?  What I have done so far is import 58 questions into a quiz.  How do I get a random 10 of them to display per quiz?
Comment 3: Check out this thread!  It answers the question! http://moodle.org/mod/forum/discuss.php?d=5440 The answer is that you create your category of 20 questions, and then on that category click the button right below the "Import questions from file" button that is labeled "Create Multiple Questions." This will ask you how many questions you want from the pool and let you add them to your quiz.  They show up as Random Question ( Categoy ) in your quiz, where Category is the category you got the questions from. Hope this works out - I know I'm excited about it.

Forum Post: 
Post title: Shuffle some questions and not others in a quiz
Post description: Hi, I'm trying to set up a quiz in which there are 133 multiple choice questions followed by 10 matching type questions. What I want to do is to shuffle the order of the MCQs and the matching questions, but not mix the two up. It does not seem that this is possible, but are there any workarounds / hacks / suggestions for accomplishing this? It is important to maintain them in one quiz, as it is timed and marked as a whole. Thanks in advance, James
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: Make two question categories. Put the MC questions in category 1.
Comment 2: Hi, Yes, of course this works fine. I should have thought of that... However, this naturally leads on to another question - is there any easy way of adding more than 10 random questions at a time? James
Comment 3: There is not an easy way, but there is a hack. When looking at the quiz editing page, copy and paste the following into the browser's URL field, and press enter. 
```text
javascript
:(function(){var count=133;var opt=document.getElementById('menurandomcount').getElementsByTagName('option')[0];opt.value=count;opt.innerHTML=count;})()
```
 That will magically change the first entry in the dropdown from add 1, to add 133. You can change the count=133 bit to use whatever number you want. This worked for me in Firefox .
Comment 4: Fantastic, thanks very much! Works well and saved me a load of time. JAmes

Post title: text editor
Post description: I am using the quiz module to try and create an algebra quiz.  However, I'm having problems using the text editor.  I can use it in the question section but can't use it in the correct answer section.  For example, I want to use exponents.  I was able to create a question using the subscript/superscript in the text editor but when I went to the correct answer box, the subscript/superscript characters wouldn't work.  I had the same problem with Hot Potato quizzes.  Any suggestions from other algebra teachers??
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: Please don't cross post. Your question was already answered in another forum.
Comment 2: There are several things you could do, including: If you have the algebra and/or Tex filters activated, you can type $$$ x^2+3x-5 $$$ and when the quiz is viewed it will appear as: $$x^2+3x-5$$ You can type HTML directly into the answer area: x<sup>2</sup>+3x-5 You can compose your answer in the question area using the text editor, toggle to HTML Source (using the <> button) and then cut the HTML from the question area and paste into the answer area.

Post title: Blocking Quiz Access
Post description: Hi I have a scenario, where i hv 2 quiz , Quiz A and Quiz B, I want if the user select the quiz A and completes it, then user should not get access to Quiz B, however if user complete the Quiz B first, then Access to Quiz A should be blocked, please advise if it is achievable, if yes then how. Regards Rudraksh
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: In the Quiz A activity Settings. Go down to Restrict Access. Change the settings to "Student must match the following: Quiz B Must not be marked complete In the Quiz B activity Settings. Go down to Restrict Access. Change the settings to "Student must match the following: Quiz A Must not be marked complete This should restrict access to either quiz if the other quiz has been completed.
Comment 2: thanks for resolving the issue. However i would like to know what if i hv 2 courses and situations is same, each course has 1 quiz and if user complete 1, then user cannot access 2 course quiz. is it possible..
Comment 3: I'm sorry, I don't know how to restrict access to Course 2 Quiz if Course 1 Quiz has been taken. Someone else may have a better answer, but it seems the best thing you could do is put both quiz activities inside one course so that you can restrict access as you need.

Forum Post: 
Post title: quiz with sections with nonstandard quiz score
Post description: Hello, I have created a quiz with different sections . But, I need a different way than the standard one to calculate the quiz score. Each section must be successfully approved individually. If all sections are successfully approved, then the average grade is made. Otherwise, the grade would be 0. I don't see a way to approach this in Moodle. I hope you can tell me if it is possible or not. Thank you
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: Hello Rodrigo, Each section must be successfully approved individually. How are the sections approved? Manually, or automatically by Moodle and according to what criteria?
Comment 2: Hello Dominique, The quiz questions would be multichoice. Each question has one correct answer. For each section the score would be automatically calculated with the standard Moodle system for that group of questions.
Comment 3: Hi Rodrigo, This is a feature Moodle does not support for the current (4.3.3) and earlier versions. The only way I can think of achieving the same result using another workflow, is the following: Instead of building one quiz with several sections containing n multiple choice questions each, you bild several quizzes containing ne multiple choice questions each. (sidemark: the number of questions may differ between quizzes). Each quiz is autograded upon submission. You may then generate a general score of the quizzes in the gradebook weighting the score of each quiz and putting the overall grade manually to 0 if one of the quizzes did not reach the pass grade. To do so you would create a category for the three quizzes which gives you a combined total score of the three quizzes. Best regards, Antonia
Comment 4: Hello Rodrigo. You might be interested in the forum discussion Allow quizzes to have multiple scores.

Forum Post: 
Post title: Moodle Close quiz vs Time Limit
Post description: Hi, I am trying to set up a Moodle quiz, which lasts for 45 minutes, but I want to limit the time that students can start the quiz. So the quiz would start at 13am (open time) and last until 13:45. I specify the time limit to 45 minutes and the close time to 13:15. Does the time limit override the close time, so that students that have started before 13:15 can work until the end? Or does is the close time absolute? It would be nice to have this functionality.
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: If you want students to be able to start at 13:15 and work for the full 45 minutes, then you need to set the Close time to 14:00 - and student would be able to start after 13:15 but they would then have less than 45 minutes to complete the quiz. It would be possible to create a new Quiz access rule plugin that gives exactly the behaviour you want. If you want a work-around, then at 13:15, you could edit the quiz settings and add a password. That would stop students starting attempts late.

Forum Post: 
Post title: Should we treat blank answers separately?
Post description: Suppose you've got a short answer question, and the student types nothing, then clicks 'submit', or 'submit all and finish'. Is that a wrong answer? Obviously, if they leave that as their final answer, they will get 0 marks, but should they be told 'incorrect', or should say something else, like 'No answer given'? And should they be given the wrong-answer feedback (feedback associated with answer '*' in the short-answer case)? And should they have a penalty applied? (Presumbably the answer to that depends on whether they have seen helpful feedback.) At the moment, when you submit a blank answer, if you do it the first time you see the question, the system just redisplays the question with no change, ignoring your submit. If you submit any non-blank answer, then submit a blank answer, you get told 'Incorrect'. That is so inconsistent, it's a bug and I need to make it consistent. Similar considerations apply to other question types, and obviously we should adopt the same approach everywhere.
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: I think this also raises the issue outside of short answer questions but also for multiple choice. Having the ability to determine when an answer has not been submitted on a question would be helpful. On standardized tests, the scores are calculated differently for an incorrect answer than for no answer. Currently, I have encouraged teachers to create an "I don't know" or "No response" option but that is not ideal.
Comment 2: I desparately need a way to let students know that they have forgotten to answer a question before they submit the quiz the final time. I have tried all sorts of methods of telling them to double check their quizzes to make sure they have answered all the questions with not so great results. I've been forced to go into the database and fiddle around and manually reopen the quiz for them. The reason my students are doing this so frequently as I use the quiz for quizzes that they have an unlimited amount of time to take. I have it set to one attempt only, and "each attempt builds on last." This means they can come and go to the quiz working on it a bit at a time, but since the quiz is usually spread out over a number of pages they may come back to it and forget where they were and accidentally skip something and then submit it for review without doing all the questions. Someone suggested allowing more than one attempt, but that won't work for me at all since the quizzes are mostly essay questions that require manual grading so there would be really big problems logistically if I had multiple attempts to deal with. I would like to see either a way of notifying the student they have left some questions blank before they submit and letting them complete those, and/or a way for me as a teacher to reopen a quiz with a single click so that the student can finish the questions they forgot.

Forum Post: 
Post title: Where are "random" type questions stored in the database in Moodle 4.x?
Post description: We recently upgraded from Moodle 3.11 to 4.1, so I'm still getting used to the differences. In 3.x, when we created a random question, it created a new record on the `questions` table where the column `qtype` set to "random." I can still see all the random questions that we created prior to the update on this table. However, I noticed that now, when I create a random question, there's not a new record on the `questions` table. So, where is this being stored now?
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: Actually, in Moodle 3.11, the real information about random questions was stored in the quiz_slots table. The row with qtype set to random in the questions table was a vestigial legacy. In Moodle 4.x, the key information has moved into to question_set_references table. You are looking for rows there with questionarea = 'quiz_slot' and itemid as the quiz_slot.id. The key information is then in the filtercondition column. (Why is this a blob of JSON ? because in the future, the flexibility to make random selections is going to increase a lot - we hope.)
Comment 2: Tim, thank you! They actually have questionarea = 'slot' and that gets me the info I need. The changes to the quiz engine in 4.x are great, I'm looking forward to see what comes next!
Comment 3: I have several questions in my moodle installation and I would like to know which ones are actually used in the various quizzes defined in the various courses how can I write a query that allows me to find the questions that are used in the quizzes also taking into account the quizzes that use random questions? Thank you for your support.
Comment 4: That is a non-trivial calculation. The information you need is in the question_set_references table. The data there is in two halves: (usingcontextid, component, questionarea, itemid) says where this set of questions is used. You need onces where component is 'mod_quiz' and questionarea is 'quiz_slot'. Then itemid is the quiz_slots.id. Then, (questionscontextid, filtercondition) tell you which questions are being randomly selected from here. filtercondition is a JSON representation of a possibly complex search. At the moment that can only involves question_categories and tags, but in future, more conditions will be possible.
Comment 5: To be more explicit I would like to know which questions are not used in any quiz and can be removed from Moodle. If I understand your suggestion, I need to look into the question_set_reference table to find the questions used in a quiz (randomly selected or not). Questions not referenced in this table are not used in any quiz. It's correct? Thank you for taking care of my post so quickly and on a Sunday too
Comment 6: Well, you still need to break apart filtercondition, but if you don't need 100% accuracy, then yes, computing an approximate answer is easier.

Forum Post: Post title: Quiz in adaptive mode solution required... Post description: If somebody use quiz in adaptive mode (I use it widely for interactive studying process - not for testing) then you should experience some inconvenience when student submits 5th or 10th question and after refresh he gets to the very top of the quiz. I guess it could be solved easily by inserting special tags into the code that after refresh page stays where it was before submit. Students waste a lot of time finding the question they were last time. And this irritates students. Please I need help on that topic. Can anybody improve the code? Comments associated with the post: Comment 1: Did you know that you can spread your quiz over several pages? That way students don't have to scroll too much. To insert page breaks you first should tick the "Show page breaks" tickbox on the Edit Quiz page. You can then repaginate the quiz with any desired number of questions per page and you can also move page breaks up and down in the list of questions. Comment 2: Yes I know that feature, but it seems to me that it will add a lot of work putting 5 page breaks and it does not solve the irritation of small scrolling withing smaller pages. Actually I have an idea how to make it work. Sorry I have no time to code it but I could explain my thought about issue. 1. insert 11 into mod/quiz/attempt.php Where 11 is a question number 2. after submitting the question all you need is to return not to mod/quiz/attempt.php but to mod/quiz/attempt.php #11 I think it should not take a lot of programming time of the speciallist who know where to insert additional code. Can anybody help me on that issue? Comment 3: Putting in page breaks is virtually no work. Simply choose "Repaginate with 1 question per page" and there you go: no more scrolling. For new quizzes you can simply set "Questions per page" to 1 when you specify the quiz options. If you want it even easier you can ask your Moodle admin to set the default for "Questions per page" to 1. Comment 4: I have received the very same request as netm@n from our teachers recently. My answer was the same as Gustav's: add pagination to the tests. ;) But at the same time I think that adding support for question anchors should not pose a difficult problem (am I mistaken?), and it seems to me that it would fit fine into the adaptive mode quiz usage. Some questions (e.g. cloze or questions containing pictures) tend to be rather long and -- in an extreme case -- the "pagination approach" could lead to having one question per page as Gustav suggests. But in tests containing a number of questions (e.g. language drills) this could produce far too many pages to navigate through. Comment 5: Thank you Daniel for supporting my thoughts about putting anchors to the question number. I did as Gustav said and have responds from my students. They say that last time they could see all questions in a quiz and now it is not really convenient for them to navigate from one page to another just to see what the questions are. Another inconvenience is that it takes more time for them to solve the same number of questions. So I need to increase time. Third thing to note is that they do not really know what particular question in a quiz is already been answered and what is not. If it could be possible to Highlight the question/page number somehow to make them know!!! Another thing they ask was: Can we choose the way questions are displayed between one or many? Like # items to display per page? - Is it good idea? Of course it would be perfect if anchors were embedded as well. Good thing is that having one question on one page leads to reduction of traffic and database load. Your opinion on that? Label:

Forum Post: 
Post title: 3 Answers 33% Each Problem
Post description: Folks, If anyone can help me solve this I'd appreciate it. I have a quiz on Fire Safety. The Fire Triangle has 3 elements. With 3 correct answers I assign 33.3333% to each - but the question can never be answered fully correctly as there is always 0.00001% incorrect. I may be wrong? but this is what I think is happening. Is my only option to ask the question providing one of the answers up front and asking the student to tick the other 2 elements - which could each be assigned 50% Also - is there any way to align images in quiz questions? My images are interferring with the text in the question, splitting it up badly? Thanks in advance for any help, jonny
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: Hi Jonny, can you precise your Moodle version, what you mean by "the question can never be answered fully correctly" and how do you enter your questions with the editor or by importing them? I just test your question on 1.5+ and     1.4.3+ and the allowed grade ( %100 ) is correct if the 3 rights answers are ok.
Comment 2: I'm using 1.5+ and creating questions manuallly in moodle, maybe I didn't explain well enough. Multi-choice Question: Which three elements below are part of the fire triangle? 1. Fuel (correct 33.333 %) 2. Oxygen (correct 33.333 %) 3. Heat (correct 33.333 %) 4. Carbon Dioxide (incorrect 0 %) 4. Electricity (incorrect 0 %) When I do this and tick the three correct values it doesn't seem to get the whole question correct. I also tried this with a short answer e.g. Name the three elements? and I cannot get the question correct because each of the three words scores 33.333% which means it is impossible to get it completely correct? I hope I am wrong, possibly doing something stupid?
Comment 3: Hi Jonny, you're not beeing stupid ;) You're completely right, the displaying of the automatic feedback string ("correct", "partially correct" or "incorrect") did not take this rounding problem into account. In the latest CVS version I changed this to use the number that are printed in the string "Marks for this submission: 0.67/1." to determine if it is correct or partially correct. So if you upgrade to the latest CVS version your question should work. On a side note: what you probably want to do is to set your question like this: 1. Fuel (correct 33.333 %) 2. Oxygen (correct 33.333 %) 3. Heat (correct 33.333 %) 4. Carbon Dioxide (incorrect -33.333 %) 4. Electricity (incorrect -33.333 %) If you don't assign negative marks for the last two options, the student can just check all answers and get full marks. Julian

Post title: Adding questions to bank after course starts
Post description: Course has a quiz with questions that are imported randomly from a question bank. Once course starts and quiz is used can during this period more questions be added to the bank?
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: Unless things have recently changed, which I doubt, yes, you can import more questions into a question bank category whenever you want to add more. This is a great Moodle feature. And you can add questions even after the quiz has started. As I recall (and have done), you can even fix some quiz question errors at any point in time. What you cannot do is once the quiz has started, you cannot add or remove questions to the quiz itself. If my ideas are incorrect, others here on Moodle.org will correct me. You can always try this on your own, either in an experimental quiz, course, or Moodle.
Comment 2: Thanks Rick. In fact my logic is, if you are not specifying any specific question or modify the points allocated to a specific question then you should be ok. The Quiz "pulls" questions from the bank, so if one sets that 10 questions are randomly pulled from the bank, it is irrelevant how many questions exist in the bank (as long as there are at least 10 questions in this case). Any expert can correct my theory??
Comment 3: I am not an expert, but your theory is what I have personally experienced.
Comment 4: Cool, Tnx Rick

Post description: Hi, I am using moodle 1.6.1. I write my questions in word, but save the file as plain text. Every question comes up with the shuffle answers option set to no. Then i have to edit every question and turn on the shuffle option before the answers will shuffle. Am i inadvertantly adding something that sets the shuffle option to no, or is there a way to reset this option. I want all of my quizzes to shuffle both questions and responses to questions. Thanks in advance
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: There was a bug report about this recently... http://tracker.moodle.org/browse/MDL-6769 It's fixed in the latest 1.6 (1.6.4+ for sure) and in 1.7.1. You'll need to upgrade to one of those.
Comment 2: Hi I had the same problem and got this from the group. worked a treat. In order for imported questions to allow shuffled answers by default, change the file \question\format.php in line 179 from 1. $question->shuffleanswers = 0; to 1. $question->shuffleanswers = 1; In order for newly created questions to have shuffled answers by default, change the equivalent setting to 1 in the file moodle/mod/quiz/mod.html regards Paul
Comment 3: Howard, Paul - thanks My administrator is going to update to 1.7 on spring break. Jim

Forum Post: 
Post title: Excessive Growth in mdl_question Table After Upgrading to from 4.4 to 4.5
Post description: Issue Summary After upgrading from Moodle 4.4.2 to 4.5 , we have encountered an extreme and unexpected increase in the `mdl_question` table size, leading to major performance concerns. Before upgrade : The table contained approximately 400,000 rows . After upgrade : The table has grown beyond 11 million rows in just a week or so . Key concern : The issue seems to occur when creating and duplicating quizzes , even before students attempt them. Observations & Testing We ran controlled tests in both Moodle 4.4 and 4.5 with identical quiz creation steps: Added a quiz with two questions from the question bank (no randomization). Moodle 4.4 : Number of rows does not change. Moodle 4.5 : 60 rows were added to `mdl_question` and related tables. Duplicated the quiz within the same course : Moodle 4.4 : Normal behavior. Moodle 4.5 : The duplication process added 120 more rows . Duplicated the quiz again : This time, the table grew by 240 more rows . It appears that each duplication exponentially increases the number of rows in `mdl_question` . Key Considerations Answering the quiz does not seem to be the trigger— the growth happens upon creation and duplication . The exponential increase in records suggests redundant or unnecessary question entries may be created in the database . We previously had hundreds of thousands of redundant rows before the upgrade, indicating that this issue may have been affecting us even earlier, but it has become much more severe in Moodle 4.5 . `mdl_question_bank_entries` has also grown significantly, mirroring the pattern in `mdl_question` . Questions for the Community Has anyone else observed excessive row creation in `mdl_question` after upgrading to Moodle 4.5? Is this a known bug or a schema change in Moodle 4.5 that affects quiz duplication? Does Moodle 4.5 handle question versioning differently, possibly duplicating questions unnecessarily? Are there safe ways to clean up `mdl_question` without breaking existing quizzes? Have there been changes made to how Moodle duplicates Quiz's? Any insights or recommendations would be greatly appreciated!
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: It might be this one MDL-83541

Post title: Selling quizzes
Post description: Newbie here. Trying to set up Moodle to deliver private tuition. Hoping to offer bespoke formative quizzes based on bespoke combinations of questions based on learners individual needs. To charge a fee for these quizzes I think each student probably needs their own 'course' creating? Main Q is, how best to compile/categorize large Q banks that these individual courses will draw from to create bespoke quizzes for individual students within their courses. Assuming that individual student-specific courses is the way to go for this project, does Moodle's allow Q banks that can easily be drawn on across multiple courses? E.g., perhaps via 'Core System context '? Possible alternative approach? Use access rules within a course to deliver chargeable items to individual students? For example, students A and B both registered on the same course but student A needs to purchase quizz X whereas student B needs to purchase quizz Y. Does Moodle allows that functionality via payment gateway etc or can students only buy whole courses? Likely that I'll be the only person constructing courses, Q banks etc so permissions probably not an issue here. Thanks!
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: If you are the admin you can make all the questions in the system context. Also you probably don't need a course per student unless you only expect to have a handful of students. You can restrict access via groups - one student per group -for example.
Comment 2: Many thanks for you'r reply Mary. I will have a look at your suggestion to restrict access via groups - one student per group -for example'. If that works out, do you know if it's possible to take payments for time limited access to quizzes for students within a group (or some other access restriction rule)? This is the kind of thing I'm hoping to set up (but for a non-medical discipline): https://www.onexamination.com/products/medical-student-finals Unless I can charge for access to the quizzes themselves, would I not need to create one 'course' per quiz, per student?
Comment 3: You can use the PayPal availabilty restriction plugin https://moodle.org/plugins/availability_paypal to restrict access to a certain quiz and you could use Restrict access to prevent access after a certain date, I guess.
Comment 4: Thanks again Mary. That plugin looks like it might be ideal for this purpose. I shall investigate. I think an approach that might work here is for a student to enroll onto to course with a broad-ish subject category which can contain bespoke quizzes that are only accessible to students who (a) need them, given their individual learning needs and (b) have paid for access to them.
Comment 5: Could you expand on what you are wanting to do. What is your subject, how far have you got in getting hosting etc etc. It sounds like an interesting project. Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: Hello Richard, I assume you have two different quizzes, and that one of them includes exclusively the essay questions, right? If your setting is like that, you can enable notifications when a quiz is submitted . You can enable this as an admin for everyone or only for those who want it and for specific quizzes, which is my preferred option. I don't get a "bell" notification because I have disabled internal notifications in Moodle, I get an email - I guess this can be configured as well. From my experience, the best way to check if a user has this feature enabled is to check his/her preferences and see if the permission is "on".
Comment 2: Hello Everyone, I am unable to receive notifications as a Teacher once quizzes are submitted for my courses. I am using Moodle 3.6 and Essential Theme. Here are the steps I did to configure the notifications site wide. 1. Open the course that contains quizzes 2. Go to Administration > Site administration 3. Go to Users 4. Select Permissions 5. Comment 3: Does anyone have any suggestions or comments on above? Thank you in advance. James.
Comment 4: I don't use this kind of notification, nor would I want to. However, from what you have said, I wonder if the notification (#8) is going to your Moodle's notification system and not intended to be emailed.

Comment 6: I am not sure. Someone else might need to guide you. My guess is that if you are not enrolled, you will not get emails. But is the site Admin enrolled in the course? I believe that unless someone is enrolled, no one will get messages.
Comment 7: I believe as you said, enrollment into course is required for receiving email notifications.
Comment 8: Well James, give it a try! Get yourself enrolled in the course as the teacher, add a quiz, add a bogus "student," take the quiz as the student (log in as the student), and see what happens.
Comment 9: I gave it a try by enrollment and that works. Thanks Rick. James
Comment 10: Great to hear this, James. In general, the beauty of Moodle is that you have the ability to experiment like this, unless your organization has prevented it. Now that you know you can do this, my guess is that eventually, your administrator will turn this off. The admin is going to be bombarded with emails unless your course is very small. Also, there are other ways to see who has taken a quiz, when one wants to see this information.

Comment 4: Read Tim Hunt's post. None of the category export formats includes images. Backup/restore is the only way to copy both questions and images. However if you insist on using category export/import, you could do it in four steps: (1) export/import the questions (2) zip and download the images from the old site (3) upload and unzip the images on the new site. All image links will be broken on the new site after step (3), so you'll have a fourth step: (4) manually repair all broken image links. Backup/restore SHOULD handle image relinking, but I have needed to repair certain links following backup/restore (and I'm not sure why).
Comment 5: Just a small correction. None of the formats include images in 1.5.x. In 1.7+ the XML format does indeed carry images!

Forum Post: 
Post title: problems after deleting question
Post description: Hi all, I help support a Moodle site and my client called in a panic yesterday because he deleted a question that was part of a quiz users had already taken. Here is the background, he had a quiz of 35 questions that was randomly choosing the questions from a question pool.  After users had already started taking the quiz, he realized one of the questions did not have the correct answer.  He was not sure what to do so he deleted that question.  Then he hit ReGrade. Now he is wondering if the grades are accurate or if he needs to make adjustments for the question he deleted. My questions are this: 1) why was restore not available for the question he deleted?  I see other questions greyed out with the restore icon but not for this question. 2) If a user got that question on their quiz (because he used random question, not everyone would have gotten the deleted one), what happened to their grade when he deleted the question and Regraded? 3) What does it mean on a user's quiz results when it says "This question has been deleted..." but there are no marks for that question? (not correct nor incorrect) We seem to have a few questions that were deleted (even though he says he only deleted one) and I have no way to tell which question it was. Thanks for any thoughts.  Sorry for so many questions. Terry
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: 1) If Moodle can detect that a question is in use, then when you ask to delete it, it just marks it hidden instead of really deleting it. If a question is marked as hidden, then it can be undeleted. Unfortunately, the way things are stored in the database , it is almost impossible to tell when a question has been used by a random question. This is MDL-5780 . 2) I didn't actually know what happens in this situation. Looking at the code, it seems that it regrades any questions that still exist. Any questions that have been deleted are not regraded, so the score for them is not changed. 3) What happens here is that, on the review screen, it displays this message in place of any question that was deleted. However, the score that the student got when they attempted that question is still stored in the database. If you want to poke around in the database, then student responses and scores are stored in the mdl_question_states table, and for random questions, the answer column starts random123-, where 123 is the id of the question that the student actually saw. That is, the 123 bit refers to the id column of the mdl_question table.

Forum Post: 
Post title: New table question_attempts
Post description: This post is probably only of interest to quiz module developers, not to most users. The quiz module often has a need for knowing whether a particular question is in use. For example when you want to delete a question the code first checks whether that question is already being used. If it is it will allow you to hide the question but not to delete it completely because otherwise all the data about student attempts at the question would become inconsistent. Now there is a problem with random questions which in an actual student attempt are replaced randomly by some question from the chosen category. The quiz module code currently has no efficient way of finding out whether a particular question has been chosen randomly in a given quiz. There is a table quiz_question_instances which one might think would do the job but it does only record the random question id, not the id of the questions that was actually used in the various student attempts. So I propose to introduce a new table quiz_question_attempts (later to be recalled just question_attempts once I get the go-ahead for separating questions from quizzes) with fields 'question' and 'attempt' which gets an entry whenever a question is used in a student attempt at a quiz. This table would then make it easy with one database query to discover whether a question is in use.
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: I have found the logic behind tracking random questions to resemble a mystery and to be less than transparent. I would be all for making it easier for Moodle and Moodlers to follow the logic behind what is happening.

Forum Post: 
Post title: Advice for managing a large question bank? (3000+)
Post description: Hi Guys, We've got a large question bank with nearly 3000 questions and growing, organized into a tree of categories at the system context level, and administrating it is now putting quite a strain on our server . I'm looking for advice on if there's a better way to structure our question bank to work more efficiently with Moodle. We provide personalized courses to language students, so rather than one large standardised course that all students follow, each student has their own course to which activities are duplicated. To facilitate this, we're heavy users of the Sharing Cart block. To avoid duplicating the data of every quiz at the course level, our questions are stored under the system context for universal access. However we've now come to a bit of a hurdle, as it seems when you backup a quiz in Moodle, it also backups up every single object in the included questions' context. That means for every quiz we copy into a student's course, Moodle goes through the process of backing up our entire database , bringing the site to its knees. Currently, our question bank is structured a bit like this... Beginners Vocabulary Adults Animals Numbered subcategories containing 6-8 questions each Drinks Numbered subcategories Fruit Numbered subcategories Vegetables etc, etc. ...and so on and so forth. Prepared activities are stored in a similarly structured category of hidden courses, which our teachers then use to copy the desired activities into their students' classrooms. The only "solution" I can think of is to store the questions of our quizzes at the course level context. We'll end with lots of duplicate data & a rapidly growing database, however at least Moodle won't be brought to its knees every time we try to copy a single quiz of just a couple of questions. Can anyone think of a better way to do this? (Related links: How to minimize the question bank when doing backup/restore , [MDL-41924] , [MDL-12403] )
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: Thinking further, this could be helped by structuring our students' courses in a similar way... Adults Beginners Student A, Beginners 1 Student B, Beginners 1 Intermediate Student A, Intermediate 1 Advanced Kids That could allow at least some question categories to be in the course category's context, saving on some of the duplication at course level. However we'll still need to be careful even at this level of separation, as even these subcategories will be quite large themselves.
Comment 2: I also used to have a large system level bank.  I ended up moving all the questions to the course level.  While I do now get duplication of questions, keeping the bank contained has helped in a lot of areas, but primarily in back up and restore which was having all sorts of issues when it tried to import the entire question bank. Also, any changes made to questions are now also contained at the course level instead of affecting anyone else using the questions.
Comment 3: Two suggestions: 1. I used to use a single course for quizzes where ALL quizzes were administered. With various restrictions you can limit who can see, administer, and take a quiz. Required a little extra effort on my part to make sure students knew where and how to take a quiz, but really cut down on duplication of effort, duplication of questions, and made course backups much smaller. 2. Do not routinely include questions banks in course backups. As an admin, go to, Site administration > Courses > Backups > General backup defaults, and remove the check mark for, Include question bank. With a centralized question bank, courses do not need to back up the same data.
Comment 4: On a different note, perhaps you could consider using the Formulas type question for some of your questions. The parameterization is effective and a single question can replace many if they are actually variations of the same question.
