Post title: Quiz Feedback not displaying as intended
Post description: Hi all I'm on 3.3.2 I have a quiz with all review options selected in the quiz settings. My quiz questions, all multiple choice, each have general feedback text. When a student logs in, they select an answer and click the "Check" button. Based on my understanding of the settings ( https://docs.moodle.org/22/en/Quiz_settings ), the general feedback back text should appear to the student upon clicking the "Check button. Currently the general feedback only appears once the "Submit All and Finish" button has been selected. My questions are: 1. Should the general feedback be appearing when the check button is clicked? If so, how do I correct this to make it happen? 2. If that is not the intended behavior, how do I correct the quiz so that the student can receive non-answer based feedback (general feedback) for each question prior to submitting the quiz Thanks!
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: You do not say, but I am guessing that you are using 'Adaptive mode' for the setting 'How questions behave'. That is the one setting that means the General feedback does not show up during the attempt. Try 'Immediate feedback' or 'Iteractive with multiple tries' instead. (Interactive only makes sense if you add hints to your question.)
Comment 2: Hi Tim Thanks for that addition. You are correct, I did have it set for Adaptive mode with no penalties. I didn't realize that general feedback didn't apply when adaptive mode was being used. I'll take another look at the other options and see if I can get the outcome I need thanks again

Post title: Is displaying the quiz questions as images available in MOODLE?
Post description: Hi, As the generative LLMs are becoming widely available, ability to easily copy-paste questions into these systems for getting the answers has become a major concern/issue. One way to make this harder is to display the questions in quizzes / exams as images, meaning using the text in them would require more work. Comment 9: By the way by Gökhan, I think this was a good question to ask.
Comment 10: To avoid coping text of quiz just use SEB. Unfortunately SEB does not prevent copying done by another mobile device as I shown in my prevoius post
Comment 11: I completely agree on "Tests should by applied only using SEB in classroom with no mobile devices and direct proctoring", only that our university stopped supporting any invigilated exams!!! Sounds like the next step may be getting rid of exams, all together! 🙄
Comment 12: Q. Is displaying the quiz questions as images available in MOODLE? If you ask ChatGPT: A. Yes, displaying quiz questions as images is possible in Moodle. Here's how you can do it: First, create the quiz and add the questions as you normally would. Then, instead of typing the question directly into the quiz question field, use an image editor to create an image of the question and save it to your computer. In Moodle, click on the "Edit" button next to the quiz and select "Edit quiz". Click on the "Edit" button next to the question you want to display as an image. In the "Question text" field, click on the image icon (a picture of a tree) to open the file picker. Upload the image of the question from your computer to the file picker. In the "Question text" field, add any additional instructions or text for the question. Click "Save changes" to save the question. Repeat these steps for each question you want to display as an image. When students take the quiz, they will see the image of the question along with any accompanying text or instructions.
Comment 13: Thanks, but I already know of this. I was asking if MOODLE could display the already existing MCQs as images instead of text, as a built-in option/function.
Comment 14: Please don't be offended as it is also very interesting to see what AI responds. If you ask ChapGPT: Q. Is displaying the quiz questions as images available in MOODLE? A. Yes, it is possible to display quiz questions as images in Moodle. You can insert images into quiz questions using the "Image" option in the Atto text editor, or by uploading the image to the "Files" area in Moodle and then inserting it into the question using the "Insert image" button. To insert an image into a quiz question using the Atto text editor, follow these steps: Click on the "Edit" button next to the quiz you want to modify. Click on the "Edit" icon next to the question you want to modify. In the Atto text editor, click on the "Image" icon. Select the image you want to insert from your computer or from the Moodle files area. Enter a description of the image in the "Image description" field (this is important for accessibility purposes). Click on the "Insert" button to add the image to your question. Once you have added the image to your question, you can format it as needed using the Atto text editor. Note that it's important to keep the file size of your images small, as larger images can slow down the loading of your quiz. You may also want to consider using alternative text for your images to ensure that they are accessible to all learners, including those who use screen readers. Q. Thanks, but I already know of this. A. I apologize for misunderstanding your question earlier. As of my knowledge cutoff in September 2021, Moodle does not have a built-in option or function to display multiple-choice questions as images instead of text. However, there are third-party plugins available for Moodle that can allow you to create image-based multiple-choice questions. One such plugin is the "Image Map" question type, which allows you to create multiple-choice questions where learners click on different areas of an image to select their answer. To use the Image Map plugin, you will need to install it on your Moodle site and then create a new quiz question using the "Image Map" question type. You can then upload your image and create clickable areas for each answer option. Please note that third-party plugins may not be supported by Moodle and may have limited functionality. It's important to thoroughly test any plugins before using them in a live course.
Comment 15: I know of all the built-in MOODLE question types that support images. As for the plugins, our IT would need to install, test and make them available, which is probably not worth the effort. Anyway, looks like what I asked/need does not currently exist as an option. It would be my suggestion to build it, if it would be possible to implement it as a display option for questions in all quizzes. Cheers, GT
Comment 16: I have been watching this conversation, and I am still puzzled about what you really want to do. Are you trying to prevent students from sharing answers to an "exam?" Or, are you trying to prevent teachers from giving questions to other teachers?

Comment 3: I guess I did not explain clearly enough. What I was saying is that at the moment there is a general mechanism that lets: people defining forms categorise each field as 'advanced' or 'not advanced'. for each user, remembers a preference of whether to show or hide advanced fields on, for example, the quiz editing form - and it does this very discreetly and simply from the user's point of view. To improve the usability of the question editing forms, we probably need to make this general mechanism more flexible (basically allow more than two categories) without making it too complicated for users, then harness that in the question types. We don't want to write lots of code in the question type forms to do all this manually.

Post title: Sharing is not copying
Post description: Sharing is defined as the joint use of a resource . If I share my lunch with you, we both eat from the same plate.  If I make you a sandwich just like mine, it is another form of charity, but it's no not sharing. In the same way, "sharing questions" means using the same questions, not copies. On our moodle site, we share questions.  Course #1 has a large question database .  Categories are published so they are visible to all teachers.    Only the editing teachers of course #1 (so far, only the site admin) can add, delete, modify, or re-categorize questions.  Teachers in other courses use these questions to create quizzes for their students.   The teachers see read-only questions in read-only categories.  If a teacher finds a mistake in a question, they report it to the site admin, who fixes it.   The mistake only needs to be fixed once, and the question magically is fixed in every quiz in which it appears. So far, everything works beautifully.  However there are some special quizzes (example: the Final exam), which must be identical in every course.   How can this be guaranteed? I experimented with two possibilities: Create the Final in course #1 and allow teachers to Import it. I can't imagine a worse solution.  First, we would have to make the teachers editing teachers of course #1, which would compromise the security of the question database.  Second, Import copies the questions, not just the quiz.  Furthermore, it copies all the other questions from the same categories, and it creates local categories for these questions. Create the Final in course #1, Backup course #1 with just this quiz, put the backup in a public place, and allow teachers to Restore (adding content to their courses) from the backup. Except that teachers don't need to be made editors in course #1, this solution has all the disadvantages of Import . I fully expected Import and Backup/Restore to copy activities , but until I experimented with them, I had no idea that they would make such deep copies.

Forum Post: 
Post title: Significant figures
Post description: If the wildcard comes up as 27, it presents as 27, not 27.0. This means the significant figures in the answer are incorrect. Sue's comment made me take a closer look at the significant figures workaround for the Formulas question. I worked in javascript . First, Javascript has the toPrecision() method. It adds trailing zeros, for example: 
```text
var Number=123.45;
Number.toPrecision(6)   // returns 123.450
```
 Unfortunately, 
```text
var Number=123.45;
Number.toPrecision(2)   // returns 1.2e+2 instead of 120
```
 1.2e+2 is not wrong. It simply is in exponential format, which often would not be as convenient as the decimal format. I worked out the following javascript for significant figures with trailing zeros and the decimal format maintained: 
```text
< script >
var x={z};                                               // x : number to round
var s = {nsf};                                           // s : number of significant figures
if (x == 0) {
  xr = 0;                                                // xr : number to round (= 0) 
} else {
  var a = s-1-Math.floor(Math.log10(Math.abs(x)));       // Inflate/deflate exponent
  var b = Math.pow(10,a);                                // Inflate factor
  var c = Math.pow(10,-a);                               // Deflate factor
  var d = Math.abs(x)*b;                                 // Inflate
  var e = Math.round(d);                                 // Keep significant digits
  var f = e*c;                                           // Deflate
// Trailing zeros
  var g = e.toString();
  var h = g.length;
  var z = "0";
  if (a==0) {xr=g+".";}                                  // Add "." Ex.: 200 w/ 3 sig fig = 200.
  if (a<0) {xr=g+z.repeat(-a);}                          // Trailing zeros
  if (a>0) {
    if (a<h) {xr=g.substr(0,h-a)+"."+g.substr(h-a,a);}   // No trailing zeros required (x > 0)
    if (a>=h) {xr="0."+z.repeat(a-s)+g;}                 // No trailing zeros required (x < 0)
  }
  if (x<0) {si="-";} else {si=""}
  xr=si+xr;                                              // Add minus sign
}
< /script >
```
 This script seems to work like a charm.
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: Well, the reason toPrecision() uses the exponential format in the example 
```text
Number=123.45;
Number.toPrecision(2)   // returns 1.2e+2
```
 is to show clearly the two significant figures. Whereas with 120, the number of significant figures is not clear since it could be 2 or 3. My apologies, toPrecision() is fine. Yet, in many cases we would like to keep the decimal format, and 120 would be preferred over 1.2e+2.
Comment 2: Hello Dominique, Don't you think it would an interesting addition to add a toprecision($number, $precision) function to variables.php so that it could be used in formulas questions ? Of course that function would return a string not a number to be able to display the right number of trailing zeros. This would not require a lot of work. In fact just to translate your code to php. My idea in adding the poly function was that if formulas already has a lot of math functions it somewhat miss some functions to ease the display of questions. The toprecision function seems to be a nice addition in the same area.
Comment 3: I am new to Moodle and formulas and really miss the stringified value of number with extra 0s at the end of the mantissa. An input of 4.00 is often better than 4. And significant digits is very important. Also, if answers are to three significant digits, then an answer with 1 as the first non zero entry should (?) have an extra significant digit displayed: 123.4, 23.4.
Comment 4: Hi Dave, "Numbers starting with 1 should have an additional significant digit" is not a strict rule. However, it is a good way to improve the precision of the numbers. If this rule is not applied, the precision of any number is between 0.1% (for example 99.9 ± 0.1 = 99.9 ± 0.1%) and 1% (for example 100 ± 1 = 100 ± 1%). If the rule is applied, the precision of any number is between 0.05% (for example 199.9 ± 0.1 = 199.9 ± 0.05%) and 0.5% (for example 200 ± 1 = 200 ± 0.5%). Thus, by applying the rule, the precision of the numbers improves from ± 1% or better to ± 0.5% or better.
Comment 5: Hello Jean-Michel, I'm sorry I missed your post. It would certainly be interesting to add a function to display the numbers with a given number of significant digits. In my humble opinion, the problem is not as simple as it seems. We might want to consider the more general problem of displaying numbers, that is, the number of significant digits but also the number format. We could draw inspiration from the calculators' display, such as HP and other calculators, in scientific notation and engineering notation. The javascript function toPrecision(), or a similar function, can only be a one-size-fits-all solution which has some gaps. I think that if we wanted to do the right thing for the Formulas question, we would have to develop a complete scientific display system and make sure it is the best.

Comment 1: Actually this question is asked relatively frequently. Dominique Bauer also has a solution on his site but I couldn't find it for you. He might comment here if he sees the discussion. This can be done using Poodll, a commercial set of plugins for Moodle. You can read more about it here: https://support.poodll.com/en/support/solutions/articles/19000125716-multi-player-audio-widget
Comment 2: I'm curious, Justin. How does this work technically? Also, what happens to a student on a weak internet connection? (E.g. studying on a train that goes into a tunnel?) Also, what about students with special needs ( accessibility )? I'm hoping that you have thought through these issues and have a good answer.
Comment 3: Hi Tim, It is just a lightweight solution that can be implemented using the Poodll widgets/filter system. The author inserts an audio file into the question's description area as usual, and surrounds it with Poodll filter tags. When the page is displayed the audio file is loaded into an audio player with a simplified interface. It is keyboard navigable and should work with screen readers (I will check) but there are no further accessibility features.
Comment 4: Thanks for explaining. That seems like a reasonable implementation. And, I can see when teaching something like listening to a language, it makes the assessment more authentic. Another way you coudl have tracked the plays, is to use a Moodle user_preference. There is a core_user_update_user_preferences web service which can be used from JavaScript . (E.g. for example https://github.com/moodle/moodle/blob/master/contentbank/amd/src/sort.js#L167 ). That would protect against people switching browser. (See also MDL-62859 , which is about wrapping that service in a nice API.)
Comment 5: Ohhh cool. Thanks for the tip. I will look at that.
Comment 6: Hello Fahm, I support what Justin said. Poodll is an great set of tools for language teachers to build dynamic courses that integrate seamlessly with Moodle. Its suite of plugins includes tools for audio and video recording, vocabulary learning, and assessment of speaking and reading. It is a Moodle Certified Integration ↗ . I also designed a client-side workaround which is to only show the play and pause buttons and let Moodle count in a quiz how many times the audio is played. It would be desirable to have the solution on the server side. However, one thing to consider is that students can easily record an audio with their phone and then play it back as many times as they want. See Limited number of audio plays ↗ .

Post title: Quiz attempts
Post description: Even when students are removed from the class, the quiz still reads, "15 students have make 19 attempts" "You can no longer add or remove questions." I want to use the quiz over again and add more questions and delete others. What should I do to clear out the attempts of students who are no longer in the class? Thanks,
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: Go to the overview report, click the select all link, then choose "with selected attempts" delete. I think it would be bad if quiz attempts were deleted just when a user is unenrolled from the course. What if you unenrolled the wrong student by mistake? You should be able to re-enrol them with no dataloss.
Comment 2: Click on the link 15 Students have made 19 attempts and it will take you to a page where you can delete the attempts as follows: select all attempts (put check marks next to all the attempts) With Selected->Delete When you go back to Editing questions, you will see that you can now add and remove questions.

Forum Post: 
Post title: Updating Question Bank
Post description: Is it possible to update the question bank by uploading new version of same questions? For example using all same tags and identifiers but the question text may include now another language filter section or possibly a new URL for the image location. Is this possible?  I'm trying to understand if everytime we want to make an edit to a large number of questions if we can "replace" the older version and that will be reflected throughout the course.
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: My understanding is that you can add them as additional questions to the bank but then you would be unable to pick questions from the bank using random selection. You can update existing questions but that will not disqualify anyone's previous attempts at the question. You can add it as a new question and 'delete' the old version of the question which will retire it from the bank but retain it for historical attempts. Then add the new question to quizzes where the questions are not randomly selected by the quiz.
Comment 2: Thanks Stephen - I think basically it is not really possible to kind of "update" the existing questions from a single place and have them reflected throughout the courses. After the update previous attempts on that question would not be relevant for us

Post title: Moodle 4.4.1+   Quiz settings  forms not scrollable on iPad Pro 12.9" and iPad 10.5", iOS 17.5 – Boost and Classic themes
Post description: Hi there! On Moodle 4.4.1+ quiz settings pages are not scrollable on iPad Pro 12.9", iOS 17.5, iPad 10.5", iOS 15.0 using either Safari or Chrome . This occurs in both Boost and Classic themes. The only scrollable area is inside the Atto editor; the rest of the form remains locked, even when tapping outside or trying to swipe. Tested on: Moodle 4.4.1+ (clean install, no custom theme) iPad Pro 12.9", iOS 17.5, iPad 10.5", iOS 15.0 Safari and Chrome Boost theme (default) Classic theme Attempts to fix (none successful): Custom CSS to force `overflow-y: auto` and `-webkit-overflow-scrolling: touch` JavaScript to manually enable scroll on `.mform` , `.card-body` , `#region-main` Switching to Classic theme per user Creating new admin user This appears to be an iOS-specific bug caused by the way Moodle's form layout and containers are structured. It prevents any meaningful quiz editing on iPad, requiring desktop access to perform basic admin tasks. Steps to reproduce: Log into Moodle as an admin on iPad Pro 12.9" Open a quiz and click on "Edit settings" Attempt to scroll the settings form Only the Atto editor scrolls; all other parts of the page remain unresponsive. Is this a known issue?? Thank you so much in advance, Tiziana
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: What about other bit forms in Moodle (e.g. course settings, ...)
Comment 2: Hi Tim, Thanks for the suggestion. I just tested other large forms like Course Settings, and the same scrolling issue occurs there as well. So it seems to be a general Moodle form issue on iOS, not limited to quiz settings.
Comment 3: Hi Tiziana, I noticed this all of a sudden last week on my iPhone, but for me it was the Course Settings page (I'm not seeing this issue on the Quiz settings pages at the moment), but I fixed my issue on the Course Settings page with this CSS on my 4.4+ site: /* Fix Inability to Scroll Course Edit Page on Mobile */ body#page-course-edit { touch-action: auto!important; }
Comment 4: Hi John,

Post title: Pictures not displaying on a quiz page
Post description: I have set up my first Moodle quiz and have included a simple JPEG from the files I have uploaded to the course.  Set-up seemed to be very simple but the picture won't display whenever I attempt the quiz. Here's the URL of the picture: http://www.webchem.net/sci-net/mod/quiz/quizfile.php/1/4/microbes_and_disease/HIV.jpg Can anyone spot a problem here? Thanks Chris
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: This url doesn't seem to work...maybe someone deleted or renamed the image after you uploaded it?
Comment 2: Chris Have you had any success solving your problem with images? I'm experiencing the same problems. What was your solution? Appreciate your feedback ps The URL does not seem to work btw Nicholas
Comment 3: There was a problem like this in old versions of Moodle, but not 1.3.x  ... what version are you using?
Comment 4: Thanks Martin. I'm using 1.3.2. I have managed to upload some images needed for the quiz this am. But my other problems in developing a quiz are as follows: 1. Some of questions require the use of superscript (degrees, etc.). However when I'm in the create question screens (M.C., T/F, etc) and I type I do not have access to font formatting. To the left of the panel where the text of the question is entered, there is a link to help file talking about html. Ho do I get access to html? I've copied my questions from an html format but the superscript 0 does not show. 2. After typeing my questions and answers and click "Save changes", the questions do not show listed in the bottom part of the "Select/Question Name/Type/Edit screen. I tried to Refresh and Shift-Fresh, F5, but they questions do not show. Any idea what I'm doing wrong. 3. I also have difficulty Importing questions from file. I'm using the GIFT format, and I have a number of questions that I've set up and saved as ".txt" and ".html" but when I try to upload them, they come up on a screen but there is nothing I can do with them. What's the best course of action here? Nicholas
Comment 5: Nicholas I found the problem was nothing to do with the images or the uploading process but in the settings for our whole Moodle site. I was trawling through all the configuration pages trying to get a feel for all the options available (I had too much time on my hands that day!) and I came across the answer.  Try going to Configuration/Variables and then scroll down till you come to a setting called "slasharguments" which is to do with the way Moodle searches for any uploaded files.  Our default setting was the second one in the pop-down list [file.php/pic.jpg] and we couldn't get pictures to display.  The guidance to the right of the pop-down list solved the problem - I switched the setting to the first option [file.php?file=/pic.jpg] and the problem was solved.] Note: according to the FAQ on "slasharguments" this can lead to problems using relative links within HTML documents. You can link to the FAQ directly from this poting as the word "slasharguments"on this page should be a hyperlink.  This gives details of how to fix the problem at the server side.  We haven't done this yet (as we don't host our Moodle site) but I'll try and remember to let you know if we sort it.  I have to say it was great to see the images appear.  They add hugely to the Moodle experience and the glossary I was working on has been transformed! Hope this helps.  Let me know if it solves the problem. Chris

Post title: Calculated question type - hard coded limit?
Post description: Hi,

Is it possible to create 200 datasets, or there is a limit of 100 datasets (hard coded)?

Ricardo
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: Hello Ricardo, I think you can't exceed the limit of 100 data sets. You have three options: Increase the limit by modifying the question code yourself. Make a request on the Tracker to have the limit increased. Use the Formulas question type, one of the advantages of which is the very simple and unlimited generation of data sets. For me, the third option is by far the best.
Comment 2: Hi, Dominique. Thank you for you help!! #3 seems indeed the best option.
Comment 3: I have a "calculated multiple choice" question type and 100 items in a dataset. In this course I have 804 participants. When taking the quiz, some students reported that the question appeared with blank fields where the variables were to appear. Is this error related to the fact that there are 100 items in the dataset and 804 participants? Would it be correct to think that 704 participants would not have their question asked correctly?
Comment 4: [SOLVED] Despite having a limit of 100 items in the dataset, questions will appear more than once if I have more than 100 participants in the course.
Comment 5: I think that you are correct.  If you have only 100 datasets, some of these will be used more than once to satisfy your 800+ students.

Now, I'd like to let students to be able to subscrive to a given quiz, i.e. only those that subscribe to the quiz (within a defined time span, say 3 days before it starts) can actually perform it. Is there such a module (extension)? regards Stef
Comments associated with the post:

Forum Post: Post title: GIFT Export - How to get rid of HTML codes? Post description: GIFT is the only common format between Moodle and Talent LMS. We use both. When exporting GIFT from Moodle, it inserts [html] and

, etc. all over. These html tags are not part of the GIFT spec, which simply then displays the preceding each answer, for example. Does anyone know how to get rid of these unwanted html codes in GIFT export? I've tried everything I can think of! Comments associated with the post: Comment 1: The GIFT format was invented by Moodle, so the spec is whatever the Moodle code does! Post title: Embedding questions from a system category of the Question bank ?
Post description: Hello, I'm testing out the Embed question filter to be able to embed questionbank questions into a book. Following the steps provided at https://github.com/moodleou/moodle-filter_embedquestion/blob/main/internaldoc/functionality.txt I am able to insert a question from a course category .  As our questions are shared across all our courses, we've structured our questions under the system category. Could you please confirm this means that it is NOT possible to embed questions located under the system category ? Thanks, Valerie
Comments associated with the post:

Comment 2: Thanks Tim.  Best. Valerie

Post title: Cannot open Quizzes – error/moodle/dmlwriteexception
Post description: Lately when I try to open any quizz on my moodle 3.3.5 installation I get the following
debug info: Debug info: Duplicate entry
'48954-0' for key 'mdl_quesattestep_queseq_uix' INSERT INTO mdl_question_attempt_steps
(questionattemptid,sequencenumber,state,fraction,timecreated,userid) VALUES(?,?,?,?,?,?) [array ( 0 => 48954, 1 => 0, 2 => 'todo', 3 => NULL, 4 => 1533734132, 5 => '2', )] Error code: dmlwriteexception × Stack trace: ·        
line 489 of /lib/dml/moodle_database.php: dml_write_exception thrown ·        
line 1300 of /lib/dml/my sql i_native_moodle_database.php: call to
moodle_database->query_end() ·        
line 1346 of /lib/dml/mysqli_native_moodle_database.php: call to
mysqli_native_moodle_database->insert_record_raw() ·        
line 227 of /question/engine/datalib.php: call to
mysqli_native_moodle_database->insert_record() ·        
line 148 of /question/engine/datalib.php: call to
question_engine_data_mapper->insert_question_attempt_step() ·        
line 100 of /question/engine/datalib.php: call to
question_engine_data_mapper->insert_question_attempt() ·        
line 100 of /question/engine/lib.php: call to
question_engine_data_mapper->insert_questions_usage_by_activity() ·        
line 349 of /mod/quiz/locallib.php: call to
question_engine::save_questions_usage_by_activity() ·        
line 2366 of /mod/quiz/locallib.php: call to quiz_attempt_save_started() ·        
line 111 of /mod/quiz/startattempt.php: call to
quiz_prepare_and_start_new_attempt() Seems that Moodle cannot write into the Database table „mdl_question_attempt_steps“
anymore. I have copied the database to a test-moodle 3.4.4 on another server with barracuda enabled. I have run the cli script to change the database to
barracuda which converted selcted tables, but did not include the table
„mdl_question_attempt_steps“ – the problem is still the same. In a radical step I deleted all the content in that table
via phpmyadmin – now everything seems to work again. Is there a better solution to my problem? Might emptying that
table have any consequences in other places? I have checked the grades for quizzes in  different
courses and everything seems to be  fine. Has anybody run into the same problem?
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: Moving to Quiz forum...
Comment 2: This is almost certaily a problem in your database. If I had to guess, the autoincrement value for one of these tables is wrong, which is what is leading to the duplicate keys. I really would not recommend truncating random Moodle tables. (Although that does reset the autoincrement counter according to the docs.) Can you reproduce the error on qa. moodle.net ?
Comment 3: Hi Tim Thanks for answering here and in the tracker: https://tracker.moodle.org/browse/MDL-63195 I’m pretty sure it is a problem in my database. Somehow the autoincrement value has
gone down by many numbers. I’m not a database specialist at all. Just trying to
understand some basics. My first approach was to delete the entries in the
database with the ID-number given in the debug-info. But then always the next
number would be the problem.  And there
were much higher ID-numbers in the table. That’s why I decided to truncate the
whole table. The question is why the autoincrement value went down
so far. And one explanation would maybe be, that when importing the quizzes to
another course the question_attempt_steps were somehow also copied, so when
trying to start the test again in the new course that would lead to those duplicate
entries. And that would probably be a bug. I have no idea how to reproduce the error on
qa.moodle.net.  What I have done, was
uploading  the course into a fresh Moodle
installation. And there everything works fine of course. So a.t.m. for me the only solution for my production
Moodle would be to also truncate the tables · mdl_question_attempts · mdl_question_attempt_steps · mdl_question_attempt_step_data · mdl_quiz_attempts to get the quizzes working again. The question is how that could affect this Moodle installation
in other places. It’s working well in my copied Moodle, but things may be different
when hundreds of participants are working in the system. So what do I really risk?
Comment 4: Ah! I have another theory: Suppose the backup file contains bad data, so that when the backup is restored, it puts data into those tables with unique key values that should not have been used yet. Then, later, when the autoincrement sequence gets to those numbers you get these errors. To test that theory, I would need to see the backup file.
Comment 5: Hi Tim That was kind of what I wanted to say – of course your explanation
is much more precise. I have created a backup of that course only containing these
quizzes without userdata. Then I imported it to a clean new Moodle and nothing was
added to the database. So far so good. But my original import was not from a backup but an import
of activities directly from a running course to a freshly created course in the
same Moodle. I have done the same thing again and checked the database before
and after - no entries were added to the database by this process. So there seems to be no proof for our theory. You will probably understand that I cannot send you a copy of
the dastabase of our production-Moodle. So I guess the only thing I can do is truncate these tables?
Comment 6: I think that instead of truncating these tables, a safer option would be to change the autoincrement sequence value, so that all newly generated ids are 'safe' and don't cause conflicts. That would involve which id is causing the conflicts (which table), then finding the sequence value that is big enough to avoid future problems, then executing SQL like ALTER TABLE tablename AUTO_INCREMENT = 123456

Forum Post: 
Post title: Safe Exam Browser Pros and Cons
Post description: It's that time of year again to renew Respondus Lock-down browser, and I would like to know the pros and cons of using Safe Exam Browser instead.  Here are the drawbacks I see: 1.  Since the code is open-source, it is easier to hack 2.  I heard it can't be used on student-owned computers, but I don't think that's true 3. It looks more complicated to use and setup than Respondus, for everyone involved. I really haven't found an easy to read "this is how you set it up and use it" as the teacher or student. 4. Support for problems would not be as good as Respondus. We had a lot of problems with wifi last year and I don't want to switch to something and have the students have different problems this coming year (hopefully wifi problems are taken care of!).
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: Good grief. Do people still believe this myth? http://www.zdnet.com/article/six-open-source-security-myths-debunked-and-eight-real-challenges-to-consider/, https://www.irisns.com/fact-versus-fiction-is-open-source-software-less-secure/ (Google will find more.) SEB can be installed on student computers (also known as BYOD). Read the documentation on their website. This presentation gives a good summary: http://safeexambrowser.org/presentations/HowTo_SEB2.0.pdf Ditto. I have dealt with commercial companies, and I heave dealt with Open Source projects, and I know which generally gives better support. Commercial support sucks. Getting online exams to work with students own computers, and wifi, is definitely still hard, not routine. But, it can be done with either Respondus or SEB. Getting and configuring a particular secure browser is the easy part. The real problems are the same in both cases: How do you make your wifi reliable? How do you support hundreds of students installing some additional software onto their own laptops? Can you find enough rooms with power at each desk?

Comment 1: The function that appears to be failing is quiz_get_category_menu(). It's failing on line 2073. I followed it all the way back to get_records_select() in /lib/datalib.php and echo'd out the sql . Ran it in phpmyadmin and discovered that it is looking for a field called parent? Post title: Detection of cheating/plagiarism in essay type questions
Post description: On a quiz, one of the problems is an essay type answer, where students are supposed to enter a mix of technical text, and equations + numbers. I want to find out if there is any plugin available which can be used to compare student responses and tell the instructor about the likelihood that part or all of the answer was copied from another student, or has common features that warrant further investigation. It is impossible to specify this completely as I am looking for any helpful tool that could help. Needless to add, the essay type question will be manually graded, so something that generates a summary map pointing to attempts of concern would be most helpful. The instructor has to obviously exert the final judgment, but a supportive tool is helpful when you have a very large number of students, and by the time you are grading the 133rd attempt, you have mostly forgotten about the 15th. I have looked at the auto-graded essay type question and that is not what I want. The bigger concern here is students copying from each other, rather than from some known source(s).

Moodle is a free and open-source learning management system (LMS) used by schools, universities, and workplaces to create online courses and manage learning activities.
Your task is to classify if the provided discussion forum post is a feature request or not for Moodle. A feature request is a post where the user asks for new functionality, missing functionality (e.g., features available in other apps), new content, or changes/improvements to existing features in future releases. Posts that are not feature requests include: bug reports, troubleshooting questions, usage questions, configuration issues, announcements, or general discussions. 
Respond strictly with one of the following labels: FEATURE_REQUEST or NOT_FEATURE_REQUEST. If the forum post is a feature request, return FEATURE_REQUEST. If the forum post is not a feature request, return NOT_FEATURE_REQUEST. Use the post title, post description, and associated comments with the post to make your assessment.
Forum Post: 
Post title: See question statistics with random question quiz
Post description: Hi, I have been doing weekly quizzes with my students. However, I usually use the random question feature, so each student gets different questions. This works well, however after when I view the results, each student's 'question 1' is different. This is a problem since I have no way of knowing which questions were harder and which ones were easier. Is there someplace where I view all the question statistics, such as question attempts? Or view students responses with all possible questions included. Thanks very much!
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: Have you tried the Statistics report built into the quiz? Does that tell you what you want?

Post title: Timer For Five Exams
Post description: Hi all .... want to make concurrent Five  exams with scenario student start First Exam student can view second exam without finish  First exam all exam with same timer (if student start first exam timer  is on ) thanx for all

Forum Post: 
Post title: Moodle auto-save/auto-submit issue
Post description: We
have experienced an issue with what appears to be quiz attempts being written
to the database . This has happened twice this week – Tuesday and Friday, at the
same time of day – although we have had many exams all week using the same type
of Quiz module with the same settings. Moodle
version: Moodle 4.1.3+ (Build: 20230427) Server OS version: Ubuntu 22.04.2 LTS Quiz
auto save interval is set to TWO (2) minutes. Quiz
modules are set to auto submit when time expires. There
is no resource issue with servers and there was plenty of CPU headroom
throughout this time. We have checked the environment and nothing was amiss. Details: Around
11:00am, the auto-save began slowing up according to cron job logs. Many
users’ attempts were auto submitted ‘around’ 11:15 – 11:20, depending on start
time. According to the logs, auto submitting took several minutes – much longer
than usual. At
11:17:04, the cron task for Updating overdue quiz attempts (\mod_quiz\task\update_overdue_attempts) began and took 9 mins 12.68 secs to complete. Cron runs every minute, the Updating overdue quiz attempts runs
every minute and generally completes in < 1 sec. The
following was returned in the task logs:

 The

Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: You say there was no issue with server load, but what you describe looks just like what would happen if the database server was overloaded, so can you make sure you have checked the CPU, memory and I/O load there? Is your database set to log slow queries? Does that show anything relevant?

Forum Post: 
Post title: My school quiz has problems
Post description: My name is Jesse. I am an IT student at Borrego Springs High school, & w e are beginning to use moodle as an online tool to administrate a school wide quiz to regulate computer control. You see, we are restricting certain individuals that think that they will not get Caught by our blocks, so they do get caught & we suspend their Computer privileges. So far it has been working, but to make this easier we are going to issue cards to have on their [the students] persons at all times at school. I have been issued as the person that will put the quiz into moodle.learningtech.net & then tell the students where to go, etc.The quiz we are using we got from a seperate school & is a HTML format document on a CD. So far I have run into several problems. Mainly because I'm about as deft at HTML editing as a potato, so I have run into some snags while inputting the quiz text into moodle. For one thing, I do not know how to make the submit button send the results to our server , or any server for that matter. Also, when I save the changes, all the buttons disappear! Can someone please assist me in my query?
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: Hi Jesse, are you putting the questions into the Moodle quiz module using the Moodle quiz setup and editing forms? If you do that, it should handle all submitting to the database automatically (results will show up in the gradebook). Or are you trying to paste the html file as a resource or something? That probably won't work inside of Moodle. If you are using the Moodle quiz module, we have a manual here that may help (login as guest).
Comment 2: My problem is that Iam trying to paste a HTML file as aresource, yes. so far I have been unsuccessful, & if you say that it will not work, then I will try to find other means of putting our quiz in. thank you for the response.

Post title: Max Time Limit for Quiz
Post description: Hi... i'm just a beginner on using moodle.. I just upgrade my moodle from version 1.5.1 to 1.5.2 latest version, but my time limit for quiz still same (option from none - 5 minutes only). How can i change the max time limit (5 minute) to 30 minute or 1 hour?? Should i edit any php script on the server to change the max time limit?? Which file?? Please help.. TQ
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: Have you checked the "sessiontimeout" variable in Admin->Variables page? The quiz time limit cannot exceed this setting, which is site-wide. Set it to a greater value, two hours for example.

Post title: New quiz attempt - infinitely loading startattempt
Post description: Hi, I have a situation I can not see how to resolve it. When a student wants to start a new quiz attempt and clicks the button Start attempt, he is redirected to ../moodle/mod/quiz/startattempt.php (from mod/quiz/view.php?id=x). On this page the white screen awaits him with only an instruction to click the Continue button to be redirected on actual quiz page. When he clicks Continue link button he gets to his quiz link with questions (mod/quiz/view.php?id=x), if not he stays on the white page (moodle/mod/quiz/startattempt.php) infinitely. It occurred after my update to actual 3.3.2 version, before there was no such redirection issue. Did anyone has the same issue and how to solve it? Error messages on the screen: Fields list in snapshot record does not match fields list in 'quiz_attempts'. Record is missing fields: date_started line 906 of /lib/classes/event/base.php: call to debugging() line 373 of /mod/quiz/locallib.php: call to core\event\base->add_record_snapshot() line 2313 of /mod/quiz/locallib.php: call to quiz_attempt_save_started() line 111 of /mod/quiz/startattempt.php: call to quiz_prepare_and_start_new_attempt() Thank you very much for your feedback. Regards, Misko
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: From the error message, it I looks like you have installed some add-on, which has added a non-standard column date_started to the quiz_attempts table. (These are the columns that 'should' exist https://github.com/moodle/moodle/blob/v3.3.2/mod/quiz/db/install.xml#L128 ) That is what is triggering the error in Moodle core.
